PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 10.00 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: East Timor
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned draws to the attention of the Senate Indonesia's continued denial of human rights to the people of East Timor.
Your Petitioners ask the Senate to call on the Australian Government to:
1. actively support all United Nations resolutions and initiatives on East Timor;
2. actively support the right to self‐determination of the people of East Timor;
3. work for the immediate release of all Timorese political prisoners;
4. repeal the Timor Gap Treaty; and
5. stop all military cooperation and commercial military activity with Indonesia.

PETITION.TITLE: Chemicals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned respectfully call upon the Federal Government to introduce legislation that will require the National Registration Authority to provide all available information on registered chemicals.

PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled
This Petition of the undersigned Australian citizens respectfully points out that:

There is an urgent demand from the majority of Australians for immediate Federal Government intervention, to comply with the United Nations Biodiversity Convention to which Australia is a signatory, and protect the remaining high conservation value forest areas which support flora and fauna unique to Australia.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to:

PARA.TAB: immediately implement the moratorium clause in the 1992 National Forest Policy Statement, and cease all logging activities in high conservation value forests;

permanently protect in reserves, all old growth, wilderness, and other high conservation value forest areas, under the custodianship of Australian indigenous peoples, in cooperation with local communities, conservation and scientific organisations;
reap only what is sown by utilising readily available plantation timbers for industry needs;
rapidly implement timber industry transition from native forests to plantations, with provision for retraining, redeployment, and compensation if necessary for affected workers and contractors;
restructure the paper and fibre board industries to use annual fibre crops such as kenaf, hemp, cane etc.

create employment incentives to collect seeds, propagate, establish and manage sustainable permaculture‐style mixed species timber plantations, on existing cleared and degraded lands, and encourage investment in the growing and marketing of indigenous forest products, such as native fruits, nuts, berries, seeds, oils, and other nutritional and medicinal resources.
develop educational environmental tourism as a sensitively managed industry, in appropriate forest areas, with full respect for Aboriginal cultural heritage and sacred sites; and
further support the above initiatives by the progressive utilisation of defence personnel, resources and funding, to assist rural communities to implement sustainable plantation forestry practices.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Croatia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The Petition of certain Australian citizens draws to the attention of the Senate the need to establish an Australian Embassy in the Republic of Croatia:

PARA.TAB: because of the many difficulties experienced by Australian citizens accessing limited consular services when travelling through Croatia;
because of the limited consular services in Croatia, requiring Australian citizens to visit the Australian Embassy in Austria, incurring travelling and other costs; and
to establish and maintain economic and political ties, for the mutual benefit of Australia and the Republic of Croatia.

PETITION.PARA: Your Petitioners respectfully request that the Senate should:

PARA.TAB: Take appropriate and immediate action to establish an Australian Embassy in the Republic of Croatia

PETITION.TITLE: Landmines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The Petition of the undersigned shows that we citizens of Australia support a world‐wide ban on the production, stockpiling and use of all forms of anti‐personnel land mines.

Your Petitioners request that the Senate support our call for a world‐wide ban on the production, stockpiling and use of all forms of anti‐personnel land mines, give high priority to support for efforts to clear land mines in affected countries and use its influence to encourage other countries to financially support the clearance of land mines in poor countries.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: Panizza, Sen John; Reynolds, Sen Margaret
PETITION.TITLE: Landmines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The Petition of the undersigned shows that we citizens of Australia support the Government's efforts to assist nations with the clearing of land mines and also support a world‐wide ban on the production, stockpiling and use of all forms of anti‐personnel land mines.

Your Petitioners request that the Senate support our call for a world‐wide ban on the production, stockpiling and use of all forms of anti‐personnel land mines, give priority to expanding Australia's support for mine clearance in affected countries and use its influence to encourage other countries to give greater support to mine clearance efforts.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Panizza (from 44 citizens)and Senator Reynolds (from 285 citizens)

PETITION.PRESENTERS: Kemp, Sen Rod; Woodley, Sen John
PETITION.TITLE: Religion and Democracy in Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned requests:
(i) that those of religious conviction who have contributed to the development of Australia should be recognised in the study of Australian history to ensure that a balanced history is taught;
(ii) that any syllabus prepared on the teaching of Civics and Citizenship should include the contribution of people of religious conviction highlighting their religious motivation;
(iii) that funds be allocated to ensure that teachers are given in‐service training on their role of religious influences in the development of Australian democracy; and
(iv) that materials are produced to support the above for use in the classroom.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Kemp (from 95 citizens)and Senator Woodley (from 1,504 citizens)

PETITION.PRESENTERS: Kernot, Sen Cheryl; Reynolds, Sen Margaret
PETITION.TITLE: French Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned, wish to lodge our protest in the strongest possible terms against the resumption of Nuclear Testing. Therefore we request:
1. the immediate and permanent cessation of mining and the export of Uranium as a signal to all nations that we will not accept nuclear weapons in any form,
2. the use of all means possible to dissuade France and any other nation from Nuclear Weapons Testing,
3. that the Minister for Foreign Affairs make a submission arguing the illegality of Nuclear Weapons to the International Court of Justice.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Kernot (from 198 citizens)and Senator Reynolds (from 22 citizens)

PETITION.TITLE: French Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned expresses the widespread community outrage throughout Australia at the decision of the French Government to resume nuclear testing in the South Pacific.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate note and endorse the concerns expressed in this petition and convey to the French Parliament in the strongest terms Australia's opposition to this decision.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Papua New Guinea
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned recognises that there is an urgent need for Papua New Guinea to address their economic ills. This needs to occur with the involvement of the people of that country so a model of development that is appropriate socially and environmentally is adopted.

Your petitioners request that the Senate should direct the executive director representing Australia at the World Bank, Mr Peter Nichols, work for the renegotiation of the Structural Adjustment Program that has been imposed on PNG by the World Bank and International Monetary Fund, with the support of the Australian government. Further we request that the National Coalition for Socio‐Economic Justice, representing trade unions and community groups opposing the current SAPs, be consulted on adjustment measures advocated by the international finance institutions.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned shows: the unjust and inequitable nature of the Government's policy to restrict Childcare Assistance where a parent is outside the workforce to 12 hours per week. This policy will cause hardship to lower income families, to the children of those families, and child care workers. The Government should be condemned for breaking its promise to ensure access and affordability in child care.

Under the Government's policy parents will have to pay full cost fees after 12 hours of childcare per week if one parent is outside the workforce. This will widen the gap between rich and poor, and many child care workers may lose their jobs.
Your petitioners therefore ask that the Senate should oppose the passage of this Bill into law.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—

PARA.TAB: (i) with concern, that the terms of reference of the current independent review of BHP Petroleum's offshore safety arrangements, jointly announced by the Federal Minister for Resources (Senator Parer), the Western Australian Minister for Mines and Energy (Mr Cash) and the Northern Territory Minister for Mines and Energy (Mr Reed) on 3 April 1996, only requires the investigator to specifically examine and report on an incident on board the BHP Petroleum vessel Griffin Venture in January 1996, omitting all mention of the incident in May 1994,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the select committee known as the Select Committee on the Dangers of Radioactive Waste, appointed by resolution of the Senate on 9 March 1995, be re‐appointed, with the same functions and powers, except as otherwise provided in this resolution.
(2) That the committee be known as the Select Committee on Uranium Mining and Milling.

(3) That the committee inquire into and report on the environmental impact, health and safety and other implications and effectiveness of security agreements in relation to the mining, milling and export of Australian uranium.
(4) That in considering these terms of reference the committee is to take into account, and where necessary report on, the following issues:

PARA.TAB: (a) the environmental impact of uranium mining and milling in Australia and the effectiveness of environmental protection and monitoring in relation to existing and previous Australian uranium mining operations;
(b) the role of the Office of the Supervising Scientist in monitoring Australian uranium mining and milling activities;
(c) the health and safety implications of uranium mining and milling for workers at mining and milling sites and workers involved in the transport and handling of uranium and uranium waste;

(d) the health, safety and other effects of uranium mining and milling on communities adjacent to mine and mill sites and communities on existing or planned transport routes for uranium ore and uranium waste;

(e) the effectiveness of Australia's bilateral agreements with countries importing Australian uranium, in ensuring that Australian‐sourced uranium is not used in military nuclear technology or nuclear weapons testing activities; and

(f) the volume and location of Australian‐obligated plutonium currently in existence in the international nuclear fuel cycle (produced as a result of the use of Australian uranium), in what form it exists (for example, separated or in spent nuclear fuel), and its intended end use.

SPEECH.PARA: (5) That the committee have the power to consider and use for its purposes the minutes of evidence and records of the Select Committee on the Dangers of Radioactive Waste appointed in the previous Parliament.
(6) That the committee consist of seven senators:

PARA.TAB: (a) three nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate;
(b) two nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate;
(c) one nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats; and
(d) one nominated by the Greens (WA) or Independent Senators.

SPEECH.PARA: (7) That the chair of the committee be elected by the members of the committee.

(8) That the quorum of the committee be three members with one representing the Government, one representing the Opposition and one representing either the Australian Democrats, the Greens (WA) or Independent Senators.
(9) That the chair is authorised to make statements to the media on behalf of the committee concerning its activities, without disclosing confidential proceedings of the committee.
(10) That each statement to the committee by a person in relation to the inquiry be published only after a resolution to that effect by the committee.
(11) That the committee report to the Senate on or before the last day of sitting of 1996.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Impacts of Uranium Mining and Milling in Kakadu National Park Committee

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move that a select committee to be known as the Select Committee on the Impacts of Uranium Mining and Milling in Kakadu National Park be established. The details of this proposal are set out in the notice I now circulate.

—That almost would suggest there is no point in giving notices of motion at all if we are going to get into this practice of just circulating them and saying that they have been circulated. That has been the practice in relation to formal matters or procedural motions and there is no problem with that. But if you are seeking something as important as setting up a select committee into uranium mining and milling, then I think you should at least tell us what the objects and purposes of your proposal are in the same way as the Greens did, because we are particularly interested to work out where the Greens sit vis‐a‐vis the Labor Party on this particular issue.
—Give them a bonus; read the lot.
—You can read the lot if you like.
—Order! It is a common practice for select committees to be dealt with in this way because of the complexity of the motions. But if you want him to read it, I am sure he can.
—I am more than happy, given the churlishness of Senator Hill, who obviously got out on the wrong side of bed this morning, to read the details. This is a most unprecedented call by Senator Hill.
—Just because you did badly on Lateline , don't get churlish.
—Very, very poor, I understand, describes the same. As I indicated, the details of this proposal are:

BREAK.PARA: (1) That a select committee to be known as the Select Committee on the Impacts of Uranium Mining and Milling in Kakadu National Park be established.

(2) That the committee inquire into and report on the following issues in relation to proposals for further uranium mining and milling in and adjacent to Kakadu National Park, with particular reference to the Jabiluka and Koongarra project areas:

TALK.START.PARA: —If you speak a bit slower, Senator Kemp may pick up what you are saying.
—No, he is grunting as a matter of fact. I am just not clear what the grunts mean.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The Governor-General made very clear yesterday that there were different standards applying in this chamber. We have an allegation of churlishness by the Leader of the Opposition about Senator Hill's behaviour. Now we have the attribution of animal tendencies to Senator Kemp. I ask that the Leader of the Opposition conforms to the accepted standards.

—On the point of order: it is usual in this chamber for any senator to give a notice of motion and, in the interests of seeing the business dealt with expeditiously, to seek to circulate the notice. That is a normal practice—a normal procedure in this chamber, which I sought to comply with to save this chamber time. It was churlish of Senator Hill. Senator Hill is well aware that what I did was not only in order but also to assist the Senate deal with important matters—
—You're embarrassed by the three mines policy, aren't you?
—And even give you an opportunity to get your act together on the procedures.

—Order! I was hoping that we would start a little better than this. I take the point that Senator MacGibbon makes. I was asking Senator Faulkner to get back to the notice and I ask you to do that now, senator.
—Thank you, Mr President:

PARA.TAB: (a) the cumulative risks to the environment of further mining and milling;
(b) the social and economic impact of uranium mining and milling on Aboriginal communities;
(c) the adequacy of current impact assessment processes, in particular whether they cover the social and economic impacts of the proposals;

(d) the occupational health and safety implications for workers at mining sites and those involved in the transport and handling of uranium and uranium waste, (In considering this term of reference, the committee should have regard to the adequacy of the applicable occupational health and safety laws, and the mechanisms for their enforcement);

(e) the health and safety implications for the residents of communities adjacent to mine and mill sites, and existing or proposed transport routes for uranium ore and waste, (In considering this term of reference, the committee should have regard to the adequacy of the applicable laws, and the mechanisms for their enforcement);
(f) the implications of further mining and milling on the world heritage values of the Kakadu National Park, Northern Territory;

(g) the consistency of any proposed projects with the Precautionary Principle and Australia's international treaty obligations under, for example, the Biodiversity Convention, the World Heritage Convention, and the Ramsar Convention;
(h) the risks associated with the long‐term storage of radioactive waste in Australia deriving from uranium mining and milling; and

TAB.TAB: (i) the adequacy of the steps the Australian Government takes to satisfy itself that sufficient efforts are being made in customer countries to overcome the difficulties in disposing of waste which will arise from the use of Australian uranium.

BREAK.PARA: (3) That the committee report to the Senate on or before 25 November 1996.
(4) That the committee consist of eight senators:

PARA.TAB: (a) three nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate;
(b) three nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate;
(c) one nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats; and
(d) one nominated by the Greens (WA) or Independent Senators.

BREAK.PARA: (5) That the chair of the committee be elected by members of the committee.
(6) That the deputy chair of the committee be elected by and from the members of the committee immediately after the appointment of the chair.
(7) That the deputy chair act as chair when there is no chair or the chair is not present at a meeting.
(8) That in the event of the votes on any question before the committee being equally divided, the chair, or the deputy chair when acting as chair, have a casting vote.

(9) That the quorum of the committee be three members with one representing the Government, one representing the Opposition and one representing either the Australian Democrats, the Greens (WA) or Independent Senators.
(10) That the committee may proceed to the despatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.

(11) That the committee and any subcommittee have power to send for and examine persons and documents, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives.

(12) That the committee have power to appoint subcommittees consisting of three or more of its members, and to refer to any such subcommittee any of the matters which the committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a subcommittee be a majority of the Senators appointed to the subcommittee.

(13) That the committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the committee, with the approval of the President.
(14) That the committee be empowered to print from day to day such documents and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.

(15) That the committee may report from time to time its proceedings and evidence taken or any interim conclusions or rec ommendations arising from its inquiry, and may make regular reports on the progress of its proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: HEALTH LEGISLATION (POWERS OF INVESTIGATION) AMENDMENT BILL 1996

This bill sets the scene for a co‐operative approach to legislation in this Parliament. The legislation before us today was initiated in the last Parliament and was supported by the Coalition. Today we are honouring this support and invite the Opposition's continuing support of these amendments concerning investigative powers held by the Health Insurance Commission.

These powers permit the Health Insurance Commission to obtain information and conduct searches in order to monitor compliance with Medicare guidelines. They also enable the Commission to execute search warrants and seize materials for the purposes of evidence.

This legislation will enable the continuation of these powers following the encouraging report from the Australian National Audit Office which will soon be tabled. The `Impact of Sunset Clause on Investigatory Powers Follow‐Up Audit' will confirm that the safety mechanisms employed by the HIC have ensured that powers have been used correctly.

By repealing Section 2 of the Health Legislation (Powers of Investigation) Amendment Act 1994 and Item 68 of Schedule 1 of the Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Act (No. 3) 1995, this legislation will enable the HIC to continue to conduct investigations and prepare prosecutions against providers and requesting practitioners who abuse the system.

Section 2 of the Health Legislation (Powers of Investigation) Amendment Act 1994 specifically provides that the entire Act should cease to have force on and from 1 July 1996. The sunset clause resulted from concerns expressed before the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs that the broad ranging powers provided for in the Act offered scope for corruption and abuse of delegated authority by officers of the Health Insurance Commission. It allowed for a reasonable period of time, roughly two years, for Parliament to make a considered judgement about whether the powers had been abused in any way by the Health Insurance Commission.

No evidence of improper activity by the Health Insurance Commission has arisen during this period. Moreover, the conferred powers have improved the Commission's ability to effectively detect and deal with Medicare non‐compliance and fraud. It is, therefore, important that those powers now be preserved in order to give full effect to the role and function of the Health Insurance Commission as a regulatory body over Medicare practices and fraud.

Similarly, Item 68 of Schedule 1 of the Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Act (No. 3) 1995 provides that Item 66 and the amendments made by Item 66 of Schedule 1 of that Act cease to be in force from 1 July 1996.

Item 66 ensures procedural fairness in relation to the seizure of evidential materials for the purposes of investigating Medicare fraud and over‐servicing. It does so by imposing an obligation on authorised officers or officers assisting the Commission to return material seized for the purposes of evidence in the course of conducting searches and investigat ions when the reason warranting the seizure no longer exists or a decision is made not to use the material in evidence. The item, therefore, aims to protect the interests and privacy of a medical practitioner who may come under investigation for fraud.

This bill establishes that certain measures should be kept in place to allow the continued control and enforcement of compliance with Medicare benefit guidelines. This bill aims to retain the delegation of powers which have proven, on a trial‐like basis, to be efficient, substantive and pertinent to the role of the Health Insurance Commission.

In the absence of any evidence that the powers delegated by the Health Legislation (Powers of Investigation) Amendment Act 1994 have been or are prone to being abused and distorted, the sunset clause incorporated into that Act should be repealed. In order to preserve a follow on provision in the interests of fairness and individuals' rights, the sunset clause incorporated into the Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Act (No.3) 1995 relating to Item 66 should also be repealed.
Without these amendments the sunset clause would take effect on 1 July 1996, thus seriously undermining the ability of the HIC to prevent, and prosecute against, Medicare fraud.
I commend this bill to the Senate.
THERAPEUTIC GOODS AMENDMENT BILL 1996
This bill is another example of the bipartisan approach of this Government to improving the health of all Australians.

This particular bill has had a tortuous history since it was first introduced into Parliament by the former Government in early 1995. The bill was initially part of an omnibus bill (the Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill No.1 1995) which was subsequently divided into more manageable parts.

This bill incorporates and re‐introduces the provisions of the Therapeutic Goods Amendment Bill 1995 which was passed by both sides of the House of Representatives on 28 September 1995, but was still awaiting consideration by the Senate when the Parliament rose at the conclusion of the 1995 sittings. As a result, over 600 applications for listing particular products for supply in Australia have been delayed. These applications comprise relatively simple, low risk products such as vitamin, mineral, herbal, homeopathic and sunscreen products.

The Government welcomes manageable legislation and particularly welcomes the innovations contained in this bill. We note that last year the former Government, who first moved this bill, also actively promoted the measures contained in this legislation. This legislation is therefore brought forward by the new Government as a priority bill for introduction and passage in this session.

The provisions of this bill will establish a new accelerated process for placing listable drugs supplied in Australia on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods (ARTG). This new process will significantly reduce product approval times to a matter of weeks, without in any way affecting the quality or safety of the medicinal products.

Under the new scheme, products must meet the same criteria as currently exists. These criteria include a statement that the goods are safe for the purposes for which they are to be used, being the purposes identified in the application for marketing, and not other purposes which go beyond the accepted indications for the therapeutic uses of the product.

The bill also provides a much better definition of some poorly understood aspects of the National Regulatory Scheme for Therapeutic Goods, which have been identified in its first five years of operation.

A mechanism to address shortages or lack of essential drugs required by the public in emergency situations has also been included, along with amendments that update and consolidate in a new part of the Act, the entry, search and warrant powers to enforce the legislation.

This bill introduces changes to align the monetary penalties in the current legislation with the "penalty units" classification used in other Commonwealth regulatory legislation, as well as closing a gap in the current scheme, in regard to the removal of illegal therapeutic goods of unknown quality, safety or efficacy from the market.

Also included in this bill are provisions to permit warrentless entry of premises to seize goods only where there is an imminent public health risk of death or serious injury, and where there are reasonable grounds for believing that illegal activity is taking place.

A definition for "food" has been inserted to clarify the interface between food and drugs. Problems have arisen from the present definition of "therapeutic goods" which excludes "food" but fails to define the term. What constitutes "food" in the bill will be linked to the presentation and promotion of a product in the market. The words "prescribed dose" and "frequency of administration" included in the definition are to be read in a pharmaceutical sense, and are not intended to encompass serving suggestions applied to or normally associated with food and beverages.

Other amendments in the bill include a provision to replace the Therapeutic Administration Trust Account with the Therapeutic Administration Reserve, consistent with statutory financial accountability requirements.

The appeal provisions in the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 relating to the review of decisions to register therapeutic goods have also been tightened. This will ensure that technical and scientific data that should be lodged in connection with a general marketing application, will be evaluated before a review on merits is undertaken by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The bill also corrects a defect in the legislation regarding the ability of the Secretary to approve the inclusion on the ARTG of products for export only where those products have been refused marketing approval in Australia. In these circumstances the Secretary is currently empowered to require confirmation that the relevant authority of the country to which the goods are to be exported is willing to accept the goods. This power is however limited to goods that have been manufactured in Australia for export only, and does not extend to products imported into Australia solely for re‐export. The bill proposes that this provision be amended to ensure that the Secretary's ability to require confirmation from Australia's trading partners of their willingness to accept goods refused marketing approval in Australia, extends to all products, irrespective of whether they have been manufactured in Australia or elsewhere.
Overall, this bill will benefit Australia's therapeutic industry and further enhance Australia's role as a leader in drug evaluation, registration and regulation in the region.
I commend this bill to the Senate.
Ordered that the bills be listed on the Notice Paper as separate orders of the day.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of the bills be adjourned until the first day of the spring sittings 1996, in accordance with the order agreed to on 29 November 1994.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following address-in-reply be agreed to:

PARA.EMPHASIS: To His Excellency the Governor-General

SPEECH.PARA: MAY IT PLEASE YOUR EXCELLENCY—

We, the Senate of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled, desire to express our loyalty to our Most Gracious Sovereign and to thank Your Excellency for the speech which you have been pleased to address to Parliament.

This is the Thirty‐eighth Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia. At each first sitting following the opening of parliament by the Governor-General a motion of this kind is moved. It is an established tradition and it is one that I am sure the parliament keeps. Certainly, I move it in that tradition.

In the motion, we all as senators express our allegiance to Her Majesty the Queen of Australia as head of state. In the same way yesterday, our three newest senators—Senator Mackay, Senator Lundy and Senator Conroy —swore, by oath or affirmation, their allegiance to the Queen as the head of state of Australia according to law.

I say these words with considerable warmth and sincerity, notwithstanding that I strongly support the Australian people considering constitutional reform to adopt an Australian head of state. I also note the gracious expressions of the Queen to the Prime Minister and others that she leaves the determination of that constitutional question to all Australians and that she will accept the outcome of that process.

In all of her reign, Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II has served this country well in never failing to accept the advice of the government elected by the people of Australia. Any allegiance that we give as senators or as members of the House of Representatives will, if the people of Australia change the constitution, in due course be an allegiance to whoever may be determined by the constitution to be head of state.

It was very gratifying to see the Governor-General, in one of his most important first undertakings, here in the Senate chamber yesterday representing the Queen in the opening of the Thirty‐eighth Parliament. We very much welcome the appointment of the Hon. Sir William Deane to the office of Governor-General.

On 16 February, my wife and I—I am delighted that my wife is in the chamber today, as many spouses have come to the parliament—attended the splendid ceremony in this chamber at which Sir William Deane, accompanied by his wife and family, was sworn in as our new Governor-General. This followed our farewell dinner the evening before to the retiring Governor-General, Bill Hayden, at which appropriate remarks were made by a number of representatives of the parliament.

Sir William has our genuine support from the start. As I observe it, that support is unanimous in this parliament and amongst the people of Australia. We know him already as a true Australian, an honourable man, a person who understands the constitution, which it is his duty to uphold, and a man of learning, compassion and humility—and I like the twinkle in his eye.

Very appropriately, before giving his speech opening the Thirty‐eighth Parliament we welcomed his statement in expression of sympathy for the people of Tasmania—hurt, as we all are, by the tragedy at Port Arthur on Sunday. Also, it was on his initiative that we met on Monday in one of the cathedrals in this city, representing the whole nation of Australia as it were, to pray for the people of Tasmania. In that service the Governor-General himself read from the Scripture these powerful words from 1 John 4:7,8:
Dear friends, let us love one another, because love is from God. Everyone who loves is a child of God and knows God. But the unloving knows nothing of God.
We all prayed in these words:
In our sorrow give us the calm of your peace, kindle our hope, and let our grief give way to joy.

We have, in the Senate yesterday and in solidarity with all of Australia again this morning, marked by silence our concern and sympathy for and solidarity with the people of Tasmania. It will also fall to us as legislators to give the most careful and intelligent consideration of gun law reform when that time comes. I welcome the remarks of the Attorney-General, Daryl Williams, and those of the Prime Minister, John Howard, with regard to the need for our consideration of gun law reform.

It was not only with regard to the tragedy felt by the people of Tasmania but with regard to all Australians that we began the day yesterday, the opening day of parliament, at the service of worship which is sponsored by the Parliamentary Christian Fellowship. I have the honour of having attended 19 of these services of worship. It was another inspiring occasion yesterday before we came here to assemble in the parliament.

One of the great hymns which for many years has been sung at all of our services was written by two great Australians who happen to be friends of mine, Michael and Honor Thwaites. The last verse of their hymn, with which we concluded the service yesterday, was a prayer for all Australia, not just for one state:
Lord, life‐giving healing Spirit,
on our hurts, your mercy shower;
lead us by your inward dwelling,
guiding, guarding, every hour.
Bless and keep our land Australia:
in your will her peace and power.

I now come to the Governor‐General's speech itself, which I welcome in its entirety. On this grand occasion I noticed the attention given by all 76 senators in this chamber, of all 149 members of the House of Representatives, of the members of the High Court, of our spouses, of the former Prime Ministers, of the secretaries to departments, of the press. Indeed, it was a grand occasion for the parliament, as has been the opening on all 38 such occasions.

The speech was succinct, positive and clearly displayed the values and objectives of the new government, the coalition government led by John Howard. I noticed that here in the centre of the chamber the leaders of the government, Prime Minister John Howard and Deputy Prime Minister Tim Fischer, were, if possible, the most attentive of all as it was on their advice that the Governor‐General was outlining the government's program for the three‐year period of this Thirty‐eighth Parliament.

There were no surprises. This is a government intent on keeping its promises. But, on an occasion such as this, where there has been a change of government after 13 years of a Labor government and we have the inauguration of a Liberal and National government, we can expect a flourish of announcements, we can expect a statement of idealism. It is therefore not surprising that we have reference to `excellence', `cohesion', `great responsibilities', `national challenges', `unequivocal commitment', and references to particular areas of policy, such as a realistic defence policy, a constructive foreign policy, an active trade policy, and so on.

I say again that these are good aspirations, these are the appropriately flourishing words expected by the people of Australia of this parliament and of the government. Cynics, some observers—I have not heard any in this parliament—might regard some of those phrases, the introduction and conclusion, as somewhat purple or even cliched. But I assure the Senate that the response of most of us—I think, with graciousness, of all of us—is that this is not the case because with a new government outlining the program for which it has a mandate we are not hearing hollow rhetoric; we are hearing the specific program promises of the new government.

Those specific programs relate to: youth employment; the promotion of small business; the reform of the labour market; raising national savings; boosting the competitiveness and productivity of the Australian economy; positive environmental measures; micro‐economic reform; tax relief to assist families and self‐funded retirees; new vocational and educational training initiatives; solutions to the problems of young Australians; positive policies for women, for indigenous Australians, for a multicultural Australia, for the arts, for constitutional reform, and for improving the standing of the parliament.

The speech, as we all heard, was divided into eight parts. The first relates to the government's objectives, the second to jobs, or the economy more broadly—industrial relations reform, small business, micro‐economic reform—and the third part to families, community services and the elderly.

The fourth part relates to young Australians, to jobs and training, and the fifth to regional Australia which, as I do not need to remind the Senate, was one of the important battlegrounds at the last election. Regional Australia was comprised of electorates that had to be won by whoever was to become the government. The sixth part related to foreign affairs, defence and trade. The seventh part was titled `A Cohesive Society' and stressed unifying Australia rather than dividing one part from another. It emphasised `the government's commitment to govern in the national interest and not for vested interests'. The conclusion summarised these initiatives with appropriate flourish and commitment.
Before moving to some particulars I draw attention to the first sentence of the Governor‐General's speech, which contained these gracious words:
On 2 March the Australian people entrusted to a new government the responsibility of managing the nation's affairs.

That is opening‐of‐parliament‐speak for, as politicians would say using their vocabulary, `What a beauty! We won! The election was a success for the Liberal and National parties.' After five losses in which my colleagues and I have participated through the 1980s and 1990s, it is fantastic to have a win.

One of the themes of our meeting yesterday as we greeted each other was this note of celebration and joy in winning endorsement for the Liberal and National parties' programs put forward at the election. I take this opportunity to say that I trust democracy. I believe that people get it right if they are informed. Certainly, my colleagues and I cannot argue with the democratic outcome on this occasion.

In South Australia, for example, 10 of the 12 House of Representatives seats were won by my party. In the Senate the Liberals will have six senators, the Labor Party four, the Democrats two. This is just one example of the dimension of the sweeping change in a vast national swing that has endorsed the Liberal‐National Party government.

May I also note with regard to women's representation in the parliament that South Australia continues to lead the way towards equality of representation by both men and women. As a result of the election, five of the 12 South Australian senators are women— nearly half—and four of the 12 House of Representatives members are women. Of all these women in the parliament from South Australia, two‐thirds of them are members of the Liberal Party and my good colleagues. I congratulate them all. Indeed, I congratulate all those who have won election from every party and every state.

Let me give my brief view—as I am sure this will be a theme which will be taken up in this address‐in‐reply debate—as to why we had this outcome. First of all, Labor lost the election. After 13 years it was time, and I see the gracious smiles of Labor members opposite. They are used to some victories but they distinctly lost this one. The people of Australia not only wanted to endorse a Liberal‐National Party government with all the freshness and vigour of its policies and programs but also wanted to reject the failures of Labor after 13 years.

There are three lessons I would mention. I do not say this patronisingly to my colleagues opposite, but indeed to put it on the record for all of us. One, do not mess up the economy; it loses votes. Two, do not break promises; it loses votes. Three, do not lie and do not condone lying; it loses votes. I say that very seriously. I also of course see that the greater factor in the outcome of the election was the positive program of the Liberal and National parties. Those positive programs and policies have been summarised in the Governor‐General's speech itself, and as we see the legislative program unfold over these coming months we will see that in action.

There were no disasters in the Liberal campaign: there was no GST, there were no hit lists, and there were no alarms set running about the reforms we envisaged. There was moderation, there was a sensible explanation of our polices, there was a direct appeal to represent all Australians. I congratulate John Howard, who superbly led my party's campaign, and I commend every member and senator for their efforts in the campaign.

PARA.BREAK: In the time remaining I would like briefly to address five particular matters: first, the wellbeing of Australian families; secondly, the essential investment that must be made in education; thirdly, the removal of all govern ment taxes and imposed costs on Australian exports; fourthly, the priority of Australia's foreign policy and trade in the countries in Asia, a priority that I have supported for many years; and, fifthly, the importance now of allowing the people of Australia to participate in and to own positive constitutional reform.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to the wellbeing of Australian families, I quote a statement made by Morris West, a noted Australian author, with regard to the family in the Australian Magazine just this last weekend. It touches upon a matter which I am sure is part of the incentive for the government to bring in tax relief and other measures to help strengthen families in Australia. Morris West wrote these words:

The breakdown of the family structure is very real, of that structure within which the child can be nurtured and cared for and given a set of social standards which they may later reject but which help them to survive in a moral sense. We seem to be producing on the one hand feral tribes and on the other, because of travel, closed‐end societies.

Mechanistically, the whole protective structure of society is breaking down. The notion of `parish' or village or small town which was to a degree self‐supporting and self‐educating in the moral sense is impossible to administer now. Mega‐cities are throwing people into total isolation, . . . The Internet, the global village . . . (are) driving people back on themselves: they are communicating with an inanimate object, with no tactile response or contact. The same with television, mere shadows on a screen . . . Alienation and isolation is becoming total. And if you look around at the debasement of children, of individuals, at repression, war, drugs, torture, then evil certainly is winning . . . the old notion of conflict between good and evil contains an essential truth.

I quote that not because I agree with all of it; I am actually much more optimistic. I believe that families can be constructive in finding remedies for those evils and for those tendencies which lead to alienation and amorality which Morris West has referred to.

In so far as the legislature can address these matters, we must do so as a top priority. But let me say that not everything is solved by the government or by legislation. A great deal is solved by the initiative and resources of families themselves in their personal interaction, by churches and by education processes and by community associations. We need to enhance and lead the forces that make for positive good and reinforcement in the family from all those quarters.

Let me briefly also refer to the family's current prized possession—the family home. Too often, it is a magnificent building with everything that opens and shuts but for many this prize is hardly ever used. Often the cry is, `There's nobody home.' We have sometimes seen families invest huge resources in the family home to find that it is empty or used for only six or seven hours sleep a night.

Families, in some senses, have never had so much money. They have never been richer. That is not true of all families, but I think it is true of the average Australian family. Despite this richness, many families have a reduced quality of life. For example, there is too much use of child-care centres. Child-care centres are good and they must be provided, but I think we are using them too much. Families are eating too much fast food. They are spending too little relaxed time together. I am much more optimistic than Morris West. I believe that the best models of Australian families are already addressing these deteriorations and are actually finding solutions. I wish that to be extended.

PARA.BREAK: The second issue I refer to relates to the essential investment that must be made in education. I stress that there is ultimately no way to dilute the truth that the greater part of education provision must come from the public purse—from the allocation of taxpayers' money through government budgets. There is no ultimate escape from the budget foundation that education requires real dollars from real governments. Although we may have efficiency reforms, avoidance of duplication, a contribution by students and parents through HECS, incentives for university research to win support from the private sector and so on, ultimately the coalition government and all governments must keep their promises for universities, schools and vocational education and training so that there will be no reductions in the real allocation of money from Commonwealth funding. The government's budgetary commitment to educ ation is a fundamental investment in Australia's productive future. The challenge is to make sure that that investment is secure.

SPEECH.PARA: I thirdly refer to the priority of removing all government taxes and imposed costs on Australian exports. That aspiration has been expressed by the coalition for several election campaigns. Now that the coalition can make those changes it is in a win‐win situation. Those changes will generate exports and ensure the best path to prosperity for the Australian economy and the Australian people. At the same time they will generate the political capital in regional Australia and in large and small business to ensure support in the next and subsequent elections.
Fourthly, I refer to the priority of Australia's foreign policy and trade policy in relation to the countries of Asia. The Governor-General's speech states:

. . . there will be no higher priority for the Government than advancing relations with countries in Asia, with particular emphasis on Indonesia and other members of ASEAN, Japan, Korea, China and India.
I support this priority wholeheartedly, as would be well‐known in the Senate from my speeches on foreign affairs, trade and defence matters over many years.

I also commend the next paragraph of the speech which states that the government will carry out its program in these areas through bilateral, regional and global negotiations. There will be direct bilateral negotiations, one country to another—I have advocated that for many years—which will benefit Australia. All three dimensions of negotiations will be used. The speech further states that the government:
. . . attaches particular importance to APEC as a forum for trade and investment liberalisation in the region that will also act as a catalyst for further global trade liberalisation.

I again endorse that. I believe that APEC genuinely has the bipartisan support of the parliament. The advantage is that the new government will approach achieving APEC's potential with fresh vigour and action.

The final matter I refer to is the importance of allowing the people of Australia to participate in and to own positive constitutional reform. I seek leave to incorporate in my speech the one‐page summary of the coalition's position on the republican issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted?
—Leave is not granted. I don't want to be churlish about this, but could we have a look at it?
—Yes. I will circulate it.
—Senator Teague, more than anyone else, understands the courtesy of this chamber.

—Thank you very much for your courtesy. I hope that I may receive leave to incorporate the document when I finish my speech. I wish to refer to a couple of undertakings that the coalition has made on the republican issue. Point 4 of the document states:

SPEECH.PARA: In government, the Coalition will in 1997 establish a People's Convention to debate the whole issue. There will be other matters discussed at the People's Convention. However, the issue of Australia's Head of State will be debated first and separate from other issues.
I endorse that statement and look forward to its implementation in the coming months to ensure that the coalition's undertaking is achieved in 1997. Point 5 states:
If a consensus emerges from the People's Convention regarding the Head of State, that consensus will be promoted by the Government at a constitutional referendum.

That is the commitment given by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in June last year which led to this issue being non‐contentious at the last election. As John Howard and the coalition said, Australian people will have a vote about the republic no matter who wins the next election. I am optimistic that this process will allow the people to be all the more consulted and that it will all the more determine the outcome of constitutional reform. I am even optimistic that, as a result of these undertakings by the coalition, there will be a greater prospect of the broader political support necessary to see the eventual referendum succeed.

After 18 years in the Senate, I will be leaving at the end of this initial two‐month sitting period. Nine senators will be leaving at that time, in addition to the three who were replaced by the new senators who were sworn in yesterday, all of whom we wish well. Indeed, we wish our successors—those elected at the last election—well.

This is my last speech on the address‐in‐reply. I take this chance to say that I have great faith in the parliament and in the Senate; I will say more about that later. I thank my colleagues for the honour of allowing me to move this motion for the address‐in‐reply.

I conclude by referring to the poem The First Surveyor by one of my favourite poets, Banjo Patterson. In context, there is a marvellous line where the settler says, `We know who ought to get the cheers and that's enough for us.' That is something of the spirit of this retiring senator in moving this motion for the address‐in‐reply.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted for Senator Teague to incorporate the document he referred to earlier?

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Coalition's Position on the Republican Issue

INTERJECT.PARA: The following points summarise the Coalition's approach.
1. The current Constitutional arrangements have served Australia well, delivering great stability, cohesion and tolerance.

2. Keating's comments about an Australian Head of State are an attempt to imply that anyone who opposes a republic is a lesser Australian. The reality is that over the past thirty years, the Governor‐General has become Australia's constitutional Head of State. That position has been occupied by an Australian since 1965. It is unthinkable that anyone but an Australian would occupy the position in the future.

3. Despite the success of the present constitution, many Australians are attracted to the idea of a republic and the Coalition believes that the matter should be fully debated and ultimately a vote taken on the issue before the turn of the century.

4. In government, the Coalition will in 1997 establish a People's Convention to debate the whole issue. There will be other matters discussed at the People's Convention. However, the issue of Australia's Head of State will be debated first and separate from other issues.
5. If a consensus emerges from the People's Convention regarding the Head of State, that consensus will be promoted by the Government at a constitutional referendum.
6. If no consensus emerges, then the Australian people will be asked to vote on a series of options for changes to establish which of them they desire.

These options for change will include that of electing the President by direct popular vote, as well as by a Parliamentary vote as proposed by the Prime Minister. Another method of election could also emerge as an option from the whole process of discussion. Naturally the option of retaining the present system would be included in any vote.

7. If it becomes necessary to put a series of options to the people, then a two‐stage process would be required. The first stage would be in effect a consultative referendum to determine which option for change the people wanted. Then a formal constitutional proposal would need to be put, giving legal effect to the option chosen by the people in the consultative process. Australians who support the current system could vote against the proposal.
The Coalition proposes to consult the people at all stages and will offer Australians a full range of choices.
The Coalition will give the people the Constitution they want, while Mr Keating wants to give them the republic he wants.
Australian people will have a vote about the republic no matter who wins the next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Sandy

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. I am very pleased to be given the opportunity to second this motion on behalf of the first Howard government. I am also more than pleased to be part of a coalition government which has a handsome mandate to nurture Australia and all who live here. I thank the Australian people everywhere, on the farms and in the factories, in the shopping centres and right across the six states and two territories of this vast country, for their trust and acknowledgment of our commitment to govern `for all of us'.

PARA.BREAK: I would like to congratulate the new Howard ministry, particularly our Senate colleagues and Senator Hill, and my leader, Senator Boswell. The members of the ministry have a depth of talent and previous experience of real life Australia that automati cally makes for a new style in administration. I wish Senator Faulkner well as the opposition Senate leader. He follows in that role some of the great contributors to Labor's cause in recent years, including the late Senator Murphy and former Senator Button and Senator Gareth Evans.

SPEECH.PARA: The excitement of the opening of this parliament is tempered by the tragedy in Tasmania. Violence devalues everyone because we are all transparently equal before indiscriminate violence. Much has been already said about the massacre but a major concern of mine, and one often mentioned by the former Prime Minister Mr Keating, is the unacceptable level of violence still shown on our television sets. For what it is worth, my personal view is that no extreme violence should be shown on free to air television at any time.

My first involvement with a parliamentary opening was on 4 May 1993 when the previous Governor-General, the Hon. Bill Hayden, opened the 37th parliament. As I had not yet taken my Senate seat, I listened to the speech from the President's gallery and I could not help but notice the expressions on the faces of the government members. There appeared a mixture of certainty borne of 10 years of government and absolute disbelief that they had been able to pull one last election out of a confused electorate. It seemed to me that the government had little expectation of being re-elected and the members were as surprised as everybody else that they were again in power.

I would like to congratulate the Haydens for their period in Yarralumla. It could not have been a more difficult time for a former republican and Labor minister to be Governor-General. But just as the weight of government tends to change people's perspectives, so too did his period as our head of state. He carried out his duties with decency, dignity and, above all, humour. He travelled overseas as our head of state and made constructive additions to some of the great debates of our time like euthanasia, our treatment of the aged and, in fact, the role of the Governor‐General itself.

BREAK.PARA: He is an extraordinary Australian and his path through public life has enriched us all. I wish Bill and Dallas Hayden many happy years on the farm. I understand that he recently had a fall from a horse and broke a rib. Riding is a bit like politics: we all fall off from time to time but generally most of the damage is done to our pride which, in the scheme of things, is of no importance.

Yesterday in the chamber we witnessed the traditional ceremony during which our new Governor-General, Sir William Deane, opened the 38th parliament and outlined the government's programs and priorities for the next three years. In that ceremony there was a coming together of the three components of what is known as the Westminster system: the sovereign, the Senate and the House of Representatives. The Westminster system is a flexible system and is constantly under review but it has served the English mother of parliaments well and it has served our federal and state parliaments, and in fact other parliaments throughout the Commonwealth, equally well. It is a core element of our democracy and as Churchill said, `democracy, whilst not a perfect system, is the best.' We remain one of the few and longest lived democracies in the world and our commitment to the Westminster system has largely facilitated that.

One component of our system is the sovereign, who in Australia is represented by her personal representative, the Governor-General. The role and the whole approach the coalition takes to constitutional change will be part of our program over the next few years. The coalition is determined that proper community involvement will be provided in the review of Australia's constitution. We want to build on the effective system we have, not distract or falsely claim to simplify a system of government which both federally and in the six states has made us the envy of most political entities in the world.

I do not often find occasion to quote the former Prime Minister of New Zealand, Mr David Lange, but he is quoted as having said that constitutional reform tends only to occur when an existing system withers on the vine. I do not know whether, in the broad, our system has reached that stage, though there are reforms that are necessary in the federal‐state and federal‐state‐local government relationships.

It is worth being reminded of the view held by the former Governor-General Bill Hayden—that is, a republic per se might lead to considerable political instability. We can do without that instability because, after all, the present system has worked remarkably well. To hasten slowly is essential because ultimately if there is to be change it will be the people's choice. I am pleased that we will legislate to ensure the flag cannot be changed by any government without considerable effort. I am sure that all those who fought under our present flag will be very pleased about that.

The great difference between a coalition government and a Labor government is the pre‐eminence Labor gives to special interest groups, and especially their desire to represent and foster organised labour in a way that many of us consider unrepresentative. Unions, like any other representative organisation, have a positive role to play. I am a member of a union—the National Farmers Federation. But unions, like political parties, should exist only on the basis that they earn their keep. They have responsibilities, not just rights. The fact is that almost all Australians believe that.

To tread the fine line between being fair to all and giving special favours to some is a problem that all political parties face. But it is appropriate at this time to give credit where it is due. The previous government, for better or for worse, had a commitment to Australia and I congratulate it on that. The ministers worked under enormous pressure—as all ministers do—to guide the ship of state. The often quoted statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), that the things that bring us together are much greater than the things that divide us, is very true. Australians are fortunate indeed in that regard.

During the last government's term, when Prime Minister Keating embroiled himself in changing Australia's identity or the flag, I often used to think of Adlai Stevenson's quote that patriotism is not a short and frenzied outburst of emotion but the tranquil and steady dedication of a lifetime. We all should reflect on that from time to time.

We all agree that healthy democracies require changes in government. People want to be part of the debate. Electors are not to be taken lightly. On 2 March the electorate expressed its choice, giving the coalition 94 seats in the House of Representatives, with five more seats going to Independents.

In my state of New South Wales, Labor holds only one regional seat—the electorate of Hunter—and the former Labor regional seat of Calare went to an Independent. The National Party is determined to give the electors of Calare a voice in the coalition government. I personally give my commitment to that region.

To be an Independent in Canberra is to be almost entirely ineffective. `Fine words butter no parsnips', as grandmother used to say. All the well-meaning words of well-meaning Independents are pretty irrelevant in the scheme of things. We all know that. To be an Independent in a world of difficult national decisions is akin to having a leg either side of a barbed wire fence. It is not a place to be recommended.

There has been much written about the new government's mandate. Some sections of the media and the Australian Democrats seem to have forgotten the basis of our democratic system: that is, the party which wins the most seats in the House of Representatives is the party with the mandate to govern. The coalition's policy platform was clearly laid out and became part of the policy debate during the election. Australia voted overwhelmingly for that platform.

The more cynical or humorous might argue that if the coalition had merely smiled and said, `Trust us,' the devastation of Labor might have been more complete. But we did not do that. We took the hard decisions. We released our policies—including our 1990s‐appropriate industrial relations reforms; the partial sale of Telstra; and our commitment to the family, to savings, to small business, to the young and older Australians, and to accountability in government generally—and they were clearly endorsed.

It is fair to say that new governments frequently claim a mandate but they do so at their peril if the mandate is false. This is the most honest claim to a mandate that I have ever seen in this country. I ask the Democrats to think carefully before they talk about their mandate.

After all, the coalition achieved a 46-seat majority in the House of Representatives. If we look at the Senate in isolation and at the 40 seats which were determined on 2 March, 20 seats were won by the Liberal-National parties, 14 by the Australian Labor Party, five by the Democrats, and one by the Tasmanian Greens. After 1 July, the Liberal‐National parties in the Senate will hold 37 seats out of 76. The Democrats achieved a stand alone quota only in South Australia. What that mandate amounts to is for my wise friend Senator Kernot and her team to decide.

One of the greatest challenges we face, one which transcends mainstream political differences and state and international priorities, is the environment. In a global or macro sense, the greenhouse effect, acid rain and more are important for our global village. Here at home we have enormous problems with managing our environment—with managing our major river systems, water generally and land use. Farmers in the main are the great environmental protectors. Over the years there have been examples of misuse of land. Frequently, these have been unforeseen and have been compounded by drought or through change of land use.

The importance of the landcare movement and water conservation is acknowledged by the new government, but more needs to be understood. We are absolutely committed to sustainable agriculture. We will be responsible and innovative to an environment which meets the expectations of land users—in other words, all of us. The way we harness the environment impacts on our industries, on our lifestyles and on the types and situations of new and existing regional centres. It extends to all our export earning industries, including tourism, which demands our physical environment to be protected as far as possible.

I live on the edge of the incredibly fertile Liverpool plains in New South Wales, which has some of the finest farming land in the world. Although there is substantial irrigation water available, the water table is dropping, it is frequently stressed, and the problems of salinity are now appearing.

Some parts of this area that are not used for grain are used for beef production, which is a very satisfactory use of fertile farming land. However, the current low beef prices are making the process of using that land for that purpose a near waste of time. Why are beef prices so low? Australia, which produces wonderful beef, cannot compete with our New Zealand and United States competitors to supply traditional markets, because of the inefficiencies in our abattoirs. It is the industrial relations system that presently exists in our abattoirs that therefore has an potential impact on land use in grazing areas of Australia. There is an amazing interrelationship in the economy these days.

The impact of water cleanliness is something that concerns everybody: from Centennial Park in Sydney, which takes the run‐off of five council areas and where signs give health warnings against letting your dog swim, to the horrendous public relations battle to put the problem of the Murray‐Darling Basin in perspective. Australians will never accept that this major river system should be allowed to disintegrate. The devastation of some tracts of land west of the Darling should not be allowed to increase. Problems of the environment have to be discussed, whether they concern the cotton producers, the feedlots, the piggeries or whatever. We must address these complex issues.

The linchpin of the coalition's approach to government was summed up by Mario Cuomo, a former governor of New York, when he said, `It is not the government's obligation to provide services but to see that they are provided.' That simply puts in perspective the fact that services will be provided to all Australians, whether they live on the coastal strip or in the vast outback. There is no way, from a National Party point of view, that we will not be pushing to restore the appropriate balance for people who live

outside the metropolitan areas. The previous government, largely reflecting its narrow electoral base, was particularly isolated from the inland and from an appropriate understanding of regional Australia.

I am not happy that the sort of commitment that is necessary to restore the balance to regional Australia is fully understood. I am not happy that those in the bush have been forced to the limit by drought and government indifference. I am not happy about regional Australia's health care, roads, fuel prices or access to welfare assistance—be it Austudy or access to a living wage whenever non‐performing assets exclude drought ravaged farm families from help. I am not happy about the process of committing Australia to the requirements of international treaties and United Nations conventions. These must be more subject to scrutiny by the Commonwealth parliament, the states and the community before they are entered into on Australia's behalf.

The Governor‐General outlined very important measures which the government will implement to improve the lives of Australians everywhere—improvements not just in the present but lasting into the future. I believe that good government is not just about facilitating efficiency and productivity in the public and private sectors. Good government is not just about making sure we have sufficient capital and consumer goods and services. Political and social realities and conflicts must not be entirely subsumed by economic ones. Good government is about equity and balance. The National Party will endeavour to bring those qualities to government decision making processes. Good government reflects the collective social, cultural and economic concerns of society. Good government is about improving the prospects of people. A coalition government will do just that.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me thank Senator Teague and Senator Sandy Macdonald for their contributions. I must say that, although I did not agree with all the sentiments they expressed in their speeches this morning, I do genuinely appreciate the spirit in which they were made.

BREAK.PARA: At the outset of my contribution I want to move an amendment to the address‐in‐reply motion. I move:
At end of motion add ", and the Senate is of the opinion that no part of Telstra should be sold".

The opposition is committed to a 100 per cent government‐owned national carrier. I believe that selling part or all of our communications carrier, worth some $24 billion, would be an act of gross irresponsibility in itself. For the government to claim that it will be a more competitive company after privatisation is just arrant nonsense. It has been corporatised and it is already competing very successfully in the international market.

We made our position crystal clear in the election campaign when the former Prime Minister, Mr Keating, said on January 23, `Telstra is simply not for sale.' The opposition also regards as thoroughly objectionable the government's approach of making environment policy some kind of bait or trade‐off for the Senate to agree to the sale of Telstra. That also is an absolute nonsense.

Telstra is a very strong, very vibrant company which achieved record profits of $3 billion in 1994‐95. It is aggressively seeking and claiming new markets in Asia. Its value has increased from $18 billion when John Hewson wanted to sell it to around $24 billion now. We believe that inevitably a partial sale of Telstra would lead to its complete privatisation. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has never hidden his intentions. In the election campaign, Mr Howard promised that a third of the company would be sold in the term of this government. He never denied, of course, that all the $24 billion resource would be flogged off in the longer term, including to non‐Australian companies.

I particularly want to concentrate this morning on this very shabby link that has been established between environment funding and the sale of Telstra—the holding hostage of environment funding in this country to the partial sale of Telstra. I must admit it was good to see that Tim Fischer fessed up to what it was all about, that the link was merely a ploy `to captivate a Senate vote', to use his words. I think only Tim could say that, but we all understand what he means. He said that on 2CS on 2 February 1996. The link was a ploy `to captivate a Senate vote'.

I think we need to get very clear that it was not because the hearts of those in the coalition were in the environment policies that were presented by them at the election: their land and water degradation programs, which we have heard something about already today, the rehabilitation of the Murray-Darling Basin, national river care, coasts, clean seas and the national reserves cooperative program. It was not because their hearts were in it. Understandably, of course, these very environment policies were ours, were Labor's, and they were stolen for electoral reasons.

The coalition concocted the shabby link because it wanted to flog Telstra off by captivating the minor parties. The dry agenda far outweighs the wet. I think the coalition failed in this shabby trick, failed in the election campaign, to convince a majority of Australians that this was a reasonable proposal. I think, without doubt, it was the single biggest negative that the coalition had in that election campaign.

Labor, of course, made very clear its level of commitment to the environment. We have always believed the environment in this country should be supported with adequate public funding with no strings attached. We actually happen to believe that the environment, and its protection, is a vital issue in its own right.

In our own time in government, without strings, we were able to ensure the protection of Uluru, Kakadu, the Franklin River and, more recently, Jervis Bay, Shoalwater Bay and the Hinchinbrook Channel. In our term we expanded the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park from 14 per cent of the region to 98 per cent of the region. We introduced the national biodiversity program, the best forest policy this country has ever seen; the endangered species program; the national reserves cooperative program; the save the bush program; the one billion trees program; the Antarctic mining ban; the national corridor of green; the river health program; Waterwatch; national wetlands program; the regional environmental employment program and so on.

Each and every one of those achievements, and the many other achievements that the Labor government made in environment policy, were made with no strings attached. Any government that is worth its salt should really show the same level of passion and commitment to protecting the environment without blackmailing the electorate. I do believe the coalition for a very long time has shown a very clear uninterest in environmental issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't like it then?

—In answer to your question, Senator Hill, I do believe that the coalition's national heritage trust is a worthy objective, but I do also believe that it has to be achieved. It has to be funded without resorting to Thatcherite funding mechanisms.

BREAK.PARA: Labor does not accept that the government has an unfettered mandate to sell Telstra. During the election campaign, the Labor Party made its position absolutely clear on this issue. I well remember the day in the election campaign when the announcement was made in relation to the part privatisation of Telstra and establishing the link to the coalition's environment policy. I well remember that some 60 minutes after that policy became public it was tagged as, `This is the Telstra environment policy'. I well remember that many of us in the Labor cabinet at the time very quickly considered what our approach would be.

In the 1993 election campaign—in fact, well before the campaign commenced—when an issue of similar significance came forward, which was the establishment of a goods and services tax in Australia, Labor made a decision that it would not oppose that measure in the Senate. We made our position clear, and we made that position clear because of the amount of time there had been for public debate on Dr Hewson's program, which had been exposed to the electorate some 18 months before the election.
