In the recent election campaign Labor said it would not vote for the partial sale of Telstra. We said it from the time the coalition announced its policy. We did not waver, we have not wavered, and we will not waver. We gave a commitment to those people who voted for Labor in the House of Representatives and the Senate that we would do everything in our power to maintain Telstra in public ownership.

We have heard from a number already in the chamber that the Liberal Party has a majority to put its programs into effect. Undeniably, the Liberal Party does have a very handsome majority in the House of Representatives. It is a truism, of course, that it does not have a majority in this chamber. There is no doubt that some Australians who voted for the coalition in the House of Representatives did not vote for coalition candidates in the Senate.

Throughout the election campaign, from the time the environment policy of the coalition and the proposal to partially sell Telstra was announced, the position of Labor, the Australian Democrats and Green candidates on the Telstra issue became clear. I have never been in any doubt that some voters may well have cast their vote in favour of coalition candidates in the House of Representatives knowing full well that the chances of the Senate passing legislation to enable the privatisation of Telstra were extremely remote.

I believe that we do always need to take account of the impact our parliamentary system and processes have on the concept of mandate. No-one in Australia expects any opposition to just roll over and allow legislation to flood through the Senate or upper house without appropriate scrutiny. No-one believes that. A free flow of legislation, a rubber stamp by the Senate, does appear to be Senator Hill's dream scenario, but it has never happened before—never in Australian political history.

PARA.BREAK: I also want to make this point: in Labor's approach to opposition in this chamber we are going to be both sensible and constructive. We are not going to take the same approach that the new government parties did in this chamber when they were in opposition. Just this morning when poor old Senator Kemp was floundering with his first efforts as Manager of Government Business in the Sen ate, I was there to assist him. The government received the assistance of the opposition just this morning.

BREAK.PARA: I have to say that, while we will take our responsibility seriously when legislation comes before us, we will be judicious in our approach. We will be judicious in our review. We will not be obstructionist. We will not be resorting to the same sorts of tactics at which the coalition became expert over 13 years in opposition. We are not going to involve ourselves in deliberate disruption. We are not going to involve ourselves in time wasting. We are not going to involve ourselves in filibustering. We are going to behave in a sensible and constructive way.

In relation to the Telstra scam during the election campaign—and that is what it was: a scam—we believe we have an absolute obligation, an absolute commitment, to the people who voted for us, and we intend to keep the faith with them. We indicated what we would do loud and clear during the election campaign. We do want to take this early opportunity to give the Senate a chance to indicate its view in relation to the part sale of Telstra.

We also have concerns about the manner in which the part privatisation policy was presented. That is of concern to us. I point out that the coalition pulled out its rolled gold environment vision at the last moment in the middle of an election campaign and linked it to the sale of Telstra without giving the electorate time to digest the sleight of hand that was involved.

I happen to believe that the two campaign promises—environment and telecommunications—are chalk and cheese, except one was the political bait in a clumsy trap, as Mr Fischer said, to captivate minority parties in the Senate. Why did the sale of Telstra need bait? I suppose because without the environment policy no-one at all would swallow the privatisation of this vital public utility that delivers cross‐subsidised services across the nation.

The Liberals, I think, know that there is strong community opposition to the sale of Telstra and that Australians will not swallow the sale of Telstra. Labor is not going to swallow the sale of Telstra. We will respect majority opinion always and, I believe, in this respect we reflect a clear majority view and, certainly, a Labor constituency view in the electorate.

I do not think that anyone in this chamber should feel comfortable and relaxed about Mr Howard's promise that only a third of Telstra would be sold during his first term of office. We have seen already a clear propensity on the part of this new government to break the election promises that were made, such as the promise that only 2,500 public sector workers were going. Already we have got department heads hinting that not only will there be very significant numbers more going than the 2,500 indicated in the election campaign but, of course, now those numbers will not be from natural attrition.

In my own shadow portfolio area, we heard that all social security entitlements would be on the table after a clear and unequivocal commitment to maintain them. Another example is the maintenance of funding for the ABC.

So I think that there will be a great deal of concern in the community about the government's willingness and commitment to honour its election promises. The key election promise in relation to the proposed sale of one‐third of Telstra will be no more than just the thin end of the wedge, as will be the proposal of limited foreign ownership. I do urge the Senate to take this early opportunity to reject this proposal by supporting the amendment that I have proposed.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Senator Kemp) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 12, I lay on the table a further warrant nominating Senators Childs, Colston, McKiernan, Reynolds and West as Temporary Chairmen of Committees when the Deputy President and Chairman of Committees is absent.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Kemp) proposed:
That the following sessional orders be agreed to:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 1. Reference of bills to committees

PROCTEXT.PARA: (1) That a standing committee, to be known as the Selection of Bills Committee, be appointed to consider all bills introduced into the Senate or received from the House of Representatives, except bills which contain no provisions other than provisions appropriating revenue or moneys, and to report:

PARA.TAB: (a) in respect of each such bill, whether the bill should be referred to a Legislative and General Purpose Standing Committee; and
(b) in respect of each bill recommended for referral to a standing committee:

TAB.TAB: (i) the standing committee to which the bill should be referred,
(ii) the stage in the consideration of the bill at which it should be referred to the standing committee, and
(iii) the day which should be fixed for the standing committee to report on the bill.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (2) That the following provisions apply to the Committee:

PARA.TAB: (a) the Committee consist of the Government Whip and 2 other Senators nominated by the Leader of the Government, the Opposition Whip and 2 other Senators nominated by the Leader of the Opposition, and the Whips of any minority groups;
(b) the quorum of the Committee be 4 members;
(c) the Chair of the Committee be the Government Whip, and the Chair appoint from time to time a Deputy Chair to act as Chair when the Chair is not present at a meeting; and
(d) in the event of votes on a question before the Committee being equally divided, the Chair, or the Deputy Chair when acting as Chair, have a casting vote.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (3) That, where the Committee reports on any sitting day, the report be presented after consideration of formal motions.

(4) That, following the presentation of a report by the Committee, the Chair of the Committee, or a member of the Committee on behalf of the Chair, may move without notice a motion for the adoption of the report.

(5) That amendments may be moved to a motion under paragraph (4), including amendments to refer to a standing committee any bill of the kind referred to in paragraph (1) which is not the subject of a motion moved pursuant to paragraph (4).
(6) That an amendment of the kind referred to in paragraph (5) shall specify:

PARA.TAB: (a) the standing committee to which the bill is to be referred;
(b) the stage in the consideration of the bill at which it is to be referred to the committee; and
(c) the day on which the committee is to report.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (7) That, upon a motion moved pursuant to paragraph (4), a Senator shall not speak for more than 5 minutes, and at the expiration of 30 minutes, if the debate be not sooner concluded, the President shall put the question on the motion and any amendments before the Chair, but if a Senator wishes to move a further amendment at that time, that amendment may be moved and shall be determined without debate.

(8) That, where a motion moved pursuant to paragraph (4) is agreed to with or without amendment, at the conclusion of the stage of the consideration of a bill referred to in the report adopted by that motion or in an amendment, the bill shall stand referred to the standing committee specified, and the further consideration of the bill shall be an order of the day for the day fixed for the presentation of the report of the standing committee.

(9) That, in considering a bill referred to it pursuant to this order, a standing committee shall have no power to make amendments to the bill or requests for amendments, but may recommend amendments or requests for amendments which would be in order if proposed in a committee of the whole.

(10) That a report from a standing committee relating to a bill referred to it under this order shall be received by the Senate without debate, and consideration of the report deferred until the order of the day relating to the bill is called on.
(11) That, when the order of the day relating to a bill which is the subject of a standing committee report pursuant to this order is called on, the following procedures shall apply:

PARA.TAB: (a) a motion may be moved without notice that the report of the standing committee be adopted (if the standing committee has recommended amendments to the bill, this motion shall have the effect of amending the bill accordingly, but may not be moved if other proposed amendments to the bill have been circulated in the Senate by a Senator);

(b) if a motion under subparagraph (a) is moved, following the disposal of that motion a motion may be moved by a minister, or, in respect of a bill introduced into either House of the Parliament other than by a minister, by the Senator in charge of the bill, that consideration of the bill be an order of the day for a future day, or that the bill not be further proceeded with;

(c) if no motion under subparagraph (a) or (b) is agreed to, a motion may be moved without notice that the bill again be referred to the standing committee for reconsideration, provided that such motion:

TAB.TAB: (i) indicates the matters which the standing committee is to reconsider, and
(ii) fixes the day for the further report of the standing committee,

and if such motion is agreed to the bill shall stand referred to the standing committee, and the further consideration of the bill shall be an order of the day for the day fixed for the further report of the standing committee; and

PARA.TAB: (d) if no motion under subparagraph (b) or (c) is agreed to, consideration of the bill shall be resumed at the stage at which it was referred to the standing committee, provided that, if the consideration of the bill in committee of the whole has been concluded and the standing committee has recommended amendments to the bill or requests for amendments, the bill shall again be considered in committee of the whole.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (12) Where:

TAB.TAB: (a) the Selection of Bills Committee recommends that a bill be referred to a select committee; or
(b) a Senator indicates that the Senator intends to move to establish a select committee to consider a bill or to refer a bill to an existing select committee,
this order shall have effect as if each reference to a standing committee included reference to a select committee.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (13) That the foregoing provisions of this resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the standing orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the standing orders, but without limiting the operation of standing orders 25 and 115.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 2. Motions and amendments to refer bills to committees—time limits

PROCTEXT.PARA: That, in debate on a motion on notice and a motion under standing order 115 to refer a bill to a committee, and on an amendment for that purpose to a question in respect of any stage in the passage of a bill after its second reading, a Senator shall not speak for more than 5 minutes, and at the expiration of 30 minutes, if the debate be not sooner concluded, the President shall put the question on the motion and any amendments before the Chair, but if a Senator wishes to move a further amendment at that time, that amendment may be moved and shall be determined without debate.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 3. Debate on bills received from the House of Representatives

PROCTEXT.PARA: (1) That, when a motion for the second reading of a bill received from the House of Representatives is moved and no motion for the adjournment of debate on that motion is moved, or when an order of the day for the consideration of a motion for the second reading of such a bill is called on, and no Senator indicates, by writing provided to the President before that time or orally at that time, that the Senator requires debate on the motion for the second reading, the question on that motion shall be put forthwith without debate.

(2) That, when the motion for the second reading of a bill has been put without debate in accordance with paragraph (1), a Senator shall not speak for more than 5 minutes to the motion for the third reading of that bill.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 4. Motions for suspension of standing orders—limitation of debate

PROCTEXT.PARA: That, notwithstanding anything contained in the standing orders, in a debate on a motion for the suspension of any standing or other order a Senator shall not speak for more than 5 minutes, and if the debate is not concluded at the expiration of 30 minutes after the moving of the motion the question on the motion shall then be put.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 5. Parliamentary secretaries—powers

PROCTEXT.PARA: That any Senator appointed a parliamentary secretary under the Parliamentary Secretaries Act 1980 may exercise the powers and perform the functions conferred upon ministers by the procedures of the Senate, but may not be asked or answer questions which may be put to ministers under standing order 72(1) or represent a minister before a legislation committee considering estimates.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 6. Speaking times—debate on motions

PROCTEXT.PARA: That, subject to the time limits applying to specified debates:
(a) a Senator shall not speak for more than 20 minutes in a debate on any motion;
(b) the time taken to make and determine points of order shall not be regarded as part of the speaking time of a Senator; and
(c) the time taken to form a quorum shall not be regarded as part of the speaking time of a Senator.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 7. Broadcasting of legislation committees when considering estimates

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the public proceedings of legislation committees when considering estimates may be relayed within Parliament House and broadcast by radio and television stations in accordance with the conditions contained in paragraphs (4) and (5) of the Order of the Senate of 23 August 1990 relating to the broadcasting of committee proceedings, and in accordance with any further conditions, not inconsistent with the conditions contained in those paragraphs, determined by a committee in relation to the proceedings of that committee.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 8. Times of sitting and routine of business

PROCTEXT.PARA: That, notwithstanding anything contained in the standing orders, the following procedures apply:
(1) The days and times of meeting of the Senate in each sitting week shall be as follows:
(2) (a) On Monday and Tuesday the routine of business shall be:

TAB.TAB: (ii) Motions to take note of answers
(vii) Any proposal to debate a matter of public importance or urgency
(viii) Not later than 5 pm, government business
(ix) At 9.20 pm, consideration of government documents for up to 30 minutes under standing order 61 (Tuesday only)

PARA.TAB: (b) On Wednesday the routine of business shall be:

TAB.TAB: (ii) At 12.45 pm, matters of public interest under sessional order
(iv) Motions to take note of answers
(x) Any proposal to debate a matter of public importance or urgency
(xi) Not later than 6 pm, government business
(xii) At 6.50 pm, consideration of government documents for up to 30 minutes under standing order 61

PARA.TAB: (c) On Thursday the routine of business shall be:

TAB.TAB: (iii) Motions to take note of answers
(ix) Any proposal to debate a matter of public importance or urgency
(x) Not later than 4.30 pm, general business (including further consideration of government documents)
(xi) Consideration of committee reports and government responses under standing order 62

PARA.TAB: (3) (a) The question for the adjournment of the Senate shall be proposed at 9.50 pm on Mondays and Tuesdays and 7.20 pm on Wednesdays and Thursdays, but if the consideration of government documents under stand ing order 61 concludes before the expiration of 30 minutes on Tuesday or Wednesday, the question for the adjournment shall then be proposed.

TAB.TAB: (b) Debate on the question for the adjournment shall not exceed 40 minutes, and a Senator shall not speak to that question for more than 10 minutes.
(c) At the expiration of 40 minutes, or at the conclusion of debate, whichever is the earlier, or if there is no debate, the President shall adjourn the Senate without putting the question.
(4) The consideration of government documents for up to 30 minutes under standing order 61 shall be called on only on Tuesday at 9.20 pm and Wednesday at 6.50 pm.

(5) (a) If a committee report is presented after the discovery of formal business and before the commencement of any other business on Wednesday or Thursday, a motion may be moved relating to the report.
(b) A Senator speaking to such a motion shall not speak for more than 10 minutes, and debate on all such motions shall not exceed one hour.
(c) If a debate is not concluded at the expiration of that time the debate shall be made an order of the day for Thursday at the time for consideration of committee reports.
(6) Matters of public interest may be discussed under sessional order only between 12.45 pm and 2 pm on Wednesday.

(7) Immediately after question time on any day motions may be moved to take note of answers given to questions without notice in accordance with the terms of the sessional orders relating to questions without notice.

(8) Debate on a matter of public importance or urgency motion under standing order 75 shall not exceed one hour, or, if no motions are moved after question time to take note of answers, 90 minutes, and a Senator shall not speak to such a matter or motion for more than 10 minutes.

(9) Where a motion is moved by leave in relation to a document presented to the Senate, including a document presented to the President when the Senate is not sitting, a senator speak ing to such a motion shall not speak for more than 10 minutes, and debate on the motion shall not exceed 30 minutes; where two or more such motions are moved in succession, debate on all motions shall not exceed 60 minutes.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 9. Consideration of government documents—amendment of standing order

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the following amendment of standing order 61 operate as a sessional order:
After paragraph (1), insert the following paragraph:

PARA.TAB: "(1A) Immediately after prayers on any day when consideration of government documents occurs, a minister may present documents by handing them to the Clerk without any announcement to the Senate, and the presentation of such documents shall be reported to the Senate by the President when the consideration of government documents is called on under this standing order.".

PARA.EMPHASIS: 10. Matters of public interest

PROCTEXT.PARA: That, notwithstanding anything contained in the standing orders, on Wednesdays at 12.45 pm till 2 pm matters of public interest may be discussed by senators without any question before the Chair, provided that a senator shall not speak for more than 15 minutes, and if a division is called for, shall be taken at a later hour of the day, not being earlier than 2 pm.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 11. Questions without notice—time limits

PROCTEXT.PARA: That, during question time:
(a) the asking of each question not exceed 1 minute and the answering of each question not exceed 4 minutes;
(b) the asking of each supplementary question not exceed 1 minute and the answering of each supplementary question not exceed 1 minute; and
(c) the time taken to make and determine points of order not be regarded as part of the time for questions and answers.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 12. Answers to questions without notice—limitation of debate

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the following conditions apply to debate on motions relating to answers given to questions without notice:
(a) motions shall relate only to answers given that day to questions without notice;
(b) a Senator may speak for not more than 5 minutes on such a motion;
(c) the total time for debate on all motions relating to answers to questions without notice on any day shall not exceed 30 minutes; and
(d) the time taken in raising and determining any points of order during debate under this order shall not be regarded as part of the time allowed for debate under this order.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 13. Consideration of committee reports and government responses

PROCTEXT.PARA: That consideration of committee reports and government responses under standing order 62 take place on Thursdays, after the time for the consideration of general business.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the first tasks of any new Senate is to put in place its sessional orders, the last sessional orders having expired with the commencement of this sitting. In this instance, the new government has given considerable attention to drafting a suggested set of sessional orders that I think is both fair to all senators but also reflects the need and commitment of the government to get its legislation dealt with by this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators would have read the details of the proposed sessional orders as they appear in the Notice Paper. In fact, honourable senators would have read them earlier because the basis of the drafts as they appear in the Notice Paper was circulated to all parties last week by the Manager of Government Business in the Senate, Senator Kemp.

You will see that we build upon the past sessional orders and the experiences of the management of this place that have been gained over a long period of time. In fact, there are not very many changes that we are suggesting from the contents of the last set of sessional orders.

Most of these provisions, I would have thought, are not contentious in any way. We had a few contentious ideas but during the consultation process we actually removed them. So I am surprised that today we apparently do not have support from all corners of this chamber.

PARA.BREAK: The first of these sessional orders relates to the reference of bills to committees. This is a good practice which was adopted some time ago in this place. It allows for an accelerated process of consideration of government legislation by committees and is as an imp rovement in many ways on the committee of the whole debate within the chamber. I think that all senators believe it has worked reasonably well. I think the legislation committees that receive the bills through this mechanism could do even better in encouraging the contribution of the public to the process.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the advantages of taking the bill out of the chamber and into the legislative committees is that the committee can then listen to the community. A strong democracy in many ways is demonstrated by the level of contribution of the community. Certainly, the interest groups that are based in this city—the professional lobby groups and the like—become aware of these considerations by committees and do contribute. It would be good if the wider public became better aware of the process of consideration of these bills in committees and were given the opportunity to contribute. I do not think, as far as I can work out, that there is any concern about reinstating the provisions for reference of bills to committees. But if there is, no doubt we will learn of it in the very near future.

The second of these sessional orders relates to time limits for motions and amendments to refer bills to committees. As I recall it, that is again reinstating the existing provisions. I have not heard any suggestion that there is a wish within the chamber to change from those procedures.

The third sessional order that we put before the Senate today is that which deals with debate on bills received from the House of Representatives, which is what we commonly refer to in here as the cut‐off motion. Over a long period of time the Senate has sent a message to the government of the day that, for it to effectively operate as a house of review, there is a need for legislation to be given adequate time for consideration and therefore orderly process and the orderly introduction of bills into this place is sensible practice. Unfortunately, Labor failed to appreciate that and therefore the Senate, in the past, felt that it needed to entrench that sentiment within the sessional orders.

We have a different attitude because we in fact recognise the importance of the principle. Nevertheless, rather than get into a debate on it, and just in case our good faith is not totally appreciated by the new opposition, we are proposing that this cut‐off motion remain in the sessional orders. I do not think that there will be any opposition to that as well.

The fourth sessional order is that which imposes limitations of debate in relation to motions for suspension of standing orders. That is a practice that has been in place for some time now, and I think that it has maintained wide support around the chamber. I doubt that there will be any concern expressed about that.

The fifth sessional order relates to the powers of parliamentary secretaries. Again we have simply adopted past practices, so I do not think that there will be any dispute there. In passing, for the benefit of Senator Faulkner, there is an argument that it might be useful practice for parliamentary secretaries to appear in estimates committees in relation to portfolios in which the minister in this chamber has a representational capacity. Nevertheless, as we objected to that on the last occasion, we think that it is probably not worth while revisiting that now. So the proposal we have here is in the same form that was previously agreed to by the Senate.

The sixth proposed sessional order relates to the speaking times for debate on motions. There has been in this place a trend towards encouraging shorter speeches. From time to time, we have objected to that; nevertheless, on reflection, I think it is sound practice. Whatever cannot be said in 20 minutes is probably not worth saying. Furthermore, there is always the option for the Senate—
Senator Carr interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —We learn from experience, Senator. Some of us are prepared to concede that and recognise that we can all gain from experience. If the Senate was to adopt this motion, it would be a continuation of the trend that has been adopted in recent times of encouraging speeches to be limited to 20 minutes. So this motion goes a little further than the previous sessional orders, but it is in a direction consistent with what I think has been the sentiment of the majority in this chamber. There may be some individuals that want to argue against that. I certainly would not expect that the Labor Party would argue against it because they have been calling for shorter speeches for some time as well. We will await the response of the opposition and the minority parties.

SPEECH.PARA: The seventh sessional order deals with broadcasting of legislation committees when considering estimates. I think that is in the same form as previously. I do not think there is any contentious aspect to that and I would not think that it would be opposed.

The eighth is that which deals with times of sitting and routine of business. The times of sitting in this place have always been a subject of vigorous debate and little unanimity. I have witnessed many of those debates over the last 15 years that I have been here, whether the Senate should or should not sit at night, whether it should start early in the morning, whether it should sit during the lunch break and what should be the terms and conditions if it does sit through the lunch break. What there is general agreement for, these days, is that the old practices of sitting very long hours into the early mornings is unwise Senate practice. As my colleague Senator Herron would say, it is bad for health. I think that all senators these days believe that that is the case, and I hope that that practice of the past will not be revisited. Certainly, it is not accommodated within the proposals that we put.

We are suggesting that on Monday and Tuesday the Senate meet from 2 p.m. to enable cabinet meetings and the like to take place on Monday mornings and for party meetings to take place on Tuesday mornings. We propose that the Senate sit from 2 p.m. until 6.30 p.m., after which there will be a dinner break for an hour and the Senate will continue to sit until 10.30 p.m. That would be relatively consistent with the House of Representatives, which now gets up at 11 p.m. We have decided, on reflection, that two evening sittings on the first two days of the week would be sensible Senate practice. It would enable more business to be transacted, which is what the public wants of us. It would not require the Senate to be sitting unreasonably late hours. Therefore, we are putting it to the Senate for its consideration today.

BREAK.PARA: On Wednesdays and Thursdays we are proposing that the Senate start at 9 a.m. and finish at 8 p.m. We do not think that that is unreasonable. Some would say that it is a long day's work, but it is not as if the Senate sits every week. We think that when we are here the Senate should be sitting reasonable hours, and that is not unreasonable.

Once the issue of the times is settled, there is the issue of the routine of business within those times. We have sought to protect the times available for non-government parties and individual senators. It is a very important part of the review process and of this chamber's wider role as a second chamber. We have also sought to provide blocks of time for the government's legislative program. That would be a first if the Senate agrees to that today. I think it would be a sensible reform. I would have thought that the Labor Party, which constantly complained about the time for its legislation being encroached by other business, would also come in here today and say in good faith that that would be a sensible reform. I look forward to hearing Senator Faulkner's response to that suggested change. We have designed this to protect time for the opposition and for individual senators and minority parties. We have suggested some block periods of time for government legislation, and I commend that to the Senate as a sensible practice.

The ninth sessional order concerns the consideration of government documents. I do not think there will be any problem with that. Matters of public interest is item No. 10, which reinstates the existing practice. Proposed new sessional order No. 11 deals with time limits for questions without notice. That has been the subject of long and tortuous debate in this place as well. Rather than re-visit that debate, we have suggested a continuation of the existing times. I presume that that will continue to be supported by the chamber. The twelfth sessional order relates to the limitation of debate on motions relating to answers to questions without notice. I think those time limits will be supported. The last sessional order we provide relates to the consideration of committee reports and government responses, which I think is also in the same form as before.

It will therefore be evident to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that what we are putting up for the consideration of this chamber for its sessional orders for this session is very much what we have had in the past, with just a number of changes—in particular, some changes to the sitting hours which we think flow from our experiences of recent times. When I say `our experiences', I mean the experiences of senators as a whole. The reform would give the government some block periods for the consideration of its legislative program, which would seem to be reasonable, and some further reduction of speaking times.

I therefore commend these new sessional orders to the Senate. As I said, they were circulated to honourable senators last week, so there has been plenty of time for the opposition party, minority parties and independents to form opinions on them. We would certainly wish that they be adopted today and put into place; otherwise, as I understand it, we revert to the old standing orders which were the subject of previous reform and therefore would be considered by most to be a less preferable alternative.

In many ways this will be the first test for the new opposition—whether it is prepared to approach this debate in a constructive way, whether it is going to come in here and use its relations with the minority parties and the numbers that can be created through that simply to be a nuisance and to waste the time of the chamber, or whether it is going to say from its experience that what we are suggesting is sound and sensible and therefore be prepared to support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not agree with Senator Hill when he said that this is the first test of the opposition. If it were, perhaps he might consider that the first test of the new government was the extraordinary performance that Senator Kemp and Senator Hill managed to engage in this morning. With the cooperation of the opposition, we tried to work out what, frankly, were a number of simple procedural matters for this Senate. At the outset, Senator Hill, we actually are interested in working cooperatively with the government and the minor parties in the Senate. We are interested in working out these sessional orders in the best interests of all senators. That is the standpoint from which we come. I do not believe the most appropriate way to conduct this debate is here in this chamber at this time because of the range of views that exists on all the different sessional orders that have been referred to across the Senate chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition comes to this debate with a lot of recent experience in government and a clear understanding of how Senate processes can be abused. We have, as a government, suffered that for a very long period of time. You, Senator Hill, are an absolute expert in Senate obstructionism. You, Senator Hill, are an absolute expert in wasting the time of a government. You are an absolute expert in disrupting a legislative program. You have seen it from this side of the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —You use that to excuse your managerial incompetence.

—In your contribution earlier you said there has been some `reflection'—that was the word you used—on a whole number of sessional orders. That is code for saying that on many issues Senator Hill now believes that the case I put in relation to better, more streamlined and more effective processes in this chamber was a good one. It is code for saying that he was wrong. It is really code for saying that the propositions he put forward in opposition were grossly hypocritical. That is what I think everyone in this chamber needs to understand.

SPEECH.PARA: I do in fact agree with much of what Senator Hill has said. I do in fact agree with many of the arguments he puts forward. I do believe that there is a lot of common ground between the government and opposition in relation to our approaches to what would be appropriate sessional orders for this chamber. But I also happen to believe very strongly that the most inappropriate way of trying to finalise this issue is this sort of debate in the chamber now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you remember when you let us go for a week on a procedural matter?

—I do remember it. I remember it vividly because when I approached the then opposition to work through those issues in a sensible way, I didn't get agreement on issues such as limiting speeches in the second reading debate in this chamber to 20 minutes. You were implacably opposed to that particular reform.
—Was I?

—Implacably opposed. There was a division at the conclusion of one of the longest procedural debates in the history of the Senate—I believe your vote was recorded during that division, Senator Hill—and the case that was put forward by very many then opposition speakers was something that was not embraced by the government, but it is something that you have done an enormous backflip, three turns and a pike on today. Now, not only do you agree with the contribution I made at that time and think it is a tremendous piece of Senate reform, but you are also actually looking to extend it beyond speeches in the second reading debate to a range of other speeches in this chamber. That measure would go, for example, to motions of censure of ministers and the like. And you may have a strong case.
—But you oppose it.

—No, you may have a strong case. Not only do I support a limitation of speeches in the second reading debate to 20 minutes; I also put to you that we solve that issue for the long term and show our level of commitment by enshrining those changes in the standing orders of the Senate. I support absolutely many of the sessional orders that you are proposing today and I believe they should be enshrined in the standing orders of the Senate. I would certainly support the government if it proposed to do that.

SPEECH.PARA: But what we have in the chamber is a situation where there are a range of views on a number of different procedural issues and a range of views on some aspects of these proposed sessional orders. The most obvious ones are the times of sitting and the routine of business. The opposition has a view in relation to this. I think Senator Hill's argument about the Senate trying to work closely to and reflect the sitting times of the House of Representatives to a significant degree has merit and it is something we can work through. There are different views on that in this chamber and they have been expressed on many occasions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the opposition have a view?

—At one point I became absolutely convinced that the really strong arguments you and members of the government, such as Senator Herron, put forward—that we shouldn't ever sit beyond early evening—were valid. These views were put by members of the then Liberal‐National opposition with tremendous enthusiasm. These were arguments of very great principle and passion, presented to this chamber.
—What is your view now?

—My view is that the only way to deal with all of these matters of contention, and all of those sessional orders that are agreed around the chamber, is to have a brief adjournment of this matter to deal with it outside the chamber, to work the issues through. I believe that process can be concluded certainly, with ease, by the beginning of the next sitting week. I believe that is a very sensible approach to these issues.
—What's your starting position?

—My starting position in relation to sitting times is that, with some minor amendments, the arguments are strong for the Senate sitting hours to reflect those of the House of Representatives. But I am flexible. I am willing to negotiate. I am willing to talk not only with the government but also with the Australian Democrats, the Western Australian Greens and Senator Harradine. I am willing to undergo a proper process to work this through.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not much care whether the process is a formal one through the Procedure Committee or an informal one around the table outside the chamber—I do not much care what the nature of the process is—but, as I have said to the government informally, that is the way to go and I believe we can solve it by the beginning of the next sitting week. That will mean that there will be significantly less time wasted on a whole range of unnecessary procedural debates in this chamber.

Those opposite are now the government. They have changed their views and now broadly reflect the view that the Labor Party held in government and would not be hypocritical enough to change now that we are on this side of the chamber. We are willing to sort it out. We want to sort it out.

Senator Hill, in his contribution, canvassed the cut‐off motion. That does not actually reflect the motion before us because it is subject to a separate notice of motion. But I agree that it is an important issue. I agree that the sitting times of the Senate is an important issue for us to work through. I agree that the routine of the business of the Senate needs to be sorted through. I agree that it is dependent on the times of sitting of this chamber.

The issue of the length of speeches is important. I think the government mounted a very persuasive case about that. It might be a little different from some of the cases the coalition has presented over the years but I found it terribly persuasive. There are also some issues in relation to the Procedure Committee report, specifically in relation to estimates committees, that need a little reflection.

I put to the government and minor party representatives in the chamber that, by the commencement of the next parliament, we should have obviated the need for this sort of debate by incorporating, where there is agreement across the chamber, many of these agreed sessional orders—most of them are agreed—in the standing orders. That would be a sensible reform. I would be happy to cooperate with the government to ensure that we see that significant step forward in Senate process and procedure.

But I suggest to the government that the sensible way of doing that is to have either formal or informal negotiations. I believe that by Monday of next week we ought to have an agreed position. If we do not have an agreed position, at least we should be in the position of ensuring that the areas of disagreement are absolutely limited to just a few issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —So you are not prepared to agree to any part of it?
—That is a deliberate and malicious misinterpretation of what I have said, or a deliberate misunderstanding of what I have said. I have said very clearly what the opposition's approach is.
—Tell me what parts you agree to, then we can limit the debate.
—Of course we can limit it but would it not be more sensible—
—Just tell me. You have had time to reflect on it. Why don't you put your house in order!

—You have presided this morning over one of the greatest shemozzles we have ever seen in the Senate chamber. Poor old Senator Kemp over there turned white. It was one of the worst performances anyone has ever seen. Don't you talk about getting our house in order. Everything you have done in relation to Senate procedures has been an appalling mess‐up. You have not kicked a goal in this chamber in relation to Senate procedures.

BREAK.PARA: You did not get your act together until the very end of last week. You know you could not provide to any senator any proposed standing order or proposed sessional order up until a day or so ago. It has been a pathetic performance. You were expecting a debate on this matter an hour or so ago. Senator Kemp blew that as well and we ended up on the address‐in‐reply debate. That is a very hypocritical statement for you, Senator Hill, to make.

Let me say that we agree with the proposal in terms of reference of bills to committees, which I think works comparatively well. I note that there is a minor change of wording in that particular proposed sessional order. That does not concern me. I believe that sessional order No. 2, which Senator Hill agreed to, is appropriate and I see no reason why some of these should not be incorporated in the standing orders.

The opposition has also had a similar view on motions for suspension of standing orders in relation to the powers of parliamentary secretaries. I have indicated what our position is on speaking times. I am personally perfectly comfortable with the broadcasting of legislation committees. We are happy, as I have said, within the framework I have indicated, to work through the issues of times of sitting and routine of business. There are only a few areas which I have identified which need be subject to further consideration, but it will be better—

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us which ones you agree to.
—I have gone through them, Senator. I do not want to go through them again.
—But you are deliberately doing it in an ambiguous way, aren't you? Tell us which ones you agree to.

—If you have not got it on board, let me say it to you again. There is the issue of the cut-off motion, which you addressed in your comments, so it is not subject to this particular motion. There are the times of sitting and the routine of business. There is the issue of the limitation of speeches, but I must say I was convinced by the contribution you made on that. There is the question of participating members on estimates committees, which is dealt with in one of the Procedure Committee reports. There is the issue of incorporating in the standing orders all the agreed sessional orders and the issue of ensuring that we deal with an approach to question time which, unless we sort it out outside the chamber, will probably lead to some long—but, most importantly, unnecessary—procedural debate.

BREAK.PARA: That is the approach the government is taking. The sensible thing to do, particularly given that the government has not got its act together, is to have a very short adjournment on this. We either formally refer it to the Procedure Committee or deal with it informally. I think it can be done informally, with the senators around the chamber. I think that will be a more sensible approach. Either way, in the meantime, I will listen to the advice of the government on what you want to propose for Wednesday and Thursday of this week in terms of routine of business—whether you want to look at some temporary sessional orders, whether they be the ones you propose or the ones we previously had—and what the standing orders envisage. I will listen to your advice on that issue.

That is the sensible way forward and that is the way to get a cooperative outcome—an agreed outcome—that will limit the areas of dispute, limit the areas of disagreement and limit the need for a long and turgid procedural debate in this chamber. That is what I would propose as a sensible approach on these issues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarrette, Sen Christabel

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to put on the record where the WA Greens stand in relation to the motion moved on behalf of Senator Hill. I noted that Senator Hill asked rather plaintively of Senator Faulkner whether there were any parts of the motion that we were prepared to agree to at this time. I think it would really simplify the entire debate if we adjourned until 6 May the motion that we are currently discussing, as suggested by Senator Faulkner, but if in the interim the sessional orders in relation to all matters revert to those used in the previous sittings. If we do that, my understanding is that some of the matters covered in Senator Hill's motion will be automatically put in place as they are identical to those we had in the last sitting. Some will not, and those remaining matters can be dealt with when we resume after adjourning.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the position the Greens would support—that we revert in the interim to the previous sessional orders and that we adjourn any further debate on this motion until Monday, when those sessional orders that are different from the previous sessional orders will stand out quite clearly and we can debate them on their merits and introduce them. That is the position we hold and we would be pleased to cooperate in any informal arrangements such as meeting together to achieve a consensus position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALK.START.PARA: —I actually feel quite sorry for Senator Hill. I have a file about an inch thick of his former speeches from the last parliament. Senator Kemp's is very interesting reading also. I will not read them out at the moment. I will wait until we actually come to doing routine matters. I suggest to Senator Kemp and Senator Hill that they go back and have a quick look so they will be prepared for that. I do not think I am the only one who has a file an inch thick like that; I think there are a few people who do.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me just go through a couple of things that Senator Hill said. First of all, he said `during the consultation process'. This sounded as if there was a consultation process. The consultation process, as far as I know, was as follows. Senator Kemp certainly did try very hard. He had a paper which was very well written and informative, and he did come around and discuss that with me. That was consultation, and I thank him for that.

If there is one thing that we in this chamber should have learnt from the last session of parliament, it is that, if we want to get something that will work, we have to have general agreement. I think that the current government probably knows as well as anybody that, if you disagree with what has been imposed on upon you, it is very easy to destroy the business of the Senate. It is far too easy to do. Imposition with numbers is something that the current opposition, when they were in government, tried not to do, because that is exactly what happened to them all the time.

I would rather that did not happen to this government. I would rather that did not happen to any government. The way to get over that is to have round table consultation, either informally—which, I think, in this instance, is the best way to go, because we want to do it pretty quickly, and I think we can—or else through the Procedure Committee. The last Procedure Committee inquiry into the days and hours of sitting had some very forceful evidence about long hours, not enough sleep and that sort of thing. I hope we will keep that in mind for any other consultation that we have.

We need a much more thorough and inclusive consultation process. I am very pleased to see that Senator Hill and Senator Kemp are doing a lot of reflecting and are benefiting a lot from experience. I think that will be to the benefit of all of us.

We agree with a lot of the proposed sessional orders. As Senator Hill said, a lot of them are identical to the sessional orders that we adopted in February 1994 after the last large Procedure Committee report. The first sessional order dealing with the reference of bills to committees was put forward as a Democrat motion many years ago, in the 1980s. It was Senator Macklin's idea in the first place. We still think it is a very good idea. It enables the public to have an input into bills, which we now all agree is a very good thing. So of course we are still going to think that is a good thing. The second suggested sessional order deals with time limits on motions and amendments to refer bills to committees. In general, I think we do have to have more severe time limits. Senator Faulkner has made that point already, far better than I could.

Debate on motions for suspension of standing orders has to be limited. That was an extraordinarily sensible sessional order. I do not know why it is not in standing orders; I believe it ought to be. That was put in sessional orders—like the first one on Friday committees—many years ago, I think in the early 1980s. We really should have that in standing orders. Why do we keep putting it back into sessional orders when we think it is such a good idea? Why don't we just put it in standing orders and, if it turns out to be a disaster in 50 or 100 years, we will change it again.

I have no problem with the proposed sessional order dealing with the powers of parliamentary secretaries. I do not personally have a problem with the 20‐minute time limit for each senator speaking in a debate on any motion. Considering that the opposition, which constitutes a very large part of the chamber, does have a problem with that, we should sit down and discuss it until we come to an agreement. The sessional order dealing with broadcasting is fine.

The really big one that will need discussion is times of sitting and routine of business. We may not need a lot of discussion; I think we are getting close to resolving the issue. The main thing that the government wants is blocks of government business. That is a very good idea, and it was a very good idea when the last government suggested it. If I recall, it was the last opposition which thought it was a bad idea. I shouldn't give this away, but I will: I said to Senator Kemp, `As you will recall, Senator Kemp'. He said, `Never say that to me. Say, "As you will not recall, Senator Kemp"'. That was very nice of him. That is a lovely sense of humour, and I enjoy it. As anyone who reads Hansard will recall, the current government thought it was a bad idea. I still think it is a good idea. I understand that the current opposition, which thought it was a good idea in the past, still thinks it is a good idea.

I am not quite sure that we need a quarter as much time again of the time we had for possible government business time. If the opposition, the Democrats, the Greens and Senator Harradine do not find the opportunities to disrupt the business, the same amount—or even a bit more—of government business in blocks will mean that the government actually gets more done. Perhaps it is a good idea. I think we should talk about it. That is the point: we should talk about it.

If we don't come to some agreement today, we will revert to standing orders. Those standing orders are from a considerable time away; we have been working under quite different sessional orders since February 1994. When I suggested in the meeting of the Procedure Committee before the end of the last Parliament that we maintain the 1994 sessional orders, no-one would agree. We ought to consider going back to the 1994 sessional orders and working under those. This is only until Monday. I was going to say that I don't know why we are having this debate in the chamber and not outside, but I guess there is not an awful lot else to do in the chamber. So it is fair enough really.

Senator Faulkner said that this morning was one of the greatest shemozzles the Senate has ever had. That is going a bit far. It is very often not the government's fault when there is a shemozzle. When there seems to be total anarchy in the chamber, it is in fact due to a collection of motives from different people across the chamber. I do not think the government can be blamed for shemozzles. This government was until very recently in opposition; I think they understand as well as anybody that oppositions can cause shemozzles just as easily as governments can.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not today.
—Senator Carr says `Not today'. Today was quite interesting. It must he very difficult becoming a government after being in opposition for 13 years.
—I'll describe it as a government shemozzle.
—Senator Faulkner says it is a government shemozzle. It must also be quite difficult becoming an opposition after being in government for 13 years.
—I can confirm that it is not the best.

—I thank Senator Faulkner for confirming that. We have to allow each other a fair bit of slack for the first couple of weeks. Let us do so until Monday. We should have an agreed position by then; we nearly have one now.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the very short time available before we rise for lunch, I will make a couple of very brief points. There was an attempt, which I think Senator Bourne mentioned, to put forward the government's position and to seek views. The consultations have been informal, with some senators being immediately forthcoming with their views and others wanting to take some time. There has been an attempt to put forward the government's position so that we could receive the views of the opposition, the minor parties and the independents. This debate has so far shown that we seem to be in blazing agreement. I think I heard the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Faulkner, say that he agrees with 95 per cent of the government's proposal. Agreement has not been reached on the precise sitting times and there are some issues arising in relation to the routine of government business. Those are the matters which still seem to be outstanding, but there has been an attempt to seek agreement.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 12.45 p.m. to 2.00 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the absence of agreement between the parties and Independent senators on the allocation of questions during question time, I will be allocating questions in the same pattern as in the previous parliament. This, of course, will be subject to further discussion by party whips and Independent senators. I understand also that informal agreement has been reached to apply the time limits operating under sessional order 14 on 30 November 1995 to today's question time and, with the concurrence of the Senate, I shall ask the clerks to set the clocks accordingly.

—My question is directed to Senator Hill as Leader of the Government in the Senate. Does your government stand by the statements made by the now Prime Minister on 19 February this year that, if it comes to the point between breaking election promises and running a budget deficit, you will stand by your promises?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Leader of the Opposition for his question. The opposition has a nerve to ask us a question about broken promises. When in government this opposition made an art form of broken promises. The worst aspect about it was that it was then a government which had no intention of ever keeping its promises. When your government went to the people in 1993 and promised that there would be no increase in taxation, you had no intention of keeping that promise.

ANSWER.PARA: It is that attitude and disrespect for the Australian people that played a big part in their determination that you were no longer fit to govern. Despite your promise, when you got back into government, having misled the people, what did you do? Up went indirect taxes, up went wine taxes and up went fuel taxes—leaded and unleaded fuel. The tax on fuel put a special and extra burden on the less well off in the Australian community, and so it went on.

But, in order to answer your question specifically, the difference is that this is a government which is committed to keeping its promises. We think that that is important. We made specific promises to small business, we made specific promises to families, we made specific promises to the battlers, specific promises on health and specific promises to the elderly, and it is our intention to rebuild the respect of the Australian people that you forfeited.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does this mean that you will be cutting government expenditure by $8 billion over the next two years and at the same time will not introduce any new taxes or increase existing taxes, and you will limit Public Service cuts to 2,500 by natural attrition and maintain funding for both the ABC and defence?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Faulkner knows the extent to which his colleagues—and I do not know about him—misled the Australian people on the state of the books. When we got into government, what did we find despite all the undertakings and promises to the contrary? In fact, there was a gaping black hole in the budget forecast of some $8 billion—Mr Beazley's black hole, the Minister for Finance responsible for that economic failure. We have to address that failure and address that deficit.

ANSWER.PARA: What would you have done in the past? You would have said, `We will now break our promises and put up taxation.' We do not believe that that is in the best interests of the economy or rebuilding Australia, particularly small business and providing jobs. As an alternative we say that the way we should respond to it is by tackling the expenditure side. What you were not prepared to do in government—you did not have the courage—we will have the courage to do. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Hill. I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to the recent statement by the shadow Treasurer, Mr Gareth Evans, on 4 April this year when questioned on whether Labor would be espousing different policies. He said:

QUESTION.PARA: On the whole, I don't think so, because the values and visions will remain basically the same.
I ask: has the government conducted an analysis of the last 13 years of Labor being in power?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable senator for his perceptive question.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is you who should be embarrassed because the legacy of 13 years of wasted Labor time is before all Australians. It is not only our responsibility now to tackle this legacy, but it is a legacy that is at a cost to all Australians. You should be so embarrassed that you passed over a situation where we find three‐quarters of a million Australians out of work. That is the worst part of your legacy and you should sit there and blush. There are three‐quarters of a million Australians out of work, so many more underemployed, so many lost opportunities and so many aspirations and hopes disappointed. That is your legacy.
—No‐one believes you.

—They do not believe it? You do not speak to the unemployed; that is the point. This demonstrates again why they were so unceremoniously thrown out of government. They did not care. Those opposite lost touch with the so many Australians who were not living their life of luxury and comfort, who were not dealing with the elites that they dealt with on a day by day basis—that is, ordinary Australians who are battling to make ends meet, who are battling to keep their jobs. You lost touch with them and so many suffered as a result of your inept policies.

ANSWER.PARA: We have inherited not only mass unemployment but also an $8 billion black hole in the budget forecast, a major shortfall that we have to address by cutting expenditure much further than we understood was necessary because you did not come clean with the Australian people. That is what we have to address. We also find there is $180 billion of foreign debt, something that you dismissed as being irrelevant. There is a current account deficit of around $27 billion. Again, you said it does not matter.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections on my left. All senators have a right to ask questions and to hear the answers.

—Whether it is the foreign debt, whether it is the current account deficit or whether it is interest rates in real terms, which are still about the highest in the industrialised world, you failed to understand how all of these macro‐economic factors in fact make it harder for people to get work and make it harder for the Australian living standard to rise. For many Australians who are out of work as a result of your failure and for many other Australians, the legacy of Labor was actually falling living standards, falling real wages.

BREAK.PARA: You talked a lot about the social wage but most Australians were interested in what was in the pocket or what was in the purse and under you it was worse. There is no doubt that the challenge before the new government is great. It is a major challenge because of your failure. We will meet that challenge. We will do a lot better and we will do it by standing true to the promises we made.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance. Does the minister agree with the view widely held in business and in the community, and recently neatly put by the Chief Government Information Officer to the Minister for Finance, Mr Fahey, that:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . information technology should not be singled out as an expense item but be considered as a means of improving the efficiency of service delivery.

Since information technology is an enabling technology, does the minister agree that slashing $985 million out of the IT budget will impair public sector efficiency and service delivery, to the disadvantage of Australian taxpayers? Is this not simply cutting off your nose to spite your face?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it incredible that the former minister has asked such a question so early in the life of the new government, but I welcome it. When you see what the former government did to efficiency in the Australian economy, when it deliberately set about avoiding taking the hard decisions to get our nation competitive again and when it broke every promise that it gave to the Australian people, you would think it extraordinary for this former minister to ask a question so far in advance of when he knows he will get a decision.

ANSWER.PARA: The budget will be delivered on 20 August. It will not be delivered before then. There is a very wide range of issues that need to be looked at in the course of the budget context. That task has been made much more difficult because of the absolute deceit of the former government in the run‐up to the election. It said that the budget was in surplus. It said that the forward estimates showed that we had surpluses in the years ahead.

Right through the election campaign, from the former Prime Minister down, that deceitful government refused to come clean with the Australian people, to open the books and to show the true state of the budget situation of which it knew perfectly well, given that the information was available to the incoming government two days later. You left Australia with an $8 billion black hole, a black hole created by your government and reinforced by the now Leader of the Opposition. That deceit was one of the basic reasons why the Australian people lost faith in you as a government and why you were thrown out so unceremoniously at the last election.

For all of those reasons, there is a large number of decisions that will be looked at. They will all be announced on budget night and not before. Any views that you might have at this stage are absolutely speculative. As my leader, Senator Hill, has said, we on this side of the chamber treat pre-election commitments very seriously. We have already made that clear through the Prime Minister. We will be keeping faith with our commitments to provide assistance to those in need in our community, to provide the approach to government and the environment for government and the private sector to operate in a way that will restore faith, confidence and hope in the Australian community.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the minister that his party promised to make these cuts before the election, so it is not speculative. Therefore, can the minister tell me: did the government examine the impact this decision would have before it made it or did it just simply think of a figure and slash that figure? Particularly, can he tell me what efficiencies that would have been made will now not proceed? What service delivery improvements that would have been made will now be junked? What impact on the Australian IT industry will this cut have? In short, did you or did you not consider those things? If you did, can you table any documents in which you set out those considerations of the impact of these cuts on government efficiency in service delivery as well as the Australian industry?

—I am not sure it is a supplementary question, but it is not a bad fishing trip. I add nothing to my previous answer. The decisions on this and a range of other issues will be announced in the course of the budget.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. I understand that the government is making a number of enhancements in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs portfolio to ensure greater accountability of taxpayers' money and to improve the delivery of services to indigenous Australians. Will you explain these enhancements to the chamber?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Tierney for his question. I have issued to the ATSIC board general directions to ensure greater accountability and improved outcomes.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You achieved nothing in your time. I have also proposed amendments to the ATSIC act, which will go before parliament.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You on that side have nothing to skite about. Hang your heads in shame! Under the general directions that I have issued to the board, a special auditor will review ATSIC grants, with power to refuse grants to organisations that fail to comply with accountability requirements. That did not occur under the previous government. Funding to organisations will continue to flow unless there is a breach. If funding is cut to an organisation in the event of a breach, ATSIC can organise for an alternative organisation to deliver services to clients. A special auditor will be appointed in the next few weeks.

ANSWER.PARA: The amendments to the ATSIC act which will go before parliament are to allow the minister to continue to appoint two commissioners to the ATSIC board and to appoint the chairman. This amendment was proposed because the government should be represented on the ATSIC board, given that approximately $1,000 million of taxpayers' funds are being expended annually. This amendment will also allow the chairman to be free of zone commitments and will allow him or her to take a truly national perspective.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you reading?
—You will lose your place.

—You did not read your question at all, did you? The proposed amendments will allow a reduction in the number of regional ATSIC councils from a maximum of 20 to a maximum of 12, which is in line with the 1995 ATSIC review which recommended a reduction in the size of regional councils to streamline ATSIC operations and to save $2 million. The proposed amendments will also give the minister the reserve power to appoint an administrator to ATSIC. This reserve power would be used only if all other accountability measures have not been adhered to.

ANSWER.PARA: After 13 years of Labor neglect, what have they got to show in the communities? I will tell you.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read it out.

—I do not have to read it out. You know it as well as I do. The indigenous population has been left a terrible legacy. You should be quiet, on that side. You should be quiet, all of you. There were 120 remote Aboriginal communities which did not have adequate water supplies. Do you remember Senator Richardson going around? He turned one tap on. That is what you did. There were 134 communities which lacked appropriate sewage disposal systems, and 250 communities had no electricity.

ANSWER.PARA: The infant mortality rate in the Aboriginal population is two to three times that of the non-Aboriginal population. Do I hear the shouts from that side about what they have achieved? Life expectancy for indigenous Australians is 16 to 19 years worse than that for the non-indigenous population. Only two out of every five Aboriginal males can expect to live to my age, whereas three out of four of the non-indigenous population can expect to live to my age.

Fifteen Aboriginal children were reported the other day as sick and living in Third World conditions on an old rubbish dump near Midland in Western Australia. That is your legacy. It would be highly irresponsible of me as minister representing indigenous people to sweep those facts under the carpet, to turn a blind eye to the problems, or to put them in the too‐hard basket, as your minister did because you thought there were votes in it. I am taking a stand on this. I will produce results. I am prepared to stand and show you those results in the period that we are in government. Hang your heads in shame. You have nothing to be proud of. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Is it not true that the growth forecast used by the Treasurer to justify the proposed $8 billion budget cut has already been made redundant by more recent Reserve Bank, ABS and business confidence figures which indicate stronger growth and a lower deficit? Is it not true that the government is just using this out‐of‐date forecast as a dishonest psychological big stick to cover up a massive attack on the public sector and more to come?
—A good question.

—I think that really is quite an offensive question. To suggest that we would have a deliberate policy to take a big stick to the public sector is quite offensive. Apart from that, it is untrue. It seems that the honourable senator is basically questioning Treasury's own figures.
—You are using them.
—Are you saying that we should not rely on Treasury figures? We have a responsibility to address the projected deficit, the forecast deficit—
—In an honest way.

—In an honest way and on the basis of the best information. The best information is surely the information the Treasury has provided to us—the information that you would not let the Australian people know about during the election. That is the legacy that we inherit. If we are inheriting a forecast deficit of $8 billion, we have got to address it. I suspect that the Democrats' approach would be to close the eyes and look the other way. The Labor Party's approach would be to increase taxation, because that is what it has always done in the past.
—Is that right?

—That is what you have always done in the past. We, being faced with that responsibility, believe that the best alternative is to reduce public expenditure. By reducing public expenditure, we are able to take pressure off interest rates, give small business a chance and give a chance for increased employment in sustainable jobs in the longer‐term future. So, faced with that legacy of Labor, we believe we are approaching it and attacking it in the only sensible policy way.

—So are the figures out of date? Minister, you say that your aim is to reduce public expenditure. Have you given any consideration to the April ANZ Business Outlook, which forecasts that a reduction in public expenditure of $5 billion would lower growth by a further one per cent and add greatly to unemployment? Don't your actions have the capacity to jeopardise stronger economic growth, on which you say you are relying as well?

—Our objective is to improve economic growth because only by improving economic growth can we provide the jobs that we are committed to provide. There is no doubt about that. One of the other misleading aspects of the Labor Party when it was in government was that it told us that it was achieving a growth rate that would eat into unemployment when it simply was not true. We are committed to and went to the Australian people on a policy program to improve the level of economic growth so that we could do something about employment. To do that successfully we need to reduce public expenditure. We need to reduce public expenditure—
—You run the risk of undermining your own strategy.

—You have got the old‐fashioned Australian Democrats solution. Here we are, three years into the recovery. You say the only way to tackle unemployment is to further pump prime. It won't work. The only way in this very competitive international economic environment is in fact to reduce public expenditure so that our businesses can be internationally competitive.(Time expired)

—My question is to Senator Vanstone. Can the minister confirm that the Department of Administrative Services approached the Attorney‐General's Department on 28 March this year seeking a legal opinion on the validity of the election of a South Australian senator?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I can't. I have no information on that matter. I will get some information for you and give it to you as soon as I can.

—I have a supplementary question. As you are seeking that information, Senator, can you also find out whether the Attorney‐General's Department did in fact give the Department of Administrative Services advice as to whether a senator‐designate was the holder of an office of profit under the crown? If so, can you find out for us what the nature of that advice was as well?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I have tried to make it pretty clear, but I will spell it out again. I am unaware of the matter that you have raised. It is a matter that the Attorney, no doubt, has some knowledge of. I will get whatever information he is prepared to give you and I will give it to you as soon as I can.

—My question is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Short. I refer the minister to the statement made during the election campaign by the then Minister for Finance and now Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, that `We are operating in surplus and our projections are for surpluses in the future'. Given that the new Treasurer, Mr Costello, announced only days after the election that there was an $8 billion budget black hole, what can the government say about its predecessor's awareness of the real situation and Mr Beazley's credibility?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Ferguson for his very important question. It was obvious throughout the election campaign that the Labor Party was deceiving the Australian people and nowhere was that more obvious than in respect of the budget situation.
