As Senator Ferguson pointed out in his question, on 1 February Mr Beazley, then Minister for Finance, said, `We are operating in surplus and our projections are for surpluses in the future.'

ANSWER.PARA: That assertion was never once rebutted by any of the former government ministers during the election campaign. Indeed, the contrary was the case from the Prime Minister down. Despite that unequivocal assurance, two days after the election the new Treasurer was handed figures showing that the budget would be in deficit for the entire period of the forward estimates. For 1995‐96, instead of a surplus of $720 million, we inherited a deficit of $280 million—a deterioration of $1 billion. For 1996‐97 the picture was even worse, with what Labor had said would be a surplus of $3.4 billion in fact being revealed two days after the election to be a deficit of $4.9 billion. That is a turnaround of $8.3 billion in the budget bottom line.

PARA.BREAK: The deceit practised by Labor and Mr Beazley during the campaign was twofold, of course. The first was that they pretended that the figures were not available. Secondly, they pretended that the budget was in surplus. Mr Beazley deceived the Australian public during the election campaign and now he is trying to continue that deception by denying the legiti macy of the Treasury figures. On 17 April—a couple of weeks ago—Mr Beazley said:

ANSWER.PARA: We don't accept the figures that have been put forward. This notion of an $8 billion hole is largely a fraud.
Yet during the election campaign, Mr Beazley said:
As far as we are concerned, the Treasury estimates that we had in connection with the last budget—and they were Treasury estimates—stand for good and we stand by them.

Now that Labor is out of office, the Treasury figures apparently are not good enough for him. The only fraud being perpetrated is by Mr Beazley himself and his Labor colleagues.In stark contrast, the coalition government will ensure that the Australian people will be fully informed on the Commonwealth's budget position at the beginning of each election campaign period, as we outlined in our proposed charter of budget honesty. Mr Beazley in the last couple of weeks has rejected this valuable reform initiative, which is further evidence of his lack of commitment to open government.

So let there be no doubt about it. Despite Labor's efforts to conceal the fact, there is an $8 million black hole. Equally, there can be no doubt that the responsibilities for this huge deterioration unquestionably rest with the Leader of the Opposition and the previous Labor government. Labor deceived the Australian public during the election. It is inexcusable for them now to try to continue that deception.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Given that the question of flags played such a central role yesterday in an otherwise barren speech from the Governor-General, and given the categorical statements made last year by the now Prime Minister and the Deputy Prime Minister that the official recognition of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander flags `would demean the status of the national flag and divide rather than unite the nation', I ask: will your government move to formally rescind the Keating government's official recognition of these flags under section 5 of the Flags Act, as proclaimed on July 14 last year, or will your government, and your Prime Minister particularly, now accept their proclamation as a major act of reconciliation with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a very good question, Senator Collins. I am surprised that you were able to find one in relation to Aboriginal affairs because there are not many, as I said previously. There is one flag, as you know—an Australian flag.
—What we want is a very good answer.
—You are getting it. There is one flag, and it is an Australian flag. The question of whether that will be rescinded or not has not been determined. When it has been, I will be the first to tell you.
—What is your position?
—What is your policy?

—That is what I was about to come to, colleagues. I appreciate the advice of Senator Herron that that matter will, in fact, be considered by his government and a decision may well be taken on it at some future time. Given that understanding, will you, as Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, give the Senate an undertaking that you will resist any attempts by your cabinet colleagues to, in fact, rescind that proclamation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Collins, we won the election. Are you aware that we won the election? Having said that, I will seek the advice of my government and listen to it assiduously, and I will let you know when that decision has been made.

—I ask the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs: how much money does ATSIC spend each year to maintain an office in Geneva so that it can liaise with the United Nations? Does the minister agree that it is a contradiction in terms that a government-funded statutory body should be given non-government organisation status at the UN?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Chamarette for the question. There is no money expended, in fact, by ATSIC in relation to that. It does not maintain an office in Geneva. However, it liaises with the United Nations through the Centre for Human Rights in Geneva and the national office of the United Nations Information Centre in Sydney. ATSIC liaises with these offices in relation to obtaining information about international and United Nations forums and meetings which concern indigenous issues. In fact, ATSIC has it in its charter that it can do that. As a result of that, it can forward information about issues of concern in relation to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples.

ANSWER.PARA: ATSIC sought and was granted a status as a non-government organisation, in a consultative way, with the Economic and Social Council of the United Nations as an independent representative body. So it has the authority to do that. The minister, in fact, was not required to authorise ATSIC's application for the status and did not do so. The matter of ATSIC's continuing NGO status with this body is a matter between ATSIC and the United Nations. In fact, there was no money expended as such. I would be happy to give you a fuller answer in relation to it but—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you?
—Are you going to give me an extension of time? I will give you a fuller answer then. Seeing you have requested it, you can hear the full answer.
—Don't read it, though.
—I would not read it. I would not think of reading it. I will even put my glasses on so that I cannot read it.

ANSWER.PARA: In western and eastern Europe, and in both the northern and southern hemispheres, the board of ATSIC is a representative institution elected by 35 regional councils—of course, you all know this—throughout Australia. The regional councils are themselves elected by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities.

ATSIC believes statutory independence is evidenced by its self-regulation and its role as the initiator and setter of its own goals and policies in consultation with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities and their elected representatives. ATSIC has consistently represented views independent of government positions at both international and national forums concerning indigenous issues. It also has a substantial independent voice and input into government policies affecting not only Aboriginal people but other members of the Australian community.

ATSIC undertakes international activities under the provisions of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989 as amended in section 7(1) `Functions of Commission' and section 10 `Powers of Commission', paragraphs 1 and 5. The `Powers of Commission' stated:
The Commission has power to do all things that are necessary or convenient to be done for or in connection with the performance of its function.
The powers of the Commission may be exercised within or outside Australia.
This consultative status is for United Nations purposes only, and the granting of that status has application only with the United Nations system.

Senator Schacht, I have filled in the time. I could have given you a little extra time to ask questions of the government, and you did not take advantage of it. I was trying to give you a short answer so that you would have more time to ask questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for his extended answer. I ask again: is it not also a contradiction in terms for the minister to be supporting the position that ATSIC is a non-government organisation on the basis of its independent status and 35 elected representatives and, at the same time, to be proposing to continue the paternalistic practice of appointing the chair of ATSIC and one of the commissioners? I ask the minister to consider that as a deliberate flouting of the principles that he has been espousing lately in terms of continuing that practice of appointing members of ATSIC as well as saying that it is a totally independent body.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The supplementary question has no connection with the first question, but I will be generous this afternoon because I thought it would come up at one stage or another. Senator Chamarette, I actually answered your question in my previous answer to a question from Senator Tierney, so I will say the same thing again if it is of benefit.
—You might not have to read it this time.

—I did not read it last time. Senator Chamarette, the feeling is that it is not paternalistic. I have asked the ATSIC commissioners to set out the criteria for selection of their next chairman. Those criteria will be determined by the commissioners themselves. Also, it may well be that one of the present commissioners should be appointed. Having said that, I think it is important that there be a direct connection between the government and a body that is spending over $1,000 million of taxpayers' funds.
—That's you. You are the direct connection.
—Yes, but not if it is a totally autonomous body and you will recall it has been and still is so up to the present. The present chairman was appointed by the now opposition and she is still in place.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. On 18 January 1996 the coalition released its broadcasting policy entitled `Better broadcasting'. I ask the minister to reconfirm the election promise to the Australian people contained in that policy document, which reads:

QUESTION.PARA: The coalition will maintain existing levels of Commonwealth funding to the ABC. We will continue to support triennial funding which has allowed the ABC to plan for the future with a greater degree of financial certainty.

TALK.START.PARA: —We gave some very careful commitments in our policy document, and we did it against the background of an understanding of the ABC and how it ought to operate. We made it clear that there is a number of ways in which the ABC could actually lift its game. I think it now accepts that there is significant scope for improvement in the operation of its affairs.
—You did this on the ABC committee, too, didn't you?

—Well, I don't think you contributed much. The fact is we gave those commitments against that background. What you are now asking me to do is, in effect, to take the issue well ahead of budget night, and we are not in the business of saying anything about the budget. I am simply saying that you are the ones who ought to examine your consciences.
—How does that sit with Robert Hill's answer today?

—If the thrust of that question is that you are going to say that there are some areas where you cannot save money or that somehow there is not a need to save money, I have made it clear to you that the ABC will continue to function in the way that it was designed to function, despite the fact that its charter is very nebulous, despite the fact that it has been running budget deficits. I would not say it has been doing that on the basis of advice it got from you, but the fact is that the ABC itself is in need of a significant shake up. It knows that, and those discussions are taking place.
—Will you maintain the funding?
—I have told you that we have given a commitment. We take those commitments seriously. I do not have anything further to add.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. In this first question to the minister as a member of the first Howard government—
—It is the second. He just had one.

—From our side. The first serious question, the first significant question. I congratulate the minister on his well‐merited appointment and ask: would he outline the benefits that will accrue to the people of Australia from the proposed one-third sale of Telstra and what exactly are the benefits to the environment that will emerge from the establishment of a $1 billion national heritage trust?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Baume for a question that is long overdue and in need of a decent answer. Quite clearly, there are some people out there who have not been listening. The fact is that most other countries in the developed world went down this track a decade ago. They have not all done it because they have had budget problems of the magnitude that you lot inflicted on the Australian community. They have done it because they understand there is a very real benefit to consumers in having a more efficient telecommunications company.

ANSWER.PARA: What you have in Australia at the moment is a company that is facing enormous challenges. If you look at the measures of its performance and productivity, you will find that it is sadly wanting. I know that is because the trade union movement and you effectively provided a veto over a number of the actions that were needed to be taken, but we have now reached a point of crisis. Telstra does need to become a lot more efficient, and it will become efficient if it is privatised because you will start to get price signals. You will start to have people focusing on the bottom line and wanting to ask the hard questions to ensure that that flows.

There are very significant consumer benefits that will flow from our package. As a result of the sale of one-third of Telstra, we will then be in a position to deliver a number of consumer benefits, not just the safeguards that will remain in legislation in terms of universal service obligations, price caps and the extension of the untimed local call option to businesses. You well know that all those consumer safeguards are there, so you do not have any concerns on that front.

What you ought to be concerned about is a much more efficient telecommunications industry. If you have the highest local call charges in the world, if you are about 30 per cent off the pace in terms of OECD measurements of performance, you desperately want a company that can perform and deliver benefits to consumers. That is why the scrutiny of the marketplace will make a very real difference. It will also provide an opportunity for Australian citizens to invest directly in the company and, to the extent it performs better than it should, they will reap that direct benefit and they will get preferential access to those shares.

The usual furphy about foreign ownership has been put to rest. There will be an absolute limit of less than 12 per cent of the company in foreign hands and less than two per cent in the hands of any one strategic investor. We are absolutely confident that the Australian community will respond in the way they have to privatisations of telcos around the world. That will mean that everyone is a winner from an outfit that has so much to deliver but has been shackled by your government over the years. Telstra employees will get a two per cent benefit and that is a major improvement on their current position. They will have a stake in the company. They will have an incentive to produce higher productivity returns.

I was also asked about the environmental package, which of course is an historic first. It is the best package that could be put in place for more than 50 years and it involves money being invested in the National Heritage Trust, which will enable $318 million to be applied to a national vegetation initiative to tackle land and water degradation problems, $163 million to implement the Murray‐Darling 2001 project and $32 million for a national land and water resources audit to provide the first ever national appraisal of the extent of land and water degradation. There will also be $80 million for the implementation of a comprehensive national reserve system to preserve Australia's biodiversity, and $100 million for a coast and clean seas initiative to tackle major environmental problems.

So we have the combination of those very positive benefits and the fact that we have a chronic savings problem in the country, a problem which is identified by people such as Vince FitzGerald on a regular basis. Even your good friend Bernie Fraser knows the problem. We will apply $7 billion to reducing government debt. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for that answer. What will be the damage to Australia in terms of both communications and the Australian environment if these benefits that are clearly wanted and requested by the Australian people are to be blocked by senators representing a clear minority of the Australian populace?

—There are benefits to two very diverse groups of people, but each should have an acute interest in Australia's welfare. Those who endorsed this environmental package prior to the election know that it very much deserves and needs to be implemented, and those who have quibbled about this proposal are simply ignoring the very real benefits that accompany such a privatisation, in terms of benefits to telecommunications consumers. I would have thought that you would be very interested in seeing local call charges come down significantly and in seeing the sort of benefits that can flow from being a world‐class telecommunications environment. Telecommunications costs, as we all know, are the second highest cost input after wages and salaries. They are a very significant factor in terms of export, productivity and performance and, unless you get those cost down, unless you have a telecommunications company that is up to world practice—and not 30 per cent off world practice, as it is now—then of course those—
—Don't give us that.
—That is the fact. Lines per employee in this country are about 140, compared with over 300 in many countries in Europe. (Time expired)

—My question is to Senator Hill, Leader of the Government in the Senate and Minister representing the Prime Minister. Will the minister give a guarantee that the Office of the Commonwealth Ombudsman will continue to have sufficient resources to pursue its responsibilities, particularly in light of Philippa Smith's statements where she has said, `I can't see how we can sustain the function'?
—Yes, we will give that guarantee.

—I ask a supplementary question. Is this response credible, when the government is proposing to reduce the funding of the ombudsman by $2.7 million, being approximately 30 per cent of the office's present budget over three years, while at the same time complaints have increased by 23 per cent in only one year?
—Even the Labor Party is having to do better with less at the moment. It is a fact of life that there are significant reductions in public expenditure and it has to be seen across the board.

—My question is to Senator Hill, Minister for the Environment. I refer the minister to the coalition election policy document called `Paying for our Commitments', and in particular to the table entitled `Environment Total Program Costs', which says that your environment policy will cost just $84 million in 1996‐97. Does the minister agree that $84 million spent on the environment next year is no $1 billion commitment, as you have been suggesting? Given that the policy says that this $84 million in 1996‐97 will be funded from the budget and not from any proceeds from any sale of anything, can the minister guarantee that this year's programs will continue to be funded in the August budget and that the government will not try to find even more thinly veiled excuses for spending very little on the environment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I am pleased that the Democrats have given away the habit of dorothy dixers to government ministers, too. It is interesting that, now we are here, they have changed the practice. The honourable senator has hit the nail on the head. We want to implement a $l billion environment trust, but we have to raise the funds to do so. The Labor Party would have liked to have been able to do so as well, as Senator Faulkner said this morning. Basically, Labor endorses our program; they would have liked to have done it.
—It is our program.

—You lost, matey; you lost. It has gone. But Labor was not able to fund it. We have found the way to fund it: sell one‐third of Telstra and put $1 billion of the proceeds towards setting up an environment fund which is very badly needed in the national interest. If the Australian Democrats will come to the party and recognise the great opportunity that they now have to be part of the biggest and best environment package in Australia's history, now is the time to be part of that process. Support the sale of Telstra, provide the funding base and let us implement that policy. We have said that in the meantime we will not have the same capacity to build on the existing programs. We said that in the document. You must have read the document, Senator, and I am pleased to see that.
—What about existing programs?

—I will get back to existing programs. If we are to build on the existing programs, we need to set up a funding base. The only way we can do that is through the sale of one‐third of Telstra. Now is the time to come on board and represent the constituency that you claim to represent in this place, instead of moving to block and obstruct the sale.

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to existing programs of the former government, as you well know and as has been publicly said, in the light of the $8 billion hole we have inherited from Mr Beazley, all current programs are being reviewed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find that a very interesting answer—the only way you will fund the environment is to sell off a valuable public asset. Surely you agree, though, that talking about this $1 billion is really misleading. What you are talking about is approximately $135 million per year for five years or—let us put it in perspective—less than one‐sixth of one per cent of your total budget outlays, less than one‐third of the costs of giving tax breaks that will help only the private health insurance industry and less than you proposed in new spending on defence. Let us look at your priorities. Do you think that the environment really is such a low priority that what little extra money you might spend is indeed tied to something—a valuable public asset, as I said—and that really what you are looking for is an excuse to spend absolutely nothing on the environment?

—The thing about the Australian Democrats is that they never have and never will have to raise the money to pay for public expenditure. Furthermore, if you were, with respect, a little more perceptive, you would see a big advantage in this trust fund because it would be outside the scope of cuts in the future. It would be a separately constituted trust. The advocates for the environment should see a special opportunity in what we are seeking to do, a one‐off chance to set up a fund. I do not know where you think we are going to find a billion dollars. It is amazing. This is an opportunity that should not be lost and you should just start talking to your constituency and ask them what they think. What they will say to you is, `We expect you to get on board.' Take the opportunity—it is too good to miss—and be part of this opportunity to really do something for the Australian environment.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney‐General and Minister for Justice, Senator Amanda Vanstone. I take this opportunity, Senator Vanstone, to congratulate you on your appointment to the cabinet. I ask the minister: has the Government obtained any advice, written or otherwise, of the likely effect on the efficiency with which the Australian Securities Commission operates of the proposed cuts in its personnel?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Cooney for his question and for his gentlemanly behaviour in congratulating me—not exhibited, I notice, by Senator Bolkus earlier. Senator Bolkus is probably not feeling very gentlemanly, because he has been shoved down the line a bit. He was here somewhere and now he is over there. He has had to have added to that insult being a part of the party the people rejected. You are the party the people did reject—comprehensively. You have to have added to that not only shifting from here to there but shifting from somewhere up here to behind Senator Faulkner and Senator Carr.
—What is the answer to the question?
—Just hold on, sport, I am coming to it. Keep yourself a bit calm. There was Senator Sherry and then Senator Collins. There must be an awful squabble between Senator Cook and Senator Bolkus.
—Senator Vanstone, please get to the answer.

—I did want to highlight, Mr President, how gracious Senator Cooney was, and I could do so only by pointing out how ungracious Senator Bolkus was. Senator Cooney, I am sorry to upset you but I do not have any information with respect to your question. Perhaps there is a plan on the other side to ask me questions that only the Attorney can give you an immediate answer to. I will tell you what I will do. I will do the same for you as I said I would do for Senator Bolkus. That is, I will speak to the Attorney and I will get an answer.

—Thank you for that answer, Senator Vanstone. When you are seeking the information from the Attorney, could you ask him whether he would be prepared to make any advice he had in this respect, or any record of this advice, available to the Senate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cooney, just as I said to Senator Bolkus, I will get what I can. I am obviously obliged to do whatever I can for any senator that asks a question, but I cannot resist saying that with respect to you, Senator Cooney, there is a temptation to work a little bit harder and get it a little bit quicker.

—My question is to Senator Parer, representing the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs. I refer the minister to the coalition commitment that there would be a small business summit within 100 days of the coalition getting into government. Can the minister tell the parliament what steps are being taken to implement this promise and how small business will be involved in that commitment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank Senator Boswell very much for that question. I think it is most appropriate that, in the first session of the new Howard government, a question should be asked on small business, which is the backbone of industry in Australia and the one that can really address the unemployment problems in this country caused by you people on the other side. The national small business summit will be held on Wednesday, 12 June 1996 in Sydney, within the 100 days promised. It will be a working meeting of ministers responsible for small business from the states and territories and representatives of local government, chaired by the Commonwealth minister for small business, Mr Prosser. Small business will be represented and play an important role in the summit. It will make presentation to ministers in the opening session on key issues of concern within the sector. The small business representative associations and interested small business owners will be invited to observe the opening session.

ANSWER.PARA: Minister Prosser has already held discussions with small business groups and consultations are progressing in the lead‐up to the summit. We are consulting. You lot lost touch. In preparing the agenda for this meeting, small businesses and their representative organisations were invited to identify issues which will be addressed at the summit. The key objective of the summit is to discuss the paperwork and compliance burden faced by small business and the ways this can be reduced. The summit will focus on issues which are cross‐jurisdictional in nature or where there is a need for national consistency in the approach to regulation reform. Early reaction from the states, territories and local government has been very encouraging and the government believes that it will get results from this summit. In addition, many of the issues and recommendations which are identified at the summit will be referred to the small business deregulation task force for consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has that been appointed yet?

—As the coalition claimed on many occasions over the past years, the Labor Party has no interest or understanding of small business, as you would know, Senator Schacht, as it was your portfolio. It never was and never will be part of the IR club and has consistently been attacked by predatory unions and, thus, the Labor Party's `no ticket, no start' policy.

ANSWER.PARA: Industrial relations reform, including the repeal of the unfair dismissal provisions and replacement with a system which is fair to employers and employees and the abolition of compulsory unionism, as outlined in the Governor-General's address to the parliament, will be a boost not only to the small business sector but to real job creation throughout Australia. Revitalisation of the small business sector was a major plank of the coalition's platform at the recent election. We will honour that commitment to the letter.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. The Sydney Morning Herald of 29 April reports that the government acknowledged that Worksafe Australia be required to slash its budget by one-third, resulting in a loss of up to half its staff. With 10 Australian workers being killed in workplace accidents each week, who will now carry out the important health and safety research functions of this agency? What other measures will this government implement to ensure that the lives of Australian workers are not placed at risk?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —Worksafe Australia was identified by the Industry Commission as significantly deficient in meeting its own objectives. Indeed, it was particularly critical of the fact that it was spending significant amounts of money on self-promotion and that it was not addressing its core activities. We are therefore committed to ensuring that that does happen. In meeting our commitments, we identified something like $5.9 million that could be saved from restructuring Worksafe Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: What we have in mind is simply the basis of expert advice from an independent assessor, one that will not jeopardise safety but will deliver benefits on a more efficient basis. It is just a pity that you have not acknowledged what has been going on in places such as Worksafe Australia. It is simply a bloated work force preoccupied with doing everything other than what it was charged with the responsibility for doing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question, Mr President. The Sydney Morning Herald of 29 April highlighted the prospect that lives were now at risk as a result of this government's action. I repeat: what actions will you take to ensure that important health and safety research functions and other functions of this body are actually carried out and that the 10 workers who are killed each week in this country could be reduced?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industry Commission is in a better position to make those sorts of judgments than the Sydney Morning Herald . If that is the best evidence you can cite in favour of the proposition that somehow real safety and lives are at risk, you will have to do a lot better. Quite clearly, we do not want to jeopardise people's lives. We do not want to emasculate any body that has a very important safety function to perform.

ANSWER.PARA: What we are doing is restructuring Worksafe in such a way that it will deliver the goods that it is supposed to deliver but at a lower cost. That is something that never appealed to you. You lot were always interested in making sure that all of these people had maximum work forces, irrespective of performance. You were not interested in productivity or efficiency benefits. The Industry Commission made it very plain that that could be achieved in this instance. I recommend that, instead of just reading the newspapers, you really do some hard work and go back and read some of those serious reports such as the Industry Commission assessment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill), to a question without notice asked by Senator Faulk ner, today relating to promises made in the recent federal election campaign.

The first question asked today was from Senator Faulkner to Senator Hill and related to a matter of honesty in government. It was a very fundamental question. It was a question fundamental to what the opposition's—sorry, the government's—point of view is on the economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are the government.

—I still make that mistake, but I am overcoming it. I note the shaky start that Senator Hill got off to as Leader of the Government in the Senate today, but I do not put it down to inexperience; I put it down to the shaky ground on which he has been standing. The question by Senator Faulkner and the question by Senator Kernot later about the government's projection of the so-called $8 billion black hole is the shakiest proposition anyone can imagine. It is tantamount to the Goebbels technique of the big lie.

SPEECH.PARA: The so-called black hole is a projection. As has been said by many pundits and by the government of the day at the time, any economic variable which will be routinely reported between now and when the budget is brought down will alter those projections fundamentally. We have already seen some of the economic variables come through, which have been a product of the fine economic management of the previous government. The most recent figure that caught the public attention was the low inflation rate that Australia had—a figure entirely due to the policies set in place by a Labor government. We know that things such as growth, inflation, employment and all of those other aspects that go to form what are the budget parameters will change dramatically between now and when the budget comes down.

We also know that at this stage of the budget cycle Treasury is notoriously conservative when it puts forward projections. No economic writer in Australia is convinced at all that what the government is saying is true about that alleged so-called deficit. What we have is the shakiest of figures on the flimsiest of grounds on the remotest of evidence being used as justification for a slash/burn economic policy across the board. We have ministers of the government going on the public record saying to lobby groups and interest groups that what they are proposing to do they admit is not good policy. In fact, Mr Moore said that with respect to industry policy recently. He said, `What we are proposing to do will not be good policy but we nonetheless need to make these cuts.' He then trotted out this hoary old chestnut of the so-called black hole.

The first thing that needs to be said about this is that that is not true. It is supposition and speculation which everyone knows will change. The second thing that ought to be said is that it is indeed a derogation of the government's position in the election campaign. Towards the end of the election campaign honourable senators in this place will remember at a press conference that the now Prime Minister, then Leader of the Opposition, John Howard, was asked an extraordinarily pertinent question by one of the journalists. He was asked whether he would still deliver on his election promises if the deficit that he believed at that point did exist in the budget or whether he would weasel out of those election promises.

Mr Howard was forthright in his answer, and we ought to remember what that answer was because this opposition will be making it public at every possible opportunity. When asked whether, if the deficit were real, he would weasel out he said no, he would deliver on his policies and on his promises—yes, yes, yes, he would deliver. Now we see a major campaign of background briefing, of leaks, of innuendo and of on the record comments by government ministers that many of the undertakings and programs that were declared sacrosanct by the then opposition during the election campaign will now be cut.

We have had allegations and stories of cuts in the ABC. We have had stories of cuts in industry policy. We have had massive cuts to the number of staff in the public sector. We have had Senator Newman saying that every welfare program is on the table for cuts. We know that education funding is under review and is likely to be cut. We know that in the health area the razor is out and being stropped to find cuts there when the coalition was clearly on the record, particularly in their campaign advertising, as saying that the welfare vote would be kept intact.

We have, with the most extraordinary and unbelievably grotesque manipulation of language that I have ever heard of, cuts in the employment area. While the then opposition, the present government, claimed that unemployment was a key priority, we now have projections of cuts to the employment programs which would have helped Australians to take worthwhile jobs in the workplace.

All of those cuts are being projected by this government so quickly after assuming power and so hard on the heels of a promise by their leader that this would not be the case. So the question asked by Senator Faulkner, a question of a character similar to that asked by Senator Kernot—

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. It is a question of etiquette more than anything else. The former minister might not appreciate that we gave leave for this debate because of an arrangement at the whips' meeting this morning that time for taking note would be allowed notwithstanding the fact that the opposition has not permitted us to have sessional orders for this session. It was certainly implied if not made explicit that this arrangement would be in the terms of the previous order. Therefore, Senator Cook would get five minutes.

—There certainly was a discussion at the whips' meeting. I indicated at the time that we would be pursuing the question of taking note and seeking leave. I also indicated that we would not be looking to extending it beyond the customary arrangement but there was no strict agreement about times. Senator Cook would probably be operating under the existing standing orders, which allow him half an hour. I indicated that we would try to run along a pattern similar to the past practice. I am sure that Senator Cook will enter into the spirit of that arrangement.
—As this chamber knows, I am a reasonable person and I am prepared to abide by that arrangement. There is no clock to guide me so I am not sure how much time I have taken.

—You have 24 minutes and 19 seconds left of the half hour. You are entitled to half an hour but I am sure you heard the comments made about the discussion at the whips' meeting and what the understanding was.

—Yes, and, as I said, as a reasonable person I will abide by the informal arrangement. The nub of my remarks is honesty in government. Mr Howard made that his long suit before the election. He promised a new honesty. He then said to a journalist during the election campaign that his party would not renege on their election promises if the budget did not show the figures that the government of the day said it showed.

BREAK.PARA: Now we have this idea of a black hole, which no one believes in, being used as an excuse to slash and burn programs and services across the board. It brings into question all of the promises that Mr Howard made. That is the fundamental issue here.
No answer was given at question time today that would assure any Australian that Mr Howard will abide by his election promises. He has made his bed; he will have to lie in it.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Senator MICHAEL BAUME

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

QUESTION.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston), to a question without notice asked by Senator Michael Baume today, relating to the proposed partial privatisation of Telstra.

The answer given by the minister was very heartening in the sense that he stressed that the government's policy was to do what it could, dependent on the support of this chamber, to improve the efficiency of Telstra by privatising it to the extent of one‐third, bringing to it a sense of commercial reality which, under the previous government, appeared to be fast disappearing. We have seen in Austel reports in recent times a continuing failure by Telstra to meet the obligations and requirements of service that Austel has set. There have been disappointing response times to complaints and matters of that nature.

BREAK.PARA: A memo from Mr Blount last November contained the horrific forecast that unless there were significant efficiencies—significant cuts in employment, for example—there would be a $1 billion blow‐out in Telstra's negative cash flow. We did not realise at the time that the cash flow was already projected to be half a billion dollars in deficit compared with the very significant positive cash flow the year before.

We have seen employment in Telstra blow out to something like 96,000 as against 60,000, a level competitive with comparable overseas organisations and a level which, I understand, is some kind of target. That indicates present over‐employment of something like 30,000 people.

Under the previous government there was a massive mishandling of Telstra. We have seen in Senate committee hearings an arrogance by senior Telstra officials in refusing to deal properly with senators' questions. Quite frankly, the previous government was only too happy to see that take place. There was no serious attempt by the previous government to make Telstra accountable either to itself or, in particular—this is why it affects this Senate—to the Senate committees inquiring into the expenditure of Australian taxpayers' money. Those opposite may well say, `Ah, but Telstra does not spend taxpayers' money'. It simply happens to have massive guarantees; it has massive contingent liabilities, which it was very reluctant to come clean about before the Senate committees.

Telstra was mishandled and mismanaged by the previous government, so there is a clear, evident need for greater efficiency. Most senators on most sides of this chamber would be well aware of the fact that in many instances people with quite proper complaints against Telstra have had a disgraceful response from Telstra. There has been a level of legal deviousness which is simply unacceptable. Apparently this has been motivated not by decency or fairness but by totally non-commercial attempts to protect backsides. People have made mistakes and no-one wants to admit it. In a typical bureaucratic way, the motive is to protect the backside rather than
face up to the commercial reality that they have done damage to Australians.

I am overjoyed to hear that the minister, Senator Alston, is keen to ensure that Telstra becomes much more aware of commercial reality, that it becomes much more motivated by commercial decisions and that it becomes determined to provide a better service to Australians at cheaper rates. Privatisation of one-third of Telstra is an effective way of seeking to ensure that it do so. That is what that element of the government's policy is all about. I commend the minister for his continuing determination to proceed in that way.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to speak on Senator Baume's motion but, after hearing his five‐minute contribution and his description of Telstra, I feel that, for the public record, certain matters ought to be addressed. He has described the performance of a company that bears no relationship to the performance of Telstra in recent years in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: It is odd that Senator Baume would attempt to ruin and downplay the reputation of the company which his government is trying to sell one‐third of, a company for which it is hoping to get the best possible price. If anyone in the marketplace thinking of buying Telstra listened to the remarks of Senator Baume, they would most certainly discount the price of $8 billion. In a very irresponsible way, he described this company as basically being hopeless, debt ridden, et cetera. That is not the record of this company. This company, which is owned by the taxpayers of Australia, last year employed full‐time approximately 75,000 people.

The new government is complaining about the lack of job opportunities in Australia and says it is going to do something about that. It appears from Senator Baume's remarks that, without rhyme or reason, the government wants to dismiss a lot of workers from Telstra. They would then go on to the unemployment list. There is an inconsistency there.

Let us look at the financial performance of Telstra. In 1994-95 it had a revenue of $14 billion. The half‐yearly report for this year indicates a revenue of $7.6 billion. If that amount is duplicated in the second half of the year, the total revenue for 1995-96 will be over $15 billion.

Let us look at Telstra's profit before tax. What an extraordinary figure this is—and Senator Baume complains that the company is not performing. In 1994‐95 there was a before tax profit of $2.4 billion. The half yearly figure for the present financial year is $1.8 billion. That shows an increase on last year's profit before tax. Last financial year there was a $1,700 million profit after tax. For the six months of this financial year, there is an after tax profit of $1,200 million. Again, that is a significant increase. Last year there was a dividend to the taxpayers of Australia of $944 million. For the first half of this year, that figure is $686 million. Again, if that figure is duplicated for the rest of the year, there will be an increase in the amount of dividend to the Australian people.

What about creating investment in Australia? Last financial year this company spent $3.2 billion. Anyone who knows anything about Telstra will know that, overwhelmingly, that was spent in buying services and products from the small business sector, helping the small business sector grow. Senator Baume has bagged Telstra for not performing. If Telstra did not exist, small business would not get that sort of assistance.

Telstra paid income tax of $649 million, separate from its dividend in 1994-95, to the Australian Taxation Office, which goes into revenue for the Australian people. Telstra's total payments to the government in 1994-95 came to $2.7 billion. This government wants to sell one‐third of Telstra for $8 billion, yet in one year the Australian government got $2.7 million in revenue. If part of Telstra were privatised, the government would still get income tax. But overall Telstra is performing very well; it is returning substantial dividends.

I will finish my remarks on a point that Senator Baume only alluded to. Once you sell a third of Telstra, it will not be long before you sell the lot. That is quite clear. At press conferences during the election campaign, the current Prime Minister (Mr Howard) could not rule out the fact that, in the end, the whole of Telstra would be sold.

BREAK.PARA: So the $2.7 billion total payments to the state after tax is taken out, or about $2 billion back to the federal government, would disappear. In four years we would be earning more than you would get for a third of the sale. I do not know what you would try to get for the full sale, but it would probably be the biggest float this country has ever seen. Whether you would ever raise $16 billion to $20 billion out of Australia—unless you sold a majority overseas to raise that sort of money—it is hard to believe. Of course you would not be game to tell the Australian people that you put Telstra into foreign hands. The remarks of Senator Baume have been quite damaging to the performance of a company owned by the Australia people. This is one reason why we will not have a bar of the hypocrisy of the government in trying to destroy Telstra, which performs a great public service to the Australian people.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Panizza, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

QUESTION.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron), to a question without notice asked by Senator Tierney today, relating to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission.

I am glad that Senator Herron spelt out his agenda for returning accountability to ATSIC. For quite a while at least $2 billion worth of government funding per year has been going to ATSIC and ATSIC related bodies. For at least three years that I know of, there has been a total lack of accountability in ATSIC. I have expressed that concern in this chamber time and time again. For some reason—perhaps it was political correctness—the former government chose to ignore this lack of accountability time and time again.

When these matters were raised in the Senate, by the Australia media and by Aborigines who were missing out on $2 billion of Australian taxes which were supposedly going into causes such as health, housing and education, the former government completely ignored the situation. The former minister for Aboriginal affairs, who is now no longer a member of the House of Representatives, chose to ignore it as well.

Time and time again I raised this with him, but he took not one iota of notice. He would not look into that issue of accountability, and as a result the money was wasted around those communities and not necessarily within those communities. That is what happened. Mr Tickner refused to have anything to do with an inquiry. So things went on. Senator Herron has had to take immediate action to look into what has been happening. I congratulate him for that.

Madam Deputy President, you may remember that in August 1993, I moved for an inquiry into the accountability of ATSIC and ATSIC related bodies. I had not convinced the government of course, but I had convinced the Democrats and their leader, Senator Kernot, to support me on such a move. The issue was supposed to be debated on a Thursday. It was the same day that the book about women in parliament was released. With the amount of business that went on that day, we did not get to my motion. By the following Tuesday, the Democrats, who cannot hold the line for more than 24 hours, retracted their support. That was nearly three years ago. That inquiry would have saved a lot of time for Senator Herron now. No one will know what could have been done if that inquiry had been undertaken.

I think I know what could have been done. There would be far more accountability now than there was then. Of course, a lot of money would have been saved that should have been going to the right causes—health, housing and education. I believe that the former government should stand condemned for refusing to look at something that was obvious. I believe that the former minister, Mr Tickner, made a grave error. I will not condemn him now because he has got enough to worry about. He himself will know that he made a mistake.

The Democrats have a motto—I do not like to hear it in this chamber, but I will repeat it just once, Senator Evans. It is: keep the bastards honest. What did they do? They let me down at the last minute and the lack of accountability continued for a further 2½ years, almost three years. I congratulate Senator Herron for having the courage to immediately order an inquiry into accountability.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

QUESTION.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston), to a question without notice asked by Senator Schacht today, relating to funding for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.

Today in question time, I clearly asked Senator Alston a question based on the coalition's policy speech of 18 January entitled `Better broadcasting'. In unequivocal terms, the coalition, now the government, said that it would maintain existing levels of Commonwealth funding to the ABC.
The policy speech stated:
We will continue to support triennial funding which has allowed the ABC to plan for the future with a greater degree of financial certainty.

Today in question time Senator Alston used every null and verbal device to get around saying yes or no to that commitment. He suggested that there were inefficiencies in the ABC and that those inefficiencies would provide savings, et cetera, but he would not actually reconfirm the commitment to continuing the triennial funding and at the end waffled off on something about the budget being considered.

Quite clearly, the supporters in the broad Australian community of the ABC now have it on record that the funding for the ABC is under threat across the board. The suggestion that has been speculated in the press that a two per cent efficiency dividend will be applied this year to training and funding, which would save about $10 million, is now the minimum available. Senator Alston would not even commit himself to that figure being the maximum they would take out of the ABC. He went on to talk about general inefficiencies in the ABC and most of us can take that as a code of words to say, `This means we can slash and burn in areas of the ABC.'

BREAK.PARA: I draw the attention of the Senate to the public document of 18 January, Better broadcasting. All through the document the coalition committed itself to maintaining all the existing programs and services of the ABC whether it was television or radio, whether it was in the capital cities or regional Australia, whether it was the orchestras or other artistic ventures successfully conducted by the ABC. Now it is quite clear that all of that is at risk, not just from the two per cent efficiency cut—$10 million—but from other areas.

What I think would worry many Australians is that some people in this coalition government will not be able to resist the temptation to try to run a political test across the programming of the ABC; those programs that from time to time put views and enable people to put views that the coalition would disagree with would be under threat.

This move would very much equate with what happened after 1975 when the Fraser coalition government was elected and Sir Henry Bland was appointed chair of the ABC with the task of cutting, slashing and burning the funding of the ABC and turning it around to be less antagonistic in the perception of the then coalition. We saw the ABC go into several years of turmoil in programming, funding and very low morale. One of the most important communication institutions in Australia that provides a service right across Australia to areas that the commercial broadcasting services do not reach, cannot reach or do not wish to reach was affected very badly.

It appears—and I qualify that it appears—that Senator Alston may be starting down that same road because he would not back his own promise from the election campaign that the funding would be maintained. Back in 1975 Malcolm Fraser promised not to cut the funding to the ABC but when he got into government he did things quite differently. I call on the supporters of the ABC, those millions of Australians right across this country, to be aware that the institution on which they rely heavily for their information and for a diversity of views is now going to be under a funding threat from this government because Senator Alston today in this chamber would not reconfirm a very simple commitment he gave on 18 January.

On behalf of the opposition, I can assure the Australian people that we will fight this ABC funding issue through this chamber and in the community leading up to the next budget. If the coalition is stupid enough to cut the funds, we will fight afterwards in the Australian community to defend the ABC funding. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: New Format for Bills and Acts

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement on behalf of the Attorney‐General relating to the new format for bills and acts and to move to take note of the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The format currently in use for bills introduced into this parliament has evolved gradually since 1901. It is only in the last 10 years or so, however, that attention has been paid to the effect on readers of the format in which legislation is set out. This has happened in the context of a growing community expectation that legislation that affects people ought to be accessible to those people.

SPEECH.PARA: The accessibility of legislation has several aspects. First, of course, the text of the legislation needs to be comprehensible to its intended audience. As well, legislation needs to be physically accessible to its intended audience—that is, people need access to up‐to‐date versions of current legislation, whether in the form of reprints of acts or electronic databases containing consolidated legislation.

For those who still use printed copies of legislation, which includes members of this parliament, the page design and layout of legislation also affect its accessibility. Document design is now recognised as a matter which can have a significant impact on the comprehensibility of documents and on how effectively documents communicate information. With this in mind, the Office of Parliamentary Counsel has undertaken a project to improve the design and layout of bills, which will also impact on the design and layout of acts.
The result of this project is a new format, which has been adopted by the office for future bills. The main features of the new format are these:

There is a substantial increase in the amount of `white space' on each page. This makes the pages look less forbidding, and this in turn contributes to the reader's confidence in dealing with the text.

Running headers are used on the top outside corner of each page. The inclusion of section numbers in the running headers will make searching for particular provisions easier. The inclusion of chapter, part and division headings in the running headers will make it easier for readers to interpret individual provisions in context.
Section and subsection numbers are separated out from the text to make searching for particular provisions easier.
Vertical spacing, variable font sizes and different margins give visual clues to the hierarchical relationships between different elements of the text.

The text of bills will no longer be right‐justified. The use of a `ragged' right‐hand margin makes text easier to read because it means that the spacing between words is the same in each line rather than varied, to ensure a straight right‐hand margin.
All bills will contain a table of contents. Among other things, the table will show all acts amended or repealed by the bill.
The first page of a bill will now be a cover page including the long title. The table of contents will start on the inside cover page.

Several bills were introduced in the last parliament in experimental formats. Now that the new format is settled, it will be used for almost all bills introduced from now on. The new format will also be adopted for reprints of existing acts. There will be a longer transitional period for reprints because it will take some time to convert all existing electronic versions of acts into the new formats.

BREAK.PARA: I would like to thank a number of people who advised the Office of Parliamentary Counsel during the development of the new formats. These include:
the clerks of both houses of this parliament,
the tax law improvement project and the corporations law simplification unit, in particular the communications experts working with each of those groups,
the Australian Government Publishing Service, and
the Communication Research Institute of Australia.

Those of us who are familiar with the current forms of Commonwealth legislation will need some time to get used to the new formats. However, I am confident that these formats represent a genuine contribution to the accessibility of Commonwealth legislation. I move:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to welcome the statement from the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone). I am pleased to see that the government is picking up some of the ideas of the old government. We welcome this initiative announced by Senator Vanstone on behalf of the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams).
—We never discard the good, just the bad.

—In a couple of years time you will be wishing you maintained all our policies, not just some of them. We welcome this initiative. In fact, we were driving it. I would like to place on record recognition of the work that the former Attorney‐General, Michael Lavarch, and former Minister for Justice, Duncan Kerr, did in this area in an endeavour to ensure that it would be easier for people to use bills and acts and, as a consequence, ensure greater knowledge, understanding and accessibility to the law.

SPEECH.PARA: The history of these changes announced today are such that they were in an advanced state of preparation under the previous government. In fact, the genesis of them was from changes recommended to the previous government by the Office of Parliamentary Counsel, following very much the experience people had in respect of the corporations and tax laws simplification initiatives undertaken by Labor. That was an important experience for those involved in the process.

Learning from that experience, the previous government announced in the Access to justice statement that we would pursue the approach taken in the corporate law simplification area to a broader perspective. That was announced in the Justice Statement a couple of years ago. It is probably worth referring to a commitment made there. In that statement, the government said:
Clear and unambiguous legislation will make laws easier to understand and easier to access. Careful drafting of acts of parliament and delegated legislation is required to ensure easy access.
I will not read everything that was said in that, but the pertinent sentence reads
`An improved design and layout of Commonwealth bills and acts will be introduced.' That is what we have today. It is good to see it happening. Of course, we welcome this ministerial statement.

As I said to Senator Vanstone, in a little while I am sure that the current government will be wishing that it maintained all of our ideas, not most of them. Recognising the important aspect of this and the need for initiatives like this to make parliament laws and people's rights more accessible, we welcome this initiative.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present a letter received from the Australian Lebanese Support Committee of Lebanon.
—I present additional information received by the Community Affairs Legislation Committee in response to the 1995-96 additional estimates hearings.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Kemp)—by leave—agreed to:
That—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I note that in the documents presented today there is a Commonwealth Grants Commission report on the Christmas Island inquiry, which, unfortunately, I have not seen. I am now trying to get a copy of it, but I think time is going to beat me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, you could seek leave of the Senate to have it reinstated if you wished.
—I was going to comment that that is what I might have to do. What I really want to say on the document before us at the present time will be qualified by whatever that Grants Commission report says.

SPEECH.PARA: In speaking to the report on the Casino Surveillance Authority and casino controller for the territory of Christmas Island, I simply wanted to draw the attention of the Senate and the government to the revenue from the casino on Christmas Island. I have an interest in this matter—

TALK.START.PARA: —Financial?

—Unfortunately, no. I have an interest as a former member of the Joint Committee on the National Capital and External Territories, which dealt with Australia's territories. In that capacity, I have been to Christmas Island a couple of times and have actually seen the start-up of the casino, although it was not in full operation when the committee was there.

SPEECH.PARA: I do point out that the casino's gross profit for the year 1 July 1994 to 30 June 1995 was $153,744,767.70, which was rather a remarkable amount. Although I do not have the figures before me, I suspect that—although it is for that entire financial year—the casino had not started to operate until some time through that year. I also want to point out that the licence fee from that profit was $12,299,000‐odd and that the community benefit fee was $1,537,000‐odd. I want to draw the attention of the government to those fees, if it has not already been attracted to them. My understanding—and it will be confirmed when I have a glance at the Commonwealth Grants Commission report—is that most of that money goes to the Christmas Island community.

The Christmas Island community is one which has received an enormous contribution from the taxpayers of Australia over recent years—a contribution that some people living in less fortunate parts of Australia might query. They may think that the Christmas Island community is being treated much more favourably than many people in regional Australia.

I simply rose to draw those figures to the government's attention and to suggest that if those amounts are going to the Christmas Island community the matter should be looked at carefully. The Australian taxpayers' contribution to that community should also be carefully considered now that the amount of revenue from that casino has been determined, as is indicated by the annual report currently before us.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts References Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

I did not intend to say a great deal about this matter. This report is one which I believe will be forgotten quickly; however, matters were canvassed by this committee that ought not be forgotten quite so quickly.

The Senate will recall that this was a committee of inquiry undertaken by the Senate Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts References Committee into allegations made concerning the administration of Australian soccer. In the first instance you have to ask yourself, `What has that got to do with the Australian Senate?' Certainly, a point that occurred to me very early in the piece was that it did not seem to have a great deal to do with the operations of the Australian Senate.

Issues were raised by a number of people about the way in which soccer was administered in this country. This was done using the media and through the Stewart inquiry. Changes have been made to the administration of soccer, but not as a result of the proceedings of this committee. In fact, this inquiry, in the judgment of Labor Party senators who participated in it, can claim little credit for the changes that have taken place in soccer.

My concern with this matter related specifically to the question of civil liberties. It seems to me—it seemed to me when we were engaged in this exercise—that one of our prime functions as senators has to be to protect the civil liberties of Australians. Some 79 citizens were adversely named in the committee's proceedings and there were very few opportunities for those named persons to state their position and clear their names. This, in my judgment, was a very clear case of where sport and politics do not mix.

BREAK.PARA: A very large number of sensational claims were made by media outlets. Many unfounded allegations and malicious rumours were made against persons prominent in soccer. They became a subject of public vilification and in my judgment they had no effective means of redress. I think it is important for senators to not confuse public interest with partisan political comment. There seems to me an appropriate place for partisan political comment, especially in here, but it is not necessarily the basis on which we launch vendettas against individuals in the soccer community or participate in a partisan way in the feuds that are occurring within the soccer fraternity.

David Hill, the Australian Soccer Federation Chairman, made the position very clear. He indicated very early in the piece, in April 1995, that `mud sticks in these things'. He indicated that you have a whole series of people who have an axe to grind and have a version of events. He stated:
. . . I do not think that constitutes grounds for sacking a national coach.
He went on:
As well as making decisions in the best interests of soccer—
the committee would—
have to have . . . regard for the rights of individuals who . . . have been wronged in this . . .
He indicated that we have to also take decisions based on the best interests of soccer itself. He said:

. . . there are people who have appeared before this Committee who have . . . repeated some rumour they are familiar with. The people who have been branded have not been charged with any offence and have not had the opportunity to say anything.

As members of the committee, we indicated from April 1995 that we felt the committee should be wound up. Unfortunately, that advice was ignored. We saw an abuse of natural justice which, in my judgment, went very much to the heart of our responsibilities as senators to protect the rights of Australian citizens.

I know it will be said that this committee provided an opportunity for people wronged to clear the air and that was often said. I would put to the Senate that none of us can be so naive as to believe that witnesses do not incur expenses in retaining barristers and solicitors who have to advise them on the evidence that is being presented. Witnesses incurred considerable expense in giving evidence to the committee and had great stress placed upon them which was not attended to through this committee. Many grave charges were laid against them and not all people are able to respond adequately in a committee format. They are not lawyers and are not able to have lawyers speak for them. The committee system is not a court of law. This is a simple proposition which so many senators opposite failed to understand through this process.

In terms of specific findings there was no evidence found that Anthony Labbozzetta had done any wrong regarding the Okon transfer matter. There was no evidence presented to suggest that charges were found against individuals named. In particular, there was no evidence found against Tom Sermanni, who had been very badly wronged through the process of public vilification. It is important to highlight that Tom Sermanni was a highly respected soccer coach. In the past he acted as manager for a number of soccer players, most notably Ned Zelic whom he had managed for many years well before his departure to Europe. Mr Sermanni claimed, correctly, that he was frequently approached by young players concerned about their future. He had provided advice to a number of them without consideration of remuneration. He had been manager to a number of players and in one or two cases had advised or assisted players in obtaining trials overseas. There was no evidence of wrongdoing produced before this committee, yet Tom Sermanni's name was bandied about and his public reputation was put at risk as a result of some people within the soccer community playing politics.

It seems to me that this is an inappropriate use of the Senate and it was totally wrong for Mr Sermanni to be subjected to this sort of abuse. Equally, in regard to the allegations against Mr Ron Smith, that he had trafficked in players, again no evidence was presented to suggest that he had done anything wrong.

On balance we have to ask ourselves what sort of actions this Senate should properly be involved in. It is particularly insidious to suggest, as this report does, that somehow or another there was a potential for conflict of interest. Every day of the week all of us face the potential for conflict of interest. The real issue in terms of public policy and public behaviour is whether action is actually taken which is in conflict of interest with our responsibilities as public figures. Surely that equally applies to national coaches at soccer clubs. It seems to be inappropriate and just wrong to use the Senate to attack individual soccer players in this way.

We have to ask ourselves why people do this sort of thing. It seems to me to be a partisan political effort involving a dispute within the soccer community. It does not even have any implications in a party political sense and one has to ask what sort of morality is at stake here. As senators we can all have a go at one another in the public domain and it is part of our job to strongly advocate views and defend our constituents and the interests of our parties as we see them. It is wrong to involve people in the soccer industry in this way without the capacity to reply.

I do not think the Senate was well served by this committee. The majority report clearly has not demonstrated that there was a proper use of the Senate's time in this inquiry. In the end this soccer inquiry has produced the result that this committee is in the position of having even less credibility than the Stewart report itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak in respect of this report and reflect on where this debate was one year ago and where this Senate committee has in fact taken it. About a year ago the national coaches, Eddie Thomson and Les Scheinflug, administrators like Basil Scarsella and Tony Labbozzetta and players were all embroiled in a very public debate on the future of soccer.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Carr quite rightly said, that debate should have been left in the soccer fraternity. The fact that it was brought into this place raises issues that we should not only reflect on retrospectively, but issues of concern in terms of how the Senate committee process needs to be approached in the future.

BREAK.PARA: People were smeared at the time. The Australian Soccer Federation itself went through its internal process and, on reflection, the Stewart report—which the federation commissioned—was one which it and Stewart should have taken greater care in approaching and putting together. Some people were smeared and have had to live with the stigma. Last Sunday I was at a game and watched my team, West Adelaide, lose to Marconi and it was quite obvious that the history of all this was something that the game still had to grapple and contend with.

Before I came into politics I was involved as an administrator for about 10 years on a league football club in South Australia and for almost three years I was involved in the West Adelaide Soccer Club in South Australia. There is nothing more certain in life than internal squabbles in sporting associations and clubs. Squabbles happen everywhere; they happen in cricket, Aussie rules, rugby—as we see in the courts—and in all codes. You often find people who want to knife someone else. The play The club written by David Williamson was not just about sport. It was about organisations, politics and the fact that you cannot divorce one from the other.

I was concerned then as to the processes, and I still am concerned as to the processes that our parliamentary committees go into. At the time, whether it was the Hill-Negus group who were coming in to `clean‐up the game' or our national coaches or administrators, they were all lost as to how to handle the process. They were to appear before the Senate committee. They all had their particular side of the story, but none of them really was aware of the fact that when called they were expected to be here.

They kept on saying things to me, and it came from all sides. It came from, as I say, those who wanted to push the new broom and those who wanted to defend the old systems. It came from the stakeholders; it came from the clubs; it came from the national administration; and it came from the reform group. This is what they kept asking: do we have a right to hear all the evidence against us? What sort of right to representation do we have? What rules of evidence are there? What rules are there against hearsay evidence? What about so-and-so, whose son could not make the team because his talent was not good enough? What right does he have to make allegations against me and not have them tested in the way that maybe courts tackle these matters?

There was real confusion, as you would imagine that people not involved in our process would find themselves in, and there was real concern as to the state of rights of people appearing before committees such as this. I think there is a lesson that we have to learn here, and hopefully it is one that the Senate can take on.
