We need to spend some time developing rules that govern people's rights when they appear before parliamentary committees: the rights of individuals, the rights to be represented, the rules of evidence and the rights to legal assistance.

Some of the people we are talking about here are not and were not rich, but they could have found themselves, and some have found themselves, in a situation where they would have had to commission and had commissioned lawyers to represent them, to defend themselves on allegations which, in the normal course of events, would have been consigned to the dustbin of selection processes. So we really do need to focus on the rules of this place as they apply to individual citizens in our society, and I think that is one lesson that we should take on from here.
One year later, soccer continues to grow. David Hill is at the head. Of course, he is having teething problems and administrative problems, as you would imagine anyone would have.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ringing ALP endorsement.

—I have had discussions with David and, in particular, George Negus consistently for a long time. Our interest in the game is one to see the game improved. Eddie Thomson and Les Scheinflug, together with Raul Blanco, are developing a very strong profile for Australian soccer internationally. It is curious to note that, in beating my team the other night, Marconi is at the top of the league and is going to be fighting out the finals. It is also interesting to note that over the last 12 months the state of soccer in New South Wales has improved enormously, and now three of the top six clubs in the national competition are from New South Wales.

BREAK.PARA: I think in soccer we have in Australia an asset which is not and has not been appreciated sufficiently. It is a great sport. It attracts young people and both male and female participants. It has more players than any other sport in this country. Okay, it has been built on the back of migrants from Britain, Ireland, Scotland, all parts of Europe and, in latter days, from Asia. It is a game that is growing in popularity, as is witnessed by the audience of soccer programs on both SBS and the ABC. I am looking forward to the day, though, that one of the major networks in this country recognises there is probably as much interest in soccer as there is in some of the other codes and actually gives it the kick along that it deserves.

I will finish my comments by saying that I do not want to pass judgment on the committee, on any individual or on the politics that were being played at the time. I do say, though, that we found quite a number of individuals who were in many ways potential victims to the process. We should learn from that and look at refining our rules in this place to ensure that basic common rights can apply in the Senate committee process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Senator MICHAEL BAUME

TALK.START.PARA: —I guess the proof of the pudding about this second report on Australian soccer is evident from some of the things that Senator Bolkus has just said. The administration of soccer has improved immensely. Soccer is stronger. I am glad to note that New South Wales is doing well, with three clubs in the top grouping—I just wish Wollongong was perhaps doing a little better. But one of the intriguing things about the negative response by senators on the Labor side to this report is that in effect what they did—and it was a deliberate action—was to seek to diminish the impact of this report on some grounds which they say are significant. It was a report aimed at clearing up what were some unfortunate aspects of soccer. It was aimed at assisting those who were cleaning up soccer in their endeavours, and they succeeded despite the efforts of some Labor senators.

SPEECH.PARA: I should mention to Labor senators that at a recent function Mr Neville Wran, the president, commended this second report as being outstanding. He congratulated me for my role in it and said that it was an enormous help in fixing up soccer. Sometimes I just wonder what the motives are of some of the people opposite. I acknowledge, and always have, that in every Senate committee there must be appropriate recognition of individual rights. In fact, this committee proceeded with great constraints on it and performed, I believe, responsibly in recognising those matters. In fact, I will quote from the report. It states:
The Committee's First Report received a mixed response.
We are now dealing with the second report, which is the subject of today's discussion.
Those, particularly in the media, who believed the Senate failed to uncover evidence of corruption of which they claimed to be aware, were disappointed that there were no sensational outcomes . . .
Labor senators were saying, `Disgrace! Shock, horror! Sensational allegations!' The fact that there were no sensational outcomes was a problem for the media. They did not like that.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gave two people a chance to clear their names.

—It gave two people a chance to clear their names. This is the key thing: their names and the names of other people in soccer had not been raised in a critical way by this committee in the first place, nor by the Stewart inquiry, but by the ABC Four Corners program, by an ABC radio program and by a magazine. The Labor senators are now pretending the attacks on those people came from us. That is the most ludicrous bit of nonsense I have heard for a long time, but it is not unusual because I have heard it over and over again. That is why I question their motives in this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Those accusations were made repeatedly and the whole point of this committee was to clear them up. They were given the opportunity of clearing it up. By doing that, opportunities were then provided for other people, if they could, to explain why they made the accusations in public, in print, and to find out whether they were in fact accurate, and those who had not made those accusations publicly but had made them privately to some members of the media were invited to come forward to backup accusations that had been made in public. It is about time people on the other side faced up to the truth and stopped trying to blame this committee for airing these matters in the first place. It is simply dishonest to do so.
As I was saying, the committee was criticised by the media because there were no sensational outcomes. The report continues:
. . . those who believed the process had allowed damaging allegations to be retailed under parliamentary privilege were outraged—
and some of their outrage was so synthetic it is just ludicrous—
despite the fact that "in camera" hearings prevented the great bulk of unsubstantiated allegations made to the Committee going on the public record—
we specifically catered for that problem by having in camera evidence—

those who looked for a report that would, on the basis of conclusive evidence, resolve all the public and private allegations made over almost two years about impropriety in the sport, were not satisfied, as many potential witnesses who may have been of assistance to the inquiry chose not to appear.

No force, no compulsion. We did not subpoena anyone. I do not think it would have been proper for a Senate committee to have forced people to give evidence when they were not the subject of the inquiry. In other words, this committee acted with the utmost of propriety. It did it right. It avoided all the ludicrous accusations being made by some members of the opposition for unreasonable motives—I suppose `unreasonable' would be a parliamentary expression. They bear no relationship to the merits of this inquiry. I will read further from the report:
The great majority of witnesses welcomed the opportunity to participate and did so without specific invitation.
You would never know that from the comments made by the Labor Party senators opposite. The report continues:
Many of them looked to positive outcomes from the inquiry, particularly by way of reform of Soccer's administration policy objectives and regulatory mechanisms.
I have already quoted from a recent discussion I had with Neville Wran and I now also quote him from the report. It states:
Mr Neville Wran AC QC, President of the Australian Soccer Federation—
now Soccer Australia—
emphasised at a public hearing on 24 March 1995 that the ASF would be behind any player who came to the Committee to give evidence:

"As the President, I would like to use this opportunity to emphasise that my weight and the weight of the Board would be put behind any player who came to this Committee to give evidence of any malpractice or breach of ethics in relation to the conduct of the code."
The Chief Executive of the Australian Unity Soccer Players' Association (now the President of the Australian Soccer Player's Association), Mr Kimon Taliadoros—
who, I might say, has found form after he left Marconi and went to play with UTS Olympic; he has had a very good season—
commented on the significance of the Committee's inquiry for the future of Australian soccer:
This is the players' union. The Labor Party apparently has no interest at all in the players' union—the blokes at the shop front or on the paddock. But Mr Taliadoros said:
I thank the Senate for the opportunity to appear before you. We regard the matters before us as critical and of absolute fundamental importance to the future of Australian soccer.
You don't hear the Labor blokes saying that, do you? He said:
We cannot overestimate the significance and the role the Senate committee does play and will play in the future of Australian soccer.
That response from the blokes actually playing the game is a slightly different response, isn't it, from the people opposite playing the man?

I am intrigued to hear what was, by inference, a defence of the Marconi club by Senator Bolkus. I am not at all surprised to hear that. I was told by someone whose credibility I find very, very high that Senator Bolkus had said to them not to worry about what was perceived as attacks on Marconi—`I'll fix the committee for you.' No wonder Senator Bolkus is now treating it this way.

BREAK.PARA: To pretend it was the committee that was smearing Marconi or Mr Labbozzetta is nonsense. Mr Labbozzetta is before various courts and has been before various courts in this nation. He has been before the liquor licensing court in relation to breaches and so on. There are still litigations proceeding, so I do not want to discuss it. The fact is that any attempt to pretend this committee initiated these kinds of comments is a disgrace. I believe the committee is quite right in expressing its concern that these matters have not been resolved in the club Marconi.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I claim to be misrepresented. The assertion was made that I claimed that I could `fix' a Senate committee. I want to place on the record that not only did I not claim that—never stated it—but also I have never asserted that it is in the capacity of anyone to be able to fix a committee, particularly a committee of this place.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Finance and Public Administration References Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

As Chair of the Finance and Public Administration References Committee, I think it is very important that we take some time to examine the report and its implications. I am quite pleased to report to the Senate that, after some considerable effort in conducting the inquiry, the committee was unanimous in this report, its findings having been endorsed by all members.

This report should be of interest to all senators, particularly those in the new government. The introduction in chapter 1 tells us the background to the inquiry. I will not trouble the Senate with the first two paragraphs but I will draw its attention to paragraph 1.4 on page 2—it illuminates to some extent the reason for the inquiry—which states:

In October 1994, with the change to the Senate committee system, the Senate Finance and Public Administration References Committee identified service delivery by the APS as a key issue arising from the conference—
referred to earlier in the report—

and resolved to conduct the inquiry. Additionally, the Committee was concerned at a number of matters raised by the Commonwealth Ombudsman in her Annual Report 1993‐94 . The Ombudsman's report identified several issues relating to service delivery.

Of course, the Ombudsman may, at the moment, be having second thoughts about the wisdom of doing that. I think we ought to take heed of the function that the Ombudsman performed in alerting us to these problems. I think the recommendations that are at the front of the report are, and will continue to be, of great relevance to the Australian Public Service—in other words, what the Public Service is; what Australians expect their Public Service to do; and why it is necessary for the Public Service to serve the Australian public. They were matters that were considered by this committee and they are matters that are addressed in the recommendations.
Many of the recommendations may seem to have great irony in the very near future. For example, recommendation 1 states:
Special problems of small agencies be taken into consideration when applying the efficiency dividend—

I remind the Senate that coalition members on this inquiry endorsed this recommendation, as they did all the recommendations. I recall that that recommendation arose from the information we derived from visiting Launceston, a regional centre. I know that Senator Watson in particular—I am sure he will not mind me reminding the Senate of this—was impressed by the fact that these smaller agencies, and their smaller regional offices, were having great difficulty in meeting the efficiency dividend because they had been pared to the bone, so to speak. That recommendation will have the potential to have a great deal of irony in the very near future. I ask that coalition members of the committee, particularly Senators Campbell, Kemp, Minchin and Watson, to have a look at the recommendations to which they were party. Recommendation No. 2 states:

BREAK.PARA: Model contract principles be developed for the contracting out of service delivery, contracts which address the concerns identified by the Ombudsman—

I wonder what chance there is of that particular recommendation seeing the light of day in light of the developments which we are led to believe may happen soon with regard to our Public Service. I wonder whether the new government has even taken the trouble to address this report, which was available to it and which had been agreed to by members of the coalition. In the light of these recommendations, I think we should be asking ourselves, and the new government, whether there is any relevance in seeking information from the departments and from Australian citizens to allow us to reach these conclusions, and to see whether they have any relationship to the policies which we are led to believe could well be applied to the Public Service.

Other recommendations may be seen to have a greater or lesser degree of irony. From what I hear of the plans, it is obvious that the new government has not taken advantage of this excellent report, which is the product of a great deal of hard work, not only by the secretariat and the senators who were on the committee but also by members of the public and the departments that took the trouble to bring to the committee their concerns and the facts at their disposal.
I now draw the Senate's attention to recommendation No. 7, which explicitly says:

Improved use be made by Department of Finance of evaluations lodged with it by portfolios, with respect to assessment of the quality of evaluation, disseminating information on best practice in evaluation activity, and in reviewing improvements in the quality of service delivery—

If the resources of the Department of Finance are reduced, I think the department will find it very hard to disseminate what best practice is. I think it will find it very hard to monitor what best practice is. If the new government is at all interested in promoting best practice, I cannot see how it can even consider working in a direction which obviously contradicts the recommendation we have made.

PARA.BREAK: I must say in passing, though, that I noticed in a news report just recently that the Depart ment of Finance is responsible for initiating a venture into the Internet which lists new best practices and which provides information about them for other agencies to see and models to follow. But all that that does is acknowledge the Department of Finance's crucial role and the increasing importance of properly resourcing such central agencies to monitor, to recommend, to initiate and to implement models of good practice, and to apply models of efficiency through the Public Service. To reduce the resources of the central agencies is surely to fly in the face of that logical step which was agreed to as being important by, I would say, all those who gave evidence to this committee.

BREAK.PARA: Another thing which was very important and which the committee agreed to unanimously is embodied in recommendation 8, which states:
Agencies improve the recording of oral advice given to clients.

Of course, the reason for that is the notorious example that we have of a member of the public receiving advice given orally, taking action according to that advice or the interpretation that the member of the public puts upon it, and then finding that that is the wrong course to follow. That is a great inconvenience to the public. It is a great inefficiency and it requires a great amount of time and effort to be expended by both the citizen and the department to rectify the situation. That problem was common amongst a number of departments. We recommend that that recording be undertaken. Of course, that requires the devotion of some more resources initially to save time and to create efficiency later. If this new government decides to reduce the resources of our Public Service, such recommendations will be very difficult to follow.
I recommend that this report be a matter of urgent reading and consideration for those who have any interest in our Public Service, especially as it is a unanimous report.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I was chairman of this committee and one of my great regrets—although one does not have many regrets about becoming a minister of the new Howard government—is that I will no longer be chairman.

This committee was one of the most efficient and productive committees of the Senate and I think it is a tribute to the Senate that the Senate committee system has evolved to the stage where it is now. When I look back on the last six years of my membership of this committee, I believe that there are two milestones. One was the committee report on breast cancer and breast cancer screening in Australia, which has become a template, and as a result of which there has been extensive improvement in the breast cancer screening process in Australia. It was the cause of an enormous amount of debate and ultimately led to the establishment of the Australian National Cancer Network. I think this committee can take great pride in the fact that it was the catalyst for that occurrence.

We often underestimate the results of reports that are produced by the Senate, but I believe that this report—the tobacco industry and the costs of tobacco‐related illness—is an outstanding report. In fact, it is to be adopted by the World Health Organisation as a template for what will occur throughout the world. Not only does it set a benchmark for the management of tobacco within the community but also it very clearly demonstrates the devastating effect of tobacco on the Australian population.

I regret that there is a minority report. It is a paradox of the system, I suppose, that I am the only now government member of that committee who signed the majority report. The minority report was signed by my colleagues who held very genuine beliefs—I understand that—about some parts of the report, and I have no doubt that at least one member who signed the minority report will speak to that.

Having said that, it may well be that action is not taken on this report. Regrettably, it might be another one of those outstanding Australian achievements that is adopted by other countries. We may well fall behind the rest of the world even though we have produced a report that is even more comprehensive than that produced by the American Senate committee on the same tobacco industry and one produced by the United Kingdom.

I am in the process of distributing it around the world. I have contacts through the various cancer societies. I am dedicating it to Sir Richard Dole, who was the first person to demonstrate in the United Kingdom the association between tobacco and lung cancer. Sir Richard Dole is now over 90 years of age. He is very active and still involved. He was the one who, 40 years ago, got 50,000 doctors in the United Kingdom to tabulate their tobacco consumption. He followed them for 40 years.

That report was the first comprehensive report. It was produced and published in the British Medical Journal a couple of years ago. It showed that half of those 50,000 died as a direct result of tobacco consumption, either of lung cancer or many of the other diseases that occur: renal cancer, pulmonary disease, emphysema, coronary artery disease, and all the other diseases.

Peculiarly enough, there is a connection with my present ministry because at the time I had no idea that I would be in this position. When that report was published one of the extraordinary things that occurred was an attack by the public relations department of Philip Morris. They wrote to every small business in Australia. I have not got around to thanking them because it was the first time my name got known throughout the wider community. They did not know that I tabulated all those names. Every small business in Australia got letters from us in relation to the campaign. I thank the public relations director of Philip Morris for letting me know the names and addresses of every small business in Australia.

BREAK.PARA: As a result of this present ministry, I just allude to page 107 of the report, which states:

In Western Australia, in the period 1983 to 1991, tobacco smoking was responsible for 13 per cent of all Aboriginal deaths, compared to 10 per cent of Aboriginal deaths being related to excessive alcohol consumption.

This came out through the research. Tobacco smoking is one of the biggest killers within the indigenous community of Australia because 56 per cent of Aboriginal people living in the Northern Territory smoke cigarettes or tobacco, according to a survey conducted in 1986. I would like to let the tobacco industry know that in this ministry one of the major projects that I will start is an anti-tobacco education program within the indigenous community because I think it is important, as documented, as it is such a major killer within that community.

Since the report was produced there has been evidence given in the United States and there are class actions occurring in relation to liability of employers to employees within the industry. I was attacked by the Australian Hotels Association. It was interesting that the executive director of the AHA was the previous director of the Tobacco Institute of Australia. I do not think that was coincidental. I wrote back to him pointing out this problem in relation to the fact that legislation may well ensue in relation to the liability of employers within the hotel and allied trades industry.

If we knew then what we know now about this particular product, of course it would be a prohibited product. As I mentioned also, the report is a blueprint. I think that the dissent that occurred will be spoken to. I welcome further debate about this particular report because I think that ongoing debate will ultimately lead to a consensus on it overall throughout the community of Australia.

I commend the other members of the committee for their contributions. It was a very comprehensive report. We sought advice from many people. We had individual contributions put forward. Many witnesses appeared before the committee. Since its publication I have received laudatory comments from the Australian Cancer Society, the Australian Medical Association, the National Heart Foundation, the Queensland Cancer Fund, the Non-Smokers' Movement of Australia, the Anti-Cancer Council of Victoria, the Australian Council on Smoking and Health and the Northern Territory Department of Health and Community Services in respect of its alcohol and other drugs program. I could go on. There are many others who have written congratulatory reports. I commend this report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Community Affairs References Committee, I would like to make a few remarks on its report into the tobacco industry. I congratulate my colleague Senator Herron on his chairmanship of the committee and the secretariat for what is a very comprehensive and valuable report in the main. I support most of the recommendations of this committee. In fact, 27 of the 39 recommendations have my endorsement as a member of the committee. I particularly support those measures directed towards the education of young people about the dangers of smoking.

SPEECH.PARA: I am certainly no advocate of smoking. There are other measures in the report which are designed to prevent young people taking up the habit. I feel very strongly about doing all that we can to prevent adolescents from smoking. At my request, the committee has recommended that the states and territories investigate the feasibility of making it an offence for underage people to purchase tobacco products. I encourage the states and territories to actually take that action.

I take the view that we should treat smoking as adult behaviour. You do have to draw a distinction between the way governments treat adults in relation to behaviour such as smoking and the way you treat adolescents. I think governments do have a role in educating and preventing young people taking up or indulging in what is a dangerous and risky behaviour. The role in relation to adults should be somewhat different in a liberal society. I think the role is to do as much as possible to educate adults about the dangers of the habit and to ensure they know the risks of this particular activity, but at the end of the day the risk is theirs.

On that basis, Senator Knowles and I did put in a minority report. There are 12 recommendations that we cannot support primarily because they seek to further increase the regulation of what is already the most highly regulated industry in Australia, regulation the like of which no other legal industry—and it is a legal industry—has to endure.

I am particularly concerned about the effect of recommendation 25, which seeks to reduce the number of retail outlets permitted to sell tobacco products. This is a Senate committee saying that there should be a reduction in the number of retail outlets. This would be devastating for the small business sector of our community. I think a lot of people are not aware of the extent to which the sale of tobacco products is a vital component of small business revenue. For tobacconists it is 85 per cent of revenue, but even for service stations it comprises 40 per cent of their revenue, for convenience stores it comprises 30 per cent and for milk bars it comprises 25 per cent. It is all very well for senators to sit around and feel good and say, `Let's reduce the number of retail outlets.' These are the lives of men and women striving in small businesses and trying to make a living under already very difficult conditions and they cannot withstand this sort of recommendation.

The problem must be treated at the source. Discouraging people from taking up the practice by education is one thing, but to actually seek to have the government act in an authoritarian manner to restrict the number of outlets able to sell the product is unduly authoritarian and not one that I could ever support.

I oppose in particular the proposal that there should be further increases in the real level of taxation on this product. My objection is on the basis that there has been a 96 per cent increase in real terms in revenue from tobacco to governments over the past 12 years—a massive increase in the amount of taxation—and, of course, this falls on the lower income earning sector of our society. It is a very regressive form of taxation and one that is very undesirable.

BREAK.PARA: ACIL, the very respected economic consultancy, has estimated that smokers are already taxed $2.2 billion over and above their use of subsidised health care. So they are making much more of a contribution to the community than they have received from it for the effects of their habit. They are subsidising the rest of the community who are non‐smokers. I think that is unconscionable and I could never support a proposition for further increases.

I will not take up any more of the Senate's time. The majority of the recommendations have our support but there are a number that simply go too far in a free and liberal society and they should never be adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to have been able to participate in the preparation of this report and to have been one of the signatories to the majority report. Tobacco smoking and related areas is always a contentious issue. We knew that before we started looking at them. I respect the opinions of those who put in the minority report but I and a number of others on the committee come from a biased background.

SPEECH.PARA: As someone with an 18‐year nursing background and having been married to a smoker who died of cardiac disease at a young age, I feel very strongly about this issue. I know, from committee discussions, that Senator Minchin is still not convinced that nicotine is addictive. That is something he will have to work through.

TALK.START.PARA: —But it is addictive.

—Yes, it is. We had evidence from people in the industry that it was not addictive but that was before the recent revelations in the United States when the industry itself said, `Yes, we know.' That is important to recognise.

SPEECH.PARA: Like Senator Herron, I am also interested in the responses to the campaign waged by tobacco companies, such as Philip Morris, against this report. I also had a lot of letters from people who did not like the report. They thought they knew what was in it without reading it. They were going on the information provided by Philip Morris.

BREAK.PARA: Where I could, I made the effort to talk to people who had written or rung and I was amazed by their lack of understanding of the committee process. They had been led to believe that these recommendations were law. That they were not was a major point to get across to them.

They informed me about the need to restrict access to tobacco products. These were people who were selling the product. There were a number of reasons for that. Lots of small outlets have a very low tobacco turnover and those who were concerned about the quality of the product felt that the low turnover was leading to stale cigarettes. They therefore felt there should be rationalisation within the industry. It seems that every other industry in this country has undergone rationalisation of their outlets.

There was also a plea by outlets for support in enforcing the no identification‐no sale law. A number of people rang me and said they were sick and tired of having parents sending their kids into the shops to buy cigarettes for them. They were embarrassed about knocking the kids back and by the fact that parents did not understand the magnitude of what they were asking their children to do, which is to break the law. They certainly wanted support in enforcing that restriction.

In recent times in the central west of New South Wales the health department conducted a survey of compliance with the law and found a compliance rate of 80 per cent. That is fine but it means that 20 per cent are not complying with the law. It means that 20 per cent could be advertising incorrectly or selling to minors.

There is another issue regarding tobacco advertising which concerns me greatly. It is touched on in recommendation 25, one of the more contentious recommendations and the one that the industry and Senator Minchin do not like. It recommends as an interim measure the isolation of tobacco products from other products for sale in outlets. It is interesting to note that newsagents in New South Wales can isolate their lotto and other gambling sales but they cannot isolate their tobacco sales. It seems to me that if you can isolate your lotto sales you should be able to isolate your tobacco sales.

That draws me to the issue of the juxtaposition of tobacco with other products. I name the Darrell Lea franchise outlets in central western New South Wales. Things may have changed in the last few weeks since the health department did its survey, but until recent times the Darrell Lea shops were selling tobacco as well as lollies, chocolates and, in some cases, discount ice cream.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are joking!

—I am not joking, Senator Bolkus; that is a fact. In a shop in Bathurst there was even an area recessed from the footpath, like a porch, with a mobile cabinet displaying tobacco products. That has gone now but following Easter, when the windows were full of Easter eggs in lovely, glitzy tinsel—nice products—there was a display window full of Alpine tobacco products. I have a problem with that.

BREAK.PARA: In a number of newsagents there is a small display of cigarettes above the counter. But I have been into several where you look behind and see a very large, colourful display of cigarettes, right next to which are the swap cards. I have a problem with the close juxtaposition of a product that can be sold legally only to persons aged 18 or over with other products that are attractive to and attention grabbing for the younger people in our community. If that situation is not addressed then we will be doing nothing to overcome the problem of underage smoking.

You cannot tell me that the chief purchasers of swap cards are people over the age of 18. They are not. I have watched them. They are young people in their early teens who, at this stage of their lives, are not able to make an adult decision as to whether or not they smoke. They are seeing a product which is absolutely next door to the product they are purchasing, which they know is legal and which they enjoy being involved with.

The wrong messages are being sent to the younger members of the community. Until retailers and tobacco companies do something to address this problem, I am afraid that I cannot rest. I find it to be in such bad taste, I wonder about the morals and the efficacy of it. It offends me greatly that these products are being put next to products that are a great attraction to young people in our community. They wrap up and put in brown paper covers the explicit sex magazines. They can restrict the sex magazines, they can restrict the access to Lotto, but they cannot restrict access to a product that kills. I do not know what our priorities are in this community if we are going to allow that to happen.

I urge the new government and Senator Herron to most vigorously pursue this report and to uphold and agree to as many recommendations as possible or to address the questions that have actually been identified here. This is a real problem. A lot of evidence came before the committee. The problem that worries us now is that an increasing number of young females under the age of 18 are taking up the habit. They are taking it up at a greater rate than are young males. This is going to have an impact on health later on. We know that unborn children are affected by tobacco. We know that babies are affected by the inhalation of tobacco smoke after they are born. These issues have to be addressed. I urge the government to take this report very seriously. This issue is of grave concern and grave importance to the young people in this community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for consideration of committee reports has expired.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a pleasant change it is to participate in a debate in response to an opening speech by the Governor-General which is full of sanity, decency, integrity and hope for the future. It is a pleasant change after 13 years of what we have had to put up with, what the Australian people have had to put up with, particularly the false hopes, false promises and, regrettably, unsatisfactory outcomes. As was pointed out in this chamber today, we were left with a black hole.

BREAK.PARA: The government, having won an enormous endorsement from the Australian people, now has to put up with resolving an even worse mess than was admitted to during the election campaign by the Labor Party in government. As the Governor-General's speech, which outlined the approach of the government, said:
Australia is a society rich in resources of all kinds. We should not have to settle for a lower level of economic performance than other countries with fewer advantages.

That is what happened under the Labor government. Fortunately, that era has ended. This government's policies, as outlined, are to fulfil people's aspirations by rewarding hard work and initiative, and achieving rising living standards, affordable home ownership and a more positive future for our children. Let us look at all those things and the way we can achieve them.

Rewarding hard work involves getting rid of the nonsense involved in the present industrial relations system. People in this place who represent a clear minority of the Australian people claim that they are going to do what they can to block the massive reforms needed to the Australian industrial relations system. Apart from rewarding hard work and initiative, we want to achieve rising living standards. That is done by reducing costs and by providing incentives, which leads to increased competitiveness internationally.

An interesting issue is affordable home ownership. Before the last election it was particularly disturbing to see that after a year or so of home ownership, young families all around Australia found that, as a result of the previous government's policies, they owed more on their house than it was worth. This negative equity was a dreadful blow to so many young Australians, many of whom found it necessary—perhaps because of moving for a new job—to sell their house. They faced losses—some of them significant—in doing so. I am not talking about mansions, I am talking about $100,000 houses.

The honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Fahey), my successor after an unfortunate break, made his maiden speech today. He said one of the striking things about the win in the electorate of Macarthur was that he won booths in what had been Labor heartland. There was disenchantment by people who had lost faith. They were no longer true believers, because of the actions of the true deceivers.

It means that we have a specific duty to ensure that we take the strong actions needed, which the previous government failed to do, to protect the opportunities of these people, to make certain that home ownership is affordable and that the government's own actions do not damage the future for Australians the way the previous government's actions did. That is why it is so heartening to hear in this speech of the Governor‐General, stating the Howard government's policies, that the needs of Australian families will be placed at the centre of the national policy agenda. Small business will be promoted as a dynamic engine of our economy which can offer new jobs and opportunities to many Australians. In particular, more young Australians will have the opportunity to fulfil their talents through rewarding jobs.

In looking at the achievements, if I can use that word loosely, of the previous government, what I found interesting was that, despite all sorts of promises and assurances and despite its attack on the 1993 coalition policy supporting a broad based indirect tax, the previous government had massively increased taxes on many of the vital products that Australians consume, without providing the offsetting tax benefits that had been promised in 1993. That dishonest campaign by the Labor Party in 1993 came home to roost. That level of dishonesty was simply unacceptable to the Australian people, and that is one of the reasons for this heartland rejection by so many traditional Labor voters of a party that simply let them down, lied to them, misled them and taxed them significantly on the very basics.

During the election campaign, I found that one of the most successful dodgers being handed out outside shopping centres was one which related to the huge increases in indirect taxes, in the face of the previous government's promise not to, which hit struggling lower income groups more than they hit anyone else. They were directed at the essentials of life. These huge increases were not as promised. They were exactly the opposite of what was promised in 1993. That helps explain the level of disenchantment.

I have mentioned before in this place the huge increase that was represented in some of these areas. For example, there was a 46 per cent increase in the sales tax on ordinary passenger cars after the 1993 election, when the previous government had promised not to increase indirect taxes. Sales tax on cars went up from 15 per cent to 22 per cent. There was a 30 per cent increase in tax on wine and cider. That was a terrific boost to the winemakers and apple growers, particularly those of Tasmania. No‐one from the Labor Party said anything about that in the 1993 election. Their sales tax was up 30 per cent because it rose from a 20 per cent rate to a 26 per cent rate. The previous government whacked up the price of food items like biscuits, flavoured milk, fruit and vegetable juices, cordials, ice‐cream and confectionery, snack foods and soft drink by 20 per cent, from a 10 per cent rate to a 12 per cent rate. And so it goes on.

Many people did not realise these taxes were there. They listened to the Labor Party talking about how dreadful indirect taxes and consumption taxes were and believed them. There were huge taxes. There is one group of items for which sales tax went up from 30 per cent to 33 per cent. That was an increase in sales tax of almost one‐third. That was on things like televisions, videos, watches, clocks, records, CD players, cameras and tape recorders. These sorts of things are what many people say are luxuries. Most Australians take the view that they are the normal things that Australians are entitled to have, because, after all, we are not supposed to be a Third World country, even though the previous government may well have treated us as such.

But there are other things too. Sales tax went up by 10 per cent, unheralded, unsung, unpromised. In fact, the opposite was promised by the Labor government. It lifted sales tax from 20 to 22 per cent on items like dog food. Pensioners who had a pet to keep them company—particularly single pensioners whose partners had died—faced these hidden rises. The reason I am stressing this is that we have a record of a Labor government which deceived the people of Australia with its hidden, unheralded taxes which it had promised not to impose. As against that, we now have a coalition government which has given a commitment to stick by its promises. This will involve a radical change in Australian politics.

The response by the Australian people to that totally deceptive approach by the Keating government is best evidenced by the Illawarra Mercury, which the Labor Party enjoys showing front pages of every now and again in this chamber. The Illawarra Mercury, on the Monday after the election, showed Mr Keating at the Bankstown workers sports club. Under the heading `Leadership' all that was left were the letters `RS'. That sums up in the Australian vernacular the style, the attitude, the approach and the performance of the Labor Party—definitely very RS. It is interesting to notice that despite this alleged attack on—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I don't know the broad definitions of `unparliamentary' but clearly Senator Baume is trying to indicate that he believes `RS' stands for something that, if he said it out loud, would be unparliamentary. He should either have the courage to say what it says or be asked to withdraw it.

—On the point of order: it is quite obvious that Senator Baume is trying, as civilly as he possibly can, to express a matter which is of great emotion and significance to him and he is trying to do it in language which befits the chamber. I do not think that that should give rise to any censure against Senator Baume, in fact I think Senator Baume should be congratulated for his moderation in these matters.

—Senator Schacht has made his submission about standing orders and it is the case that Senator Baume has drawn attention to two letters which he has not made explicit in the chamber. Also, there are colloquialisms that he has implied. In noting that it is a headline in one of the papers to which he has drawn reference, I ask him to continue his speech on the address‐in‐reply.

—I can understand Senator Schacht's sensitivity. Those initials may well appropriately summarise his performance whilst he was a minister, in whatever vernacular meaning it may or may not have. This government has to face a situation in which the previous government, the Labor government, failed dismally. We keep hearing how the Labor Party is going to reconsider its approach to taxes. The President of the Labor Party is quoted today in the Australian Financial Review as saying that he thought perhaps they should have a look at a consumption tax. The article states:

BREAK.PARA: ALP President Mr Barry Jones yesterday added his voice to Labor calls for open debate on tax reform, saying that in the aftermath of its emphatic defeat at the polls, the party could not rule out a goods and services tax in any revision of its policies.

That is going back to basics, is it not? I can remember Mr Paul Keating, the former Prime Minister who slunk out of this business without facing the parliament after his defeat, was one of the first people to urge for a goods and services tax. Is it not incredible to see how flexible the Labor Party is on matters of principle?

It is disappointing that the Labor Party managed to increase sales tax significantly, which is the most common indirect tax, since it came into office. It was a huge increase which it hid; in fact there was a 50 per cent increase in sales tax as a proportion of GDP since it came into office. At the same time, it was saying we could not have any indirect taxes.

The 1982-83 budget—that is, the Howard budget—had sales tax collecting about two per cent of gross domestic product. The 1995-96 Labor budget had three per cent—a 50 per cent increase in the percentage of sales tax to GDP. But at the same time in 1982‐83 income tax provided 16.3 per cent of gross domestic product. It is now up to 18.4 per cent. That is higher than even in the Whitlam years. So the previous government was hitting the Australian consumer by stealth, yet at the same time it was resisting attempts to really fix up the tax system.

There is one area of the tax system that I hope the government takes into consideration in its review of tax: tax expenditures—and I am glad to hear that it will be looking at equity and such matters. There is a statement before the chamber at the moment from Treasury dealing with tax expenditures. I hope that it will take into consideration the fact that there are some benefits in some tax expenditures. Tax expenditures, by the way, represent the cost to the government of tax concessions and many people find them particularly useful concessions for various reasons such as providing incentives, in some instances, for private sector activity.

It is intriguing to note, though, that there has been a blow-out in tax expenditures over the last six years. Six years ago tax expenditures—in other words, the cost to the government of various deductions—were $10.8 billion. They are now $17.8 billion, something like a 70 per cent increase in just six years. Obviously, this is one of the things that will have to be looked at. As the Treasury document states:
While most tax expenditures could in principle be replaced by a direct outlay—
in other words, by a grant of some kind—
the tax expenditure estimates refer to revenue forgone.

Is it better, for example, to give people direct grants or to give people tax deductions? Clearly, that is a question the government will have to look at. There are many people who would much prefer to see things given as a direct grant.

In some areas, like culture and recreation, there is a clear benefit in providing a tax expenditure; in other words, providing incentives for the private sector to provide funding for various activities in order to get a tax deduction. These areas are not large expenditure items. Tax concessions in culture and recreation now represent only 0.1 per cent of all tax expenditures; of the $17.8 billion that these concessions cost the government—in other words, taxpayers—culture and recreation now represent only $24 million, 0.1 per cent. Six years ago, they represented a whole 0.8 per cent. They have never been big, but they have declined dramatically—from about $80 million to only $24 million. At the same time, the total of all these other areas has gone up from $10.8 billion to $17.8 billion.

The advantage of having tax expenditures for the arts is that it provides an incentive for the private sector to contribute to the arts in a way that the private sector may well not find interesting or attractive otherwise. A small concession by the government encourages a large contribution from the private sector. It is arguable that without the contribution from the government the private sector may find other ways of spending its money.

There are quite a few areas where great benefits can be achieved. Film is one that was overdone. As a result of the abuse of film credits, there was almost a reaction against it. There is no doubt that taxation incentives for the film industry, which have continued, but on a less generous rate, have been a factor in the extraordinarily dramatic success of the Australian film industry. I think almost all of the $24 million that is going to culture and recreation goes to film.

There are other areas, though, that I would hope would receive a much greater stimulus, in particular funding for the area of sports activities. Not enough attention has been paid, in my view, to the capacity for people to contribute, through tax deductible items, to the sporting success of Australia. There is an organisation run by the Australian Sports Foundation, which hopefully, with the Olympics in Atlanta and the Sydney Olympics coming up, will encourage many people to take up this matter.

I want to make my plea to the government. If there is to be a total review of tax, and in particular tax expenditures, I plead with the government to recognise—and I am certain that the government will recognise—that there is some merit in some of these areas. There is no doubt that in many other areas—I exclude arts and sport from these—there has been an incredible blow‐out in tax expenditures.
I also want to quickly deal with the issue of industrial relations. The Governor-General in his speech said:

The industrial relations legislation, to be introduced early in the life of the Parliament, will promote genuine co‐operation between employers and employees, provide greater scope for workplace agreements and give all Australians greater choice and more incentive.
I certainly endorse that. The Australian people endorsed that at the last election.

Many people go around the place saying that they have a mandate to do something. I would prefer to see it as a responsibility to do something. We were elected to be a responsible government. It is the responsibility of this government to make those improvements that it talked about clearly and openly to the Australian people before the Australian people passed their very decisive vote in favour of this government.

Maybe the opposition will say that we do not have a mandate and that, really, all the Australian people were doing was voting against them. I suppose that that is a respectable point of view. One would expect most people of sound mind to take the view that the previous government was not doing a very good job and deserved to get beaten. The fact is that the present Australian government has a responsibility to deliver those reforms that could not be delivered before.

Despite comments by even such people as the Chief Justice of the Industrial Relations Court—who said that everything was wonderful in that jurisdiction before the election, which was a fairly inappropriate intervention—there is no doubt that there are serious problems in that court and certainly in the way that the union membership matter has been conducted in the past. It would seem to me that as fewer and fewer people in Australia—less than a third of the work force now—determine that they want to be `protected' by unions, there is greater and greater need for a new system to be introduced that will provide a degree of effective protection for those people. I am overjoyed to see that this government is doing that.

I should also briefly refer to the Telstra matter, which I raised at question time today. It was alleged that my question, which was followed by my welcoming the determination of the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) to make Telstra more efficient, was taken by the Labor opposition to be an attack on Telstra which would diminish our capacity to float it off. How absurd! What was being demonstrated was very simple: there is enormous scope for massive improvements in the efficiency of Telstra, and those efficiencies will emerge from its partial privatisation, because at last it will be genuinely exposed to commercial reality.

Obviously, it is very difficult for an organisation which has been an effective monopolist for so long to suddenly change into being a competitive force. You can see those difficulties—institutional difficulties, if you like—in the dispute about Optus and Telstra sharing cabling, about whether things should be underground or overhead.

It has been revealed that attempts to negotiate by Optus were met with a pretty tough and brusque response from Telstra. Whoever was right or wrong, the fact remains that Australian society is having to cope with an unnecessary and expensive duplication of a whole set of cables, some of which are unsightly, because of an inability to come to a rational and sensible arrangement beforehand. I would hope that commercial reality will be a much stronger factor in future decisions of Telstra. Far from my damaging the prospects of floating Telstra, what I am demonstrating is that if past figures which were quoted by the Labor opposition showed a great achievement while it was being run badly, imagine what could be achieved if it is run well and if you get back to international standards in terms of employment and so on, and you have better work practices and a situation where commercial reality is dominant.

I do not know whether Labor members really believe the people who complained about Telstra affecting their businesses. Maybe the Labor Party does not believe those people. Maybe they think they did not have a claim or maybe they think they were handled admirably. If so, I think Labor Party senators who take that view would be in a massive minority, both in this building and among the Australian people. The fact is that there are improvements that can and should be made. I am overjoyed that we are proceeding with this. Of course, the results of the sale will allow one of the greatest environmental advances from a government ever made in this country. I totally approve. I commend the speech. I think it sets us on a path which will result in this government being the first of many Howard governments to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this address‐in‐reply to the speech of the Governor-General. Of course, as we all know, it is not a speech written by the Governor-General. It is a speech written by the government—the Prime Minister in particular. I have been in politics for nearly 30 years. I have seen governments of all persuasions, state and federal. I sat here yesterday and I have to say that I have never heard a more uninspiring speech from a new government. One would have thought that after 13 years in opposition, we would have got something more visionary, more inspiring and more exciting than was dished up yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: It does not matter about the length of the speech. That is not important. The Gettysburg Address, which I think is 267 words, is considered to be one of the great speeches of all time. So length of speech is not a determining factor of quality or of content. It was a short speech yesterday, but it is the content that really condemns it.

I waited for an indication of some view from the new government of the practical measures they are going to introduce—bits and pieces of legislation, the odd privatisation and the odd change to industrial relations legislation. I expected that there would be some theme to it.

The one theme that I could detect was something to do with improving the competitiveness of the Australian economy. That is fine. Improving the economy is a noble objective. Certainly, if you went back and looked at Governor-Generals' speeches over the 13 years of the previous government, we also had the objectives to make ourselves a more internationally competitive economy, with more effective exports, et cetera. But there was no vision in this speech about the sort of society Australia should have, other than a few cliches about inclusiveness, cohesiveness or anything like that. There was no indication of how that was going to be achieved.

I suppose one of the reasons why there was so little substance about policy in the speech is in fact because, to get itself elected, the opposition had to commit itself to supporting so many of the policies of the previous government. It would have been too embarrassing for John Howard to support the continuation of the many excellent policies of the previous government in the Governor-General's speech.

I will return later to some individual aspects of the Governor‐General's speech. I certainly want to return to the remarks he made on behalf of us all about the shocking events that occurred last Sunday in Tasmania. I do want to make mention of the constitutional convention that he will be calling and the issue of legislation on the flag. But as shadow minister for communications, I wish to talk about the speech and the government's policies on the privatisation of Telstra.
I second and strongly support the amendment moved by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Faulkner. It is:
That the following words be added to the Address‐in‐Reply:
", and the Senate is of the opinion that no part of Telstra should be sold."

We have before us, in a limited way in the Governor‐General's speech and also from the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) here in the parliament today, reasons why Telstra should be privatised. We have heard remarks from Senator Baume—probably not the last remarks, but maybe we will not have long to hear from Senator Baume, if the rumours are correct. I hear that he may be given one of the first political appointments of the new government, some ambassadorship or high commissionership overseas. Many of us on this side of politics may think that his appointment as ambassador to Liberia would be appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only Senator Baume could bring peace to Liberia—only Senator Baume has the capacity.

—When Senator Baume's appointment is made, one of the things we will not have to put up with is the sanctimonious remarks the opposition made for 13 years about political appointments. Senator Baume will be the ultimate political pay-off of the new Prime Minister paying off an old friend who stuck with him through thick and thin, the bad days and the good days, of the 13 years of opposition. I suppose maybe Senator Baume, with his previous record with Patrick Partners being a stockbroker and investment adviser back in the seventies, is hankering for the consul generalship in New York, where he can be close to Wall Street and may be able to see how people like Mr Michael Milken defrauded hundreds of millions of dollars from the shareholders in America and ultimately went to gaol for his crimes. We will not have to put up with Senator Baume for much longer and, for many on this side, that will probably be a great relief.

SPEECH.PARA: The comments Senator Baume made about Telstra today in the parliament are really amazing and way off the point. He has talked down and bagged one of the biggest companies in Australia. He has tried to make out to the Senate that this is a broken down company that is inefficient and appalling and that it should be privatised to be saved.

As I pointed out in my remarks when taking note of Senator Alston's comments, this is a company that at the moment employs 75,000 Australians full time. Senator Baume wants to sack about 30,000 of them, if you try to read through his remarks. This is from a senator who made sanctimonious remarks about the need to reduce unemployment in Australia but is quite cheerful about the idea that up to 30,000 employees from Telstra around Australia would be sacked.

Remember this, it will not be just the employees or middle managers at headquarters in Melbourne or Sydney that will be dismissed; it will be literally thousands—tens of thousands of employees of Telstra spread out across rural and regional Australia. I would have thought the National Party would be particularly worried to see the impact that would have on employment in small and large towns in regional and rural Australia.

He has bagged the performance of Telstra, failing to mention that in 1994-95 this company made a profit before tax of $2.4 billion—the biggest profit of any company in Australia's history. That is not a bad performance. Profit after tax was $1.7 million. The dividend to the federal government, to the people of Australia, was $944 million, which was on top of tax of $649 million paid to the Australian people.

The total value added of the company for 1994-95 was $8.7 billion and that was distributed, which again points out the value of this company to Australia. The value of that $8.7 billion went to workers—employees' wages and superannuation of $3.9 billion or 44.6 per cent. To the providers of capital, $506 million went as interest, and $944 million, as I said, went as dividends.

Government taxes were 7.4 per cent—that is, income tax—and other taxes were $288 million. For reinvestment, $2.4 billion, 28 per cent, of that value added went in reinvestment. That is major investment for the infrastructure of Australia. It is investment that created jobs, investment that created growth for literally thousands of small businesses across Australia that rely on Telstra to be a major purchaser of their services.

Telstra has a policy of buying Australian. It is an industry policy that, when we were in government, we were proud to be associated with. We wrote it into the policy of Telstra and into our telecommunications policy. We have no indication from the opposition when they privatise Telstra how those industry policies, those guarantees of Purchasing Australia, will be maintained. When you start letting foreign owners in, they are not going to be interested in buying from the corner store or from an Australian SME. They will want to buy at the cheapest possible price. They will import the product from overseas, and that costs jobs. It costs the jobs in the small business area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Telstra has consistently favoured foreign mobile phone manufacturers over Australian ones.
—Senator, you speak with great ignorance on this issue, but I cannot condemn you because generally your ignorance on most issues in this place is profound.

SPEECH.PARA: Telstra has a purchasing policy, wherever possible, to buy Australian. You go and talk to Ericsson Australia, to Alcatel and to other major manufacturers and they will all tell you that they only exist in Australia because of Telstra's policy for the past 30 or 40 years to buy Australian. They would not be in Australia if it were not for that Telstra policy—a policy that goes right back to when it was a government department. That will all come to an end. There will be no industry development policy with the privatisation of Telstra.

The opposition has said, `But we are only going to privatise a third of it. We are going to privatise a third and raise $8 million, and we will only allow 12½ per cent foreign owners.' We all know that will be the foot in the door. During the election campaign, on a couple of occasions Mr Howard let it slip, `That is only the first step. Maybe after the next election, if we are successful, we will look at privatising more of it.' We all know that once you privatise part of such an organisation the inevitability of the whole lot being sold will follow as surely as day follows night.

Let us not beat around the bush here. We are talking about the privatisation of Telstra. We are told that there will be limitations on the foreign investment, the foreign ownership, of Telstra. At the moment it will be 12 per cent but, when you go to full privatisation, the government would be looking at selling Telstra and getting a price of something in excess of $20 billion—the biggest float of any company in the history of Australia.

It is said by many experts that you will not be able to find anywhere near the $20 billion in the Australian stock market or the Australian capital market. The only way you will get anywhere near that figure is to allow a large proportion of it to come in from overseas. Even though you may want to limit it, in the end, to get the money you want, you will have to raise the foreign limit and basically let the foreigners have as much as they want to get the price you want. Once that occurs, every time you make a phone call in Australia thereafter the money registers will roll over in Tokyo or Paris or New York or London. Those foreign companies will get the benefit.

The other aspect of the Telstra policy that the coalition has not talked about is that once you allow foreign ownership from other telcos in at any level they would not want Telstra competing with them in foreign markets, particularly in the Asia‐Pacific region. Some people have predicted in the next 10 years 500 million phones will be connected in the Asia-Pacific region, which will double the number of phone connections in the history of telephony in the world.

We should be in there with a big company, like Telstra, owned by Australians, by the government, to make sure we get a big slice of that action. Could you imagine that a Japanese owned company, an American owned company or a French owned telco would be very happy having an Australian company sharing with them? If they are a shareholder in the Australian company they will do everything at the board level to wind back Telstra's investment overseas so they have less competition.

Those of us who have had the opportunity to see the impact Telstra staff have made on places like Vietnam, China, Indonesia and India with the development of foreign markets that are earning income for Australia would realise we have great prospects. The privatisation of Telstra, allowing other foreign owned telecommunications companies in, will restrict our ability to develop an Australian generic name—an export earner for Australia. These are important issues which the government has not yet addressed in the debate we have heard so far.

One of the issues the government has tried to address is cross‐subsidies and community service obligations. Senator Alston has been at some pains to say, `We will write in the privatisation legislation that we will guarantee community service obligations will be connected, will continue and will be subsidised.' I know, and anyone who has been around politics long enough will know, that you can write it in, but when a government five years hence is a bit short of money and trying to raise funds it will say, `Well, it is costing us $500 million for the community service obligations.' Treasury and the Finance department might say, `Well, we know how to get you a couple of hundred million. We will reduce the community service obligations.' It would be put in the budget and through it would go. That would be a reduction. You cannot guarantee the community service obligations forever and a day even by legislation or regulation.
The National Party, in particular, should be extremely worried because its constituency out in the bush will be the first losers when the community service obligations are wiped out or reduced.
Senator McGauran interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —We had an example of this only a couple of weeks ago when Telstra approached the new government, after approaching the previous government on several occasions, to say, `We want to charge for directory assistance. We believe we can raise $80 million in a year by handling the millions of phone calls that people make to get telephone and directory assistance.' That is provided free at the moment. There are sections of our community who need to have that assistance and should not be charged for it. The blind, old people and so on have difficulty reading telephone books.

SPEECH.PARA: We rejected those applications when we were in government. So far—I may be corrected—I have seen no public statement by Senator Alston saying that he is going to reject such an application. The reason I believe he will not reject it at the moment is if the so-called privatisation process is allowed to run he will want to tell those companies who want to bid for Telstra, `There is another $80 million of revenue coming your way. You can charge for directory assistance.' This will boost the price at the expense of the blind, the old, the feeble—those in the community who can least afford it. You cannot guarantee with a privatised organisation that all these community service obligations can survive. But there is even a wider issue than community service obligations.

BREAK.PARA: Because Telstra is a national network it operates a cross-subsidy to help, in particular, the non-metropolitan areas of Australia, Senator McGauran. Figures I have been given show that in rural areas of Australia the cost of providing a normal telephone service to ordinary Australians can vary considerably. I will use the electorate of Barker in my own state as an example. The member for Barker is the Defence minister in the new government. In Bordertown the annual access cost per line is $1,480. In Murray Bridge it is $460. In Naracoorte it is $1,650. In Kangaroo Island it is $2,360.

You cannot convince me, and you will not be able to convince the Australian public, that when you privatise Telstra and allow it to be purely market driven it will not go down the list and say, `We are not going to subsidise and lose money on providing these rural services in these areas. We have to make a quid for our shareholders.' Therefore the cost will start going up. Telstra will start changing the rates to recoup those cost subsidies from those areas. You will not be able to even out the profit, even out the national network, to have some informal cross‐subsidisation. Again, as sure as day follows night, the price will be jacked up.

Senator McGauran, I will give an example from your own state of Victoria. In the Bendigo electorate, in Charlton it costs $900 for an annual excess cost. In Bendigo it is $480. In Maryborough it is $550. Again, the smaller the town, the more remote, the bigger the access cost, the bigger a privatised Telstra will start charging to provide that telephone service. These issues have not been addressed, and no matter how you write the legislation you will not be able to protect the ordinary citizen that you are supposed to represent, Senator McGauran—those people living in rural and regional areas.

PARA.BREAK: At the last election, we lost a lot of regional seats in Australia, make no bones about that. We got done like a dinner. I accept the result without argument: the result is there. If you are mad enough to continue with the privatisation of Telstra, and these people start having to pay something extra to maintain a normal telephone service because this infor mal cross‐subsidy ends—not the official community service obligation—then we are going to win back a lot of those seats very rapidly because people are not going to pay those sorts of fees.

BREAK.PARA: You won a seat called Bass back at the last election. On Flinders Island in the electorate of Bass, the cost of annual access per line is $4,900. I want the new member, Mr Warwick Smith, former ombudsman for telecommunications, to go and tell his new electors, `We cannot guarantee that that informal cross‐subsidy is going to continue on Flinders Island.' And he will not be able to continue that cross‐subsidy under privatisation.

These are the issues. These are the reasons that this opposition will use every power it has in the Senate to vote down the privatisation of Telstra. We said all through the election campaign that if we had the numbers with other minority parties in the Senate, we would use them to stop the privatisation of Telstra. Because of the voting system in the Senate, that is how the votes turned out.

I find it a bit strange that some now‐government members are whingeing about the Senate system, when for 13 years they wallowed in it like fat pigs in a big trough, saying, `Isn't the Senate wonderful? We can thwart the government of the day, the Labor government, in many of its measures'. We said clearly to the people that if we have a majority in the Senate, with the minor parties, we will oppose the legislation and defeat it. And we will defeat it even under the threat of a double dissolution.

I cannot imagine a more interesting campaign, as shadow minister for communications, than to go these rural and regional areas and tell them that if the coalition won a double dissolution, and got the bill through in a joint sitting, then on Flinders Island, the cost per telephone service would be $4,900. There would be no way that those people would not have their charges put up. I would love to campaign all around Australia on a double dissolution bill on the privatisation of Telstra. The Labor Party will not run. We will not buckle at the knees under the threat of a double dissolution. We would welcome it on this issue and, if the Government wants to take us on, we have been around a hundred‐plus years on these issues and we will be around to fight you.

I conclude with a couple of other remarks about the Governor‐General's speech. Yesterday, the Governor‐General quite rightly mentioned in his opening remarks the terrible tragedy in Tasmania and all of us in the parliament have shown how appalled we felt at this unbelievable occurrence. People are asking what can we do to stop it. I want to be blunt about this. Clearly, national and state parliaments in Australia have to take action to ban public access to these sorts of weapons.

Tasmania has the loosest gun laws existing in Australia. People there are able to buy automatic and semi‐automatic rifles. There have been stories in the press in the last few days about that. Let us be blunt about it, unfortunately, Tasmania has reaped what it has sown by not carrying out decent, reasonable legislation to restrict access to these weapons.

In a letter to the editor the other day, someone quite rightly pointed out that even if this man was mad, if he had turned up with a meat cleaver, a knife or a baseball bat, instead of an automatic rifle, he may have killed only one or two people before he was stopped. But because he had access to an automatic rifle, he killed 35 people and wounded another 15. It was the fact that he had access to an automatic rifle that led to the killing of so many people.

The argument that we hear from the Shooters Party, and its ilk, that it is not the guns that kill people, it is the people themselves, is a fallacious argument. I say quite bluntly in this place that I hope that John Tingle, who is a member of parliament for the Shooters Party in New South Wales, recognises what his party has wrought on Australia by following these policies. I think that that party, and the lobby groups that it represents, have to take some responsibility for conducting a political campaign to intimidate politicians so that they cannot carry out suitable and proper reform of the gun laws of this country. I believe that the people of Australia are now asking all state and federal politicians to do something about it. If the states do not take appropriate, reasonable action, then the Australian parliament should, even if it needs a referendum to do it, to ensure that there are decent, tight gun control laws in Australia so that the dreadful events last Sunday at Port Arthur in Tasmania do not occur again.

If we think this is an issue we can avoid, just listen to the remarks of the relatives of the victims. All of them are asking why this happened and what do we have to do. Listen to the heartfelt appeals of those relatives, particularly the father who lost his wife and two daughters, questioning how someone could get an automatic rifle and kill his family. That is a question that all parliamentarians in Australia have to answer.

One last point I will make is that in this very mediocre Governor‐General's speech on behalf of the new government, a speech lacking vision, substance, and any indication of what sort of Australia we should have, there was one interesting proposal which is, of course, to establish a constitutional convention to talk about the issue of the republic and related matters. I hope that when we get the detail of that, we can see that it is a fair dinkum convention which can debate the issue. I know, Mr Acting Deputy President, that you, personally, will be keen to participate in such a convention, because you are one of those from the Liberal Party who stood up and said quite loudly that you wanted an Australian head of state, and I congratulate you for that.

Another remark I want to speak about concerns legislation to protect the Australian flag.
