I find it a bit extraordinary, in one sense, that we have legislation to indicate that this flag can be changed only by a referendum or a plebiscite. You cannot do it by referendum because it is not written in the constitution. That is fine in one sense, but I wish Mr Howard had pointed out that, when the law went through to establish the present flag of Australia in the early 1950s, it was done by legislation. There was no consultation with the people of Australia. It was done by an act of parliament. Sir Robert Menzies introduced it. It went through with the support of the then opposition, but there was no consultation with the people of Australia. Suddenly we are told that though Bob Menzies could change the flag in 1953 or 1954 without consultation—

TALK.START.PARA: —What did he change it from?

—He changed it from being the red background to the blue background. That was a significant change. The flag has changed several times since 1901. I remember very clearly a painting done from an account of our troops at Anzac Cove. The flag flying over Anzac Cove was not the current flag. It was a flag with a red background, not a blue background. The soldiers who fought so courageously at Anzac Cove fought either under the Union Jack or under a flag that had a red background.

BREAK.PARA: When you look at many of the photographs taken during the Second World War showing the places where our soldiers fought, the soldiers either fought under the Union Jack—and my father certainly did as a serviceman in the Royal Australian Air Force in the Middle East—or under an Australian flag that had a red background. Those things were changed by an act of parliament. The flag was not changed by a plebiscite. While I do not in any way disagree that if there is going to be a change to the Australian flag there should be some form of plebiscite, I do not want to hear the hypocrisy of the government saying that it has always been done this way.

We should also remember that the present flag was basically designed with the Union Jack in the corner—whatever colour background—with clear rules to say that it must have the Union Jack on it because in 1901 we still saw ourselves as part of the British Empire, an empire that has long since gone into history. (Time expired)

DEBATE.TITLE: HAZARDOUS WASTE (REGULATION OF EXPORTS AND IMPORTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Hill)—by leave—agreed to:
That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act to amend the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1989.
Motion (by Senator Hill) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

The purpose of this bill is to amend the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1989 to ensure that Australia can discharge its obligations under international instruments relating to the control of transboundary movements of hazardous waste.

The Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill 1995 was introduced to the Senate by the former government on 29 June 1995. At the time of introduction, a small number of issues regarding the amendment of the principal act were still unresolved. In order that the progress of the bill not be impeded, it was agreed that these matters would be further discussed after lodgement, and any necessary changes achieved by government amendment. As a result of subsequent consultation, a number of amendments were proposed and formed part of the bill on which debate was commenced and adjourned on the last day of the Spring sittings on 1 December 1995. This government notes that the consolidated bill represents the subject of exhaustive discussions with all interested parties. The package addresses the need to give effect to the relevant international agreements, and also satisfies industry's need for both certainty and flexibility. After careful consideration of the consolidated bill, the government, which supported the bill when it was debated last year, has decided to reintroduce it without further amendment.

The principal act was passed at the time that the Basel Convention was negotiated. At that time the major concern regarding trade in hazardous waste related to hazardous waste sent to another country for what is termed final disposal, that is for incineration, landfilling or the like. As a result, the principal act defines waste as material which has been rejected as worthless or otherwise falls within the ordinary definition of waste. As such it generally does not cover material sent for recovery. In the years since the convention was negotiated the emphasis in international debate has shifted to its coverage of materials which are traded for recovery operations; that is, for reclamation of metals or recovery of other useful materials.

Just as the trade in hazardous waste for final disposal led to an active process of transferring the environmental costs associated with the generation of hazardous waste from one country to another, and in particular from developed to developing countries, so the trade in hazardous waste for recovery operations can similarly lead to the transfer of environmental costs in an uncontrolled fashion. The Basel Convention was drafted to cover both kinds of processes, that is both final disposal and recovery operations, and both kinds of processes are included in the convention definitions under the single term "disposal". The Australian act does not cover a wide range of hazardous wastes from which valuable materials are to be recovered; these hazardous wastes have not been rejected as worthless or do not fall within the ordinary meaning of waste. The major purpose of amending the act is to remedy this discrepancy between our international obligations and our domestic legislation.

The Basel Convention is the primary international instrument under which trade in hazardous waste is controlled. It is the set of rules for this trade on which Australia and the many other countries which are parties to the convention have agreed. As virtually all of Australia's trading partners are either parties to the convention or parties to similar sets of rules established by the OECD, it is in Australia's trade interests, as well as within our international obligations, to abide by these rules. The interpretation of the convention as expressed in the principal act and with the amendments now put forward is in line with the views of other parties to the convention. In the absence of these amendments, Australia will continue to be out of step with other Parties in its capacity to give domestic effect to the convention.

In accordance with the primary intention of the bill, the object of the act is to be amended to make it clear that one of its major aims is to give domestic effect to the Basel Convention and other international instruments relating to trade in hazardous wastes.

The definition of hazardous waste now to be adopted is aligned with that in the convention. This will ensure that in future Australia does not find itself in breach of the convention by virtue of having adopted a definition which is at odds with the interpretation of the convention followed by others. Nevertheless, the question of definition remains central to the operation of the act, and indeed definitional questions remain the subject of very active debate in Basel Convention meetings. In Australia, a high degree of concern has been expressed because of the uncertainty of the definitions in the convention. The bill addresses these concerns through the establishment of a process to provide greater practical certainty regarding what is and is not a hazardous waste. The bill provides for the establishment of a Technical Group of scientific and technical experts who will advise the Minister on definitional questions. The advice of this group will be of great benefit in enabling the Minister to decide whether he or she believes that a material falls within the definition of hazardous waste and so is regulated.

The Minister will have the power to issue Evidentiary Certificates which will be prima facie evidence that a given material is or is not a hazardous waste; and by compiling a list of materials for which Evidentiary Certificates have been issued, the Minister will be able to provide greater certainty to those subject to regulation on what materials will be controlled and what will not. This means for example, that it will be possible to issue an Evidentiary Certificate stating that a material such as clean ferrous scrap is not a hazardous waste subject to the act and can be traded without any controls. At the same time, flexibility will be retained to respond to incremental progress in international discussions on what materials should and should not be controlled. As an example, recent international discussions suggest that the existence of internationally recognised product specifications will be influential in deciding what are and are not hazardous wastes. The Evidentiary Certificates will not be conclusive, but will be prima facie evidence; and the definitions in the act would remain as the final means of determining the definitional question. In practice, however, the advice of the Technical Group will provide the government with the capability of issuing clear guidance on definitional issues, and should satisfy the needs of those who are subject to regulation for a clear understanding of their obligations under the act.

There are many who would prefer to replace the uncertain Basel definitions with Australia's own list or set of criteria. To follow that course, however, would inevitably lead to Australia once again being at odds with the convention and the views of trading partners on what constitutes hazardous waste under the convention. This would risk not only breach of our international obligations but could well lead to shipments acceptable under our definitions being rejected at foreign ports, to the embarrassment, cost and inconvenience of all.

The convention itself recognises that the hazard criteria it establishes are in need of further development. There is provision for the development of national tests which would provide greater precision in determining whether a waste is hazardous. That provision is included in the relevant Annex to the convention, by reference to which the bill defines hazardous waste. Over time the Technical Group will advise on national tests to establish hazard on a more certain basis, taking account of international developments.

Another key concept in the convention now adopted into the act is the definition of "environmentally sound management". The convention requires not only that an exporting country obtain prior consent from the country of import before allowing the transboundary movement to proceed, but also that the country of export require that the waste to be shipped is managed in an environmentally sound way in the country of import. The concept of environmentally sound management of hazardous waste is defined in the convention as "taking all practicable steps" to ensure that the hazardous waste is managed to protect human health and the environment. The Technical Group will advise the Minister to assist in determination of what constitutes environmentally sound management and whether particular facilities or processes meet the definition. For that reason, it will include people with expertise in scientific and technical, social and economic, environmental and public health fields.

The concept of environmentally sound management as set out in the convention replaces the phrase in the principal act "dispose of safely". In the principal act "dispose of safely" is defined in terms of an outcome, that is hazardous waste is disposed of safely provided there is no damage to human health or environment. By contrast, "environmentally sound management" is defined by reference to a process, that is, "taking all practicable steps" to prevent damage to human health or the environment. On the other hand, he definition of "dispose of safely" appears to exclude any assessment of effluents and emissions from the disposal process. In practice, pragmatic considerations are likely to prevail. Within the Basel Convention process detailed guidelines on what constitutes environmentally sound management have already been drafted, and these will provide the context for the Technical Group's advice to the Minister. Australia will put its efforts into ensuring that those guidelines are sound. Once again, the need to ensure that our legislation is fully in line with our international obligations is the overriding consideration in the changes set out in the bill.

Under the convention the general rule is that Parties must not trade in hazardous waste with non-Parties. An exception to this is provided for in Article 11, whereby Parties may enter into agreements or arrangements either with other Parties or with non-Parties. These agreements or arrangements can set out controls which are different from those prescribed by the convention itself, provided those controls do not reduce the level of environment protection intended by the convention. The main such agreement to which Australia is a party is the OECD Decision on Transboundary Movement of Hazardous Waste Destined for Recovery Operations (the OECD Decision), which regulates transboundary movement of hazardous wastes among OECD countries.

The bill provides explicitly for regulations giving effect to such agreements and arrangements, and for those regulations to give domestic effect to rules different from those in the convention. The materials covered by the agreements or arrangements may also differ to some extent from those covered by the convention. Thus the OECD Decision covers some wastes which are not hazardous wastes under the convention and trade in these must comply with the controls set out by the Decision; conversely, the Decision classifies some materials as non-hazardous waste (the OECD Green List) and these materials may be traded without a permit provided countries outside the OECD are not involved. The provisions are general and can be applied to any further Article 11 agreements or arrangements which Australia enters into.

The procedures by which the Minister reaches a decision on whether or not a permit should be issued for a transboundary movement have been amended, once again to bring the act more closely into line with the convention. Among the changes are those ensuring that the notification and consent procedures established by the convention are followed. Another amends the existing provision that the Minister have regard to the prospect of processing hazardous waste within Australia rather than allowing export to take place. This is in accordance with Article 4(2)(d) of the convention which requires parties to "minimise the transboundary movement of hazardous waste

consistent with the environmentally sound and efficient management of hazardous waste". The intent of this Article is met by requirements that disposal in Australia must be both efficient and environmentally sound. The intent is that a local disposal facility must be more than merely an experimental or test facility, and must operate on a commercial basis. There must be some cost effectiveness factor which is brought to bear when the Minister weighs up the pros and cons of local versus overseas disposal in deciding whether or not a permit should be issued.

The principal act already provides that there must be appropriate insurance for shipments of hazardous waste before a permit is issued. A new provision in the bill allows the Minister to require bonds or guarantees in addition to, or instead of, insurance. This recognises that where there is contravention of a permit, for one reason or other an insurance policy may not be paid out, and in an appropriate case a bond would allow the Commonwealth to ensure that there was some coverage. In other cases insurance may not be available, and a guarantee would provide the opportunity for a permit to be issued in such cases. The principal act allows the sum total of such arrangements (insurance, bonds, and guarantees) to be assessed when the Minister comes to a decision.

Other procedural amendments are aimed at ensuring that the administration of the act proceeds smoothly and efficiently, and that all convention requirements are met. Because the convention itself contains detailed rules, it has not been possible to simplify the administrative system beyond a certain point. That is why both the principal act and the amending bill are complex. Where possible and appropriate, provision is made for the making of regulations to set out requirements under the act, in order to ensure that its administration will be flexible and responsive to the needs of industry. A detailed set of administrative procedures is being developed in consultation with interested parties, including industry, and will be complete by the time the amendments are ready to come into force.

The act also addresses a number of aspects of the convention which were not picked up in the original drafting process. One of the most important of these is the issue of transit permits, that is for Australian consent (or its denial) to the transiting of waste from another country on its way to a third country for disposal.

There is also explicit provision for more than one shipment of the same hazardous waste to be covered by a single permit. The convention allows such a procedure up to a maximum of 12 months, provided that certain conditions are met and that is now reflected in the bill.

The current system for recovery of the government's administrative costs in respect of issuing permits is unnecessarily inflexible. The bill provides for fees to be set in regulations on the basis of administrative costs of each type of permit. The Minister has discretion to reduce fees where appropriate. The fee level may not be above the fee currently prescribed in the principal act.

Penalties under the act have been increased in order to provide a deterrent to illegal traffic. Prevention of illegal traffic is specifically required by the convention, and the value of some of the transactions involved requires that penalties be raised to ensure that companies are deterred from failing to comply with the act's requirements. A new provision is that executive officers of companies will be personally liable for contraventions by companies, with the onus of proof resting with the Commonwealth—that is, liability will not be automatic. Liability for executive officers of companies is an important step in ensuring compliance with the act, as it would be difficult for other compliance measures to be effective—for example, identification of hazardous wastes at the Customs barrier when materials leave the country would often be difficult given that hazardous waste cannot readily be distinguished from a variety of other materials.

Third party standing under the principal act is already very broad with respect to appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Standing under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 has been extended by providing standing for Australian organisations and associations which have matters which relate to the act as part of their object or purpose. This will provide further legislative clarity to the standing rules for the purposes of the ADJR Act and is an extension of the standing rules already recognised in recent cases under other similar legislation. The standing provisions in the bill relate only to persons or organisations living or incorporated in Australia.

The bill has been the subject of extensive consultations with a variety of groups both inside and outside government. In particular, detailed consultations have been held with a Policy Reference Group made up of representatives of industry, environment groups, development and co-operation groups, and unions. State and territory governments have also been consulted. An exposure draft of the bill was provided to members of the Reference Group and to states and territories, and comments have been taken into account in finalising the bill. In the course of the consultations, an issue which has stimulated more discussion than any other is the prospect of bans of transboundary movement of hazardous wastes from developed to developing countries. This issue has been the subject of a decision at the Second Meeting of the Conference of Parties to the Basel Convention in March 1994 (Decision II/12) and an amendment decision at the Third Conference of Parties to the convention in September 1995 (Decision III/1). This latter decision, known as the Ban Amendment, implements an immediate ban on the export of hazardous waste for final disposal from countries listed in Annex VII of the convention (parties and other states which are members of the OECD and the EC, and Liechtenstein) to non-Annex VII countries; and phases out by the end of 1997 and bans from that date the export of hazardous waste for recovery operations from Annex VII countries to non-Annex VII countries. In it Explanation of Vote at that meeting, Australia said that ". . . it is essential Parties have a common understanding of what is prohibited", and indicated that it would "only consider ratifying the [ban] amendment when the work on hazardous characteristics is completed to (Australia's) satisfaction". (The work referred to is being carried out by the Basel Convention's Technical Working Group, and is aimed at clarifying the wastes covered by the convention.)

It is important to note that the bill does not implement the Ban Amendment. This government is yet to consider its position on ratification of the amendment, and before any decision is made on ratification, the government's new process for treaty-making must be observed.

The export of wastes for final disposal to developing countries, however, is not generally regarded as acceptable practice. That is now reflected in the bill. Indeed the bill extends that policy by limiting exports for final disposal to any country to exceptional circumstances, such as where there is a direct risk to human health or environment if the waste remains in Australia, or if the wastes are being exported for research or testing. Each permit issued under this provision of the amended act will be specified in the regulations to ensure that the application of the concept of "exceptional circumstances" is transparent and subject to scrutiny by the community.

The extension of the definition of hazardous waste from that in the principal act to that in the convention will inevitably result in regulation of a far wider range of hazardous wastes than at present. Studies which have been carried out recently into the range of wastes that may be covered by the Basel Convention and Australia's trade in them suggests that total trade may be somewhere between $100 million and $200 million each year. The vast majority of this takes place with OECD countries, and is therefore subject to the less rigid controls set out by the OECD Decision. The kinds of materials in which we trade with developing countries of our region include spent lead acid batteries, metal-bearing wastes such as sludges, slags and drosses and a miscellaneous range of wastes variously containing metals such as lead or arsenic. These are the kinds of materials which will be regulated under the amended act. Suggestions that ferrous and most non-ferrous scrap metal will be caught up under the convention are mistaken.

In general, the amended act will not cover trade in products, mineral ores and concentrates, processed minerals and metals, petroleum products, forest products including uncontaminated waste paper, textiles, or materials produced to meet commercial specifications intended for recycling. The distinction between wastes on the one hand, and non-wastes on the other, will be subject to consideration and advice by the Technical Group, and will exclude co-products, intermediates and by-products from the definition of hazardous wastes. The Technical Group will also be giving priority to assisting the Minister in determining which of the OECD green listed materials are clearly inside the scope of the act and which are clearly outside it, with a view to the Minister's reflecting this in Evidentiary Certificates. Consultations with all interested parties will continue as regulations and supporting administrative arrangements are developed.

Bilateral discussions between Australia and our developing-country trading partners make it clear that they wish and expect Australia to abide by the rules to which so many of the countries of the world have agreed. A continued failure to do so may lead to retaliatory reaction by these countries, which could threaten trade far more seriously than the controls required by the convention and now established by this bill. It is time for Australia to give effect to the obligations it has taken upon itself, just as the vast majority of its trading partners have done.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of the bill be adjourned until the first day of the spring sittings 1996, in accordance with the order agreed to on 29 November 1994.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Stott Despoja, I remind honourable senators that this is her first speech and I ask that the usual courtesies be extended to her. I call Senator Stott Despoja.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this chamber today as the youngest woman ever elected to a federal parliament. It is an honour that I cherish but for no longer than it takes other young women to be chosen by an electorate that has shown it wants true representation of all sectors of our population. I look forward to the day when I look across this chamber from my seat and see such a diversity of faces—young people, old people, different ages, men and women, and the many cultures that make up our nation, including indigenous cultures—that we no longer have to strive for it. When that time comes I think we will accept that neither youth nor age, any more than being male or female, black or white, is a virtue in itself, except that it deserves to be represented in a system that claims to be representative.

SPEECH.PARA: Accepting and including difference with tolerance and respect is what Australia has shown herself to be all about, and I think we are all proud of that. I hope you will consider that what I have to offer is worthy of this great chamber and that what I have to say is of more interest than my footwear, which the media seems to notice so frequently. The truth is that last year I was given very big shoes to fill when I replaced former Senator John Coulter after he retired due to ill-health. I am pleased to say that Dr Coulter is in the gallery today, looking much more robust after surgery. In fact, I served only two days in this place before the federal election when the electors of South Australia showed great confidence in my party, giving me a quota in my own right and saving me from the fate of being the shortest serving senator.

John Coulter's eight years in this parliament will be remembered for many things: his negotiation of the ethanol package, his time as leader during a period of consolidation for the Australian Democrats, his staunch defence of public funding for the CSIRO and his commitment to research and development. He remains one of Australia's most committed environmentalists and I look forward to continuing his work, be it fighting for an end to uranium mining and its export, reforming our constitution to include an environmental power, or highlighting our threatened species, a cause many of you will have become more familiar with over the Easter break—that is, assuming your chocolate bilby made it through staff security checks.

I thank John for his wisdom and his support. It was during his time as leader that he took a chance by employing me as a researcher. I was very young, but fresh from campus and fuelled by a desire for social reform. I was given responsibility for the education, training and youth portfolios, areas dear to my heart and ones I also gladly act as the spokesperson for today. It was through this work that I discovered not only the wonders of this chamber but the many opportunities there are to effect change through the parliament and law making.

We live in a time where legislation is greatly affecting destinies. Equal opportunity legislation and sex discrimination laws have changed lives for the better without dampening the fierce individualism that Australians wish to maintain. I think the native title package has the potential to go the same way towards righting institutionalised and ancient wrongs in the relations between indigenous and non-indigenous Australians. It seems natural to me to want to be a part of this process—one that puts into laws the nation's best aspirations of fairness and decency and also fosters decent dealings between people. Some of the best, if not all, changes for the better in Australian society have been initiated or supported by laws of this parliament.

I should say that at this time of national grief and overwhelming loss of life in Tasmania, Australians need no reminding that the first duty of government is to maintain and secure public safety. Whatever we considered the major issues to be in advance of this session, I think what happened on Sunday afternoon in Port Arthur must change our priorities. We must ensure that any legislative powers we have and all our wisdom and will are used to prevent another such massacre. I express my deepest sympathies for all those suffering personal loss as a result of that dreadful event.

If I can speak at all for the youth of this country it is to say that we want to respect our institutions and our leaders and we want to pursue change that makes individuals free and able to pursue their hopes and dreams whatever their circumstances. We want respect for our land and sea, the rivers and sky of this great country. We want our environment cared for and protected. For this, too, we look towards legislation to draw all Australians into a shared determination that Australia shall be a healthy continent, its beauty and its life‐giving forces sustained forever.

This philosophy underpins the Australian Democrats. We are committed to the notion of intergenerational equity—the notion that we have a responsibility to promote fairness not only within current generations but between one generation and the next. It is this concept of ecological sustainability, combined with the Democrats' commitment to social justice and democracy, that made me join a political party. I bring to the parliament the values of that party and values that have been formed in the late 20th century, an education enhanced or limited by decisions made in this parliament and the experiences of a peer group and my parents, which reflect contemporary challenges.

I am part of a multicultural generation, born in Adelaide to Shirley Stott and Mario Despoja, hence my name. I have spent nearly all my life in the state that I represent, apart from a brief period in Canberra when I attended Canberra Boys Grammar as part of a co-educational experiment. That the school is boys only today suggests that the experiment failed.

TALK.START.PARA: —No-one else could do that.

—It has not dampened my enthusiasm for taking on male‐dominated institutions based in Canberra. My mother is my enduring role model. She took on the male‐dominated institution of journalism while raising two children. It is her experiences that have given me insight to the many problems that face single mothers in our community, just as her severe deafness has taught me literally to speak up. On that note, I would like to acknowledge that we have a hearing loop system here for people who are hearing impaired. I hope we do not have to wait too long before our parliamentary broadcasts of question time are subtitled so that we can actually make the workings of parliament more accessible to the 11 per cent of the population who are hearing impaired.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently I addressed a women's group that my mother had spoken to the year I was born, except in 1969 so appalled were some women at my mother's intention of being a working mother that they walked out in disgust, but not before predicting that her child would be a delinquent. I am not sure whether politics qualifies as delinquency, but it is a sign of progress that 26 years later her daughter can address that same women's group, as a member of the federal parliament, without too many forecasts of doom and gloom.

But we still have a long way to go in our society before women have equality with men. I am glad to say that South Australia has led the way in legislative reform for women. And, of course, I belong to a political party that has the best record when it comes to women's representation. Not only that, we have achieved what no‐one else has done, and that is elected a female leader, a tradition we have continued with the fine leadership of Senator Cheryl Kernot.

Even though my state may have been the first place in the entire world to grant women the right to vote and the right to stand for parliament in 1894, today only 20 per cent of our elected representatives to the federal parliament are women. In fact, Parliament House, as you all know, has a glass ceiling—literally, as if to emphasise this political difficulty for women.

I would like to pay tribute to my colleagues and acknowledge the presence in the gallery of my mother, my friends, family, party members, and staff members and also acknowledge the life‐long support of my brother Luke and my godmother Heather Duncan. A lot of people have supported and fostered my political involvement, beginning as it did in secondary school with involvement in the State Council of Students and International Youth Year activities. To paraphrase Sir Winston Churchill's advice to his son: politics is like piano playing; the earlier you start, the better.

My political awakening came as a student at the University of Adelaide. I am part of `Generation HECS', that group of graduates who have accumulated debt for no other reason that their decision to broaden their knowledge. One former minister, when he heard that I was the Australian Democrats' higher education spokesperson, and shadowing his portfolio area, said, `Trust me to get the former student activist.'

But I covet this portfolio, not simply as a former campus president, but as someone who is unshakeably committed to the belief that education is a right and that education, be it primary, secondary or tertiary, is a community resource.

In 1974 tertiary fees were abolished and that opened up our tertiary institutions, challenging their unspoken privilege and increasing access for traditionally under‐represented groups, such as women, disabled people, people from differed socio‐economic backgrounds, as well as Aboriginal and Islander people. But that legacy of the Whitlam era was under threat when I arrived on campus in the late 1980s. Policy changes by the federal government aligned education with economic objectives and students were designated consumers to justify the re‐imposition of fees in a new form—the higher education contribution scheme.

The Democrats were, and remain, the only party to recognise that the concept of students as consumers is a distortion. In undertaking their studies, students not only seek qualifications to assist with employment, but are also broadening their political, cultural and social horizons.

PARA.BREAK: Education offers empowerment. It is one way that individuals can affect their own destinies. And those people who protest against disincentives to education, such as fees and loans, should not be told simply to `get a job'. Nor should young people strug gling to find work in today's workforce be told by the media, or anyone else, to `get a haircut'.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, it is often said that some cultures have a special respect for the aged. I think our society has a special fear of the young. They are so often stigmatised as lazy, unappreciative of parents, easily lured to drugs, and uncaring about their country, their history and their language. I think we need to ask whether some people, perhaps no longer categorised as young, are allowing themselves to repeat atavistic fears that have no foundation in reality.

No group in society has been more consistently subject to structural change and its cruel and cutting edge, and for a longer period, than the young. I do not underestimate the pain of older workers whose jobs have disappeared nor devalue the struggle of women to find their role in the work force, but often young people feel defeated before they even start out and, as they experience the hardship of disappearing jobs, they are derided as dole bludgers and layabouts.

For four years I have conducted the Democrats' Youth Poll, the only survey by a political party that gives young people a chance to express their views on a range of topics—employment, education, sex, drugs and rock `n roll. The Youth Poll paints a very different picture of young Australians. It shows a very caring generation—caring about employment prospects and concerned about their families and teenage suicide levels. They are anxious to be a part of decision making processes and determined—absolutely determined—to ensure that the environment is not further degraded. Perhaps even the vilified Paxton young people care more about the big picture—the nation, their future—than some media will ever allow us to know.

However, it is true that young people show disdain for politicians and are cynical about the political process. The Youth Poll shows that only 1.5 per cent of young people trust us. Research may show that a majority of young people do not know that we have a constitution or believe that Jim Bolger is a professional surfer, but our own Senate standing committee reports into active citizenship reveal that over 80 per cent of secondary school students want to know more about the electoral and political processes.

Civics education will go some way towards addressing this but we have a responsibility. We have to ensure that young people's issues are addressed and that they are drawn into this process, the process that so affects their destinies.

The priority for any government must be the creation of jobs for young Australians— long‐term, sustainable jobs—not the `McJobs' that Douglas Coupland talks about in Generation X, which he defines as `low‐skilled, low‐valued and low‐paid jobs'.

Employment growth needs a healthy economy, but an economy cannot stay healthy in the long term without us making sure that we use our national assets—our environment, our savings—in a sustainable way. We must link employment creation with environmental protection, something the Democrats have long recognised. We have pushed for a long time for jobs in sustainable and future industries, such as high technology fields, value‐added manufacturing, and the fast‐growing environmental industries. This will ensure continuing quality of life, both now and extending to all future generations of Australians.

It is an exciting time to be a member of the federal parliament as we debate questions central to our nation's future and to how we will be seen in the next millennium. As co-chair of the South Australian Republican Movement, I look forward to being part of a movement that involves all Australians in its discourse, especially those who are among the strongest supporters of the move to a republic—young people. The republican debate also offers us the opportunity to assess our democratic institutions and their fitness.

We can afford to feel proud of the fact that we live in one of the longest continuous democracies in the western world. But this does not mean we should not seek to update or review our democratic systems. We should reform our constitution to reflect contemporary challenges, to recognise prior ownership, to refer to Australia's natural and geographic heritage and to enshrine in all states the bicameral system of parliament.

BREAK.PARA: Increasingly, Australians look to the upper house as a check on executive power, just as they rely on the Democrats as their parliamentary watchdog. Our role is about much more than ensuring accountability. The role of the Senate is not only to keep the government honest but also to give the government a few ideas as well. The role of this chamber has changed over time. We no longer operate as a states house but have refined our responsibility as a genuine and deliberate house of review, a house in which I think the views of the populace are more fairly reflected and represented. This role will no doubt come under the spotlight in the coming long months and will confirm what many of us here already believe—especially Democrats: that the real action takes place on the red leather benches. I am honoured to take my place on these benches today and I thank honourable senators for their indulgence.

I hope that before I leave this place young people will no longer be unrepresented in this chamber or in the other place. I hope that I can make a contribution to help bring that about. I am aware of how big an aim this is and how modest the talents I bring, but if hard work can do it then I shall make that contribution. Thank you.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I start by congratulating Senator Stott Despoja on a most interesting and obviously well researched first speech. I say in passing that some of the despair she exudes for young people is really a result of the last decade or so of Labor rule. A lot of that despair arises from the inability of young people to obtain employment. Under a new government I look forward to a situation where young people are able to get employment in much the same way as I was able to when I left school. When I left school—I was young once—I was able to choose between four jobs that were offered to me. That is the sort of thing that has been unheard of for 11 or so years of Labor mismanagement. I am sure that under the new government young people will again have a hope for the future and will be able to obtain meaningful and rewarding employment.

BREAK.PARA: The address by His Excellency the Governor‐General yesterday sets out a blueprint for Australia's advancement, a direction that the Liberal Party has been working towards in the past decade and one which quite obviously the majority of Australians enthusiastically share. The mandate given to the Liberal Party and the coalition generally indicates that Australians want a change—a change for the better. The Governor-General's speech set out the change that the new government will be bringing to Australia's direction.

Various minor politicians and so-called political experts and commentators have been arguing about mandates. But the facts are quite clear. At the most recent opportunity that the people had to express their choice of parliamentarians and policies, they elected the coalition with an absolute majority of 45 seats in the lower house, the House of Representatives, and, significantly, with 50 per cent of senators. I emphasise that when people talk about the role of the Senate and whether mandates have or have not been given. At the last election, 50 per cent of elected senators were from the Liberal and National parties. In each state, the Liberal Party achieved three senators, except in New South Wales and Queensland where the National Party achieved one each to join two Liberals. The Senate result in Queensland was the best ever result for the Liberal Party with, for the very first time in a genuine three‐party state, the Liberal Senate team achieving more votes than any other party.

In a passing reference, I want to dispel some of the inaccurate statements made by the Democrats and, curiously, most of the media. The Democrats did not achieve in Queensland a quota in their own right and had to again rely on—surprise of all surprises—the preferences of the Labor Party to get their candidate elected. So there we go again. The Labor Party were supporting their mates. At least they are all sitting together on the other side now. The Labor Party ensured the election of a Democrat candidate who could not get a quota in her own right. I am happy to say that the Democrat candidate just pipped the third Liberal candidate, Ms Debbie Kember, who would have been and who will be at some time in the future an excellent representative in this chamber.

But it should also be pointed out that, in spite of comments about the huge increases and gains made by the Democrats, the Democrat candidate this time received much the same sort of vote as she received six years ago, so there has been no increase in Democrat support in Queensland. The Democrat candidate again had to rely on Labor Party support to get herself elected.

The Liberal Party and the coalition were given an overwhelming mandate and support quite unprecedented in Australia's political history. In Queensland we have a situation where only two of 26 seats are now held by the Labor Party. Two out of 26—they still do hold two—are held by the Labor Party. I want to welcome to parliament for their contribution to Australia's direction the 10 new Liberal members from Queensland.

I am particularly pleased to record that Australia's northernmost electorate and the electorate perhaps furthermost from Canberra—one which borders our closest neighbouring nation—is now for the very first time firmly in the hands of the Liberal Party with the election of Mr Warren Entsch to the electorate of Leichhardt. Following the magnificent win in the state election by Lyn Warwick in Barron River, the Liberal Party has really consolidated its position in northern and regional Australia. In the electorate of Herbert my good friend and now colleague, former Townsville city councillor Peter Lindsay, swept the floor in what was previously a traditional Labor seat, particularly since the boundaries have now contracted to encompass basically just the cities of Townsville and Thuringowa.

On election night it was not even exciting in Townsville. From the very first booth that came in it was quite clear that Peter Lindsay had won a remarkable victory. This follows the stunning win by the Liberal Party in the Mundingburra by‐election that is now part of Australia's political history and which has elevated my friend and colleague, Frank Tanti, to being one of the most recognised politicians in Australia. I am pleased that my faith in Frank Tanti, starting in the days when he ran in an unwinnable Labor ward in the city council election—and lost it by only 89 votes, I might add—has been justified.

My 10 year goal to turn the north of Australia into a Liberal bastion has at last started to show dividends. When I first entered parliament six years ago I was the only Liberal north of the Brisbane suburb of Aspley in either the state or federal parliament. Queensland, unlike most other states, is a very decentralised state with a great number of federal and state electorates north of the capital city. It is a matter of some pride to me—and, I must say, relief as I now have four colleagues to do the state and federal work which previously fell to my office—that there are now four other Liberal parliamentarians in the north. This is not said just because of pride in the political party to which I belong; it is said more in the knowledge that these members are members of a party that supports initiative and enterprise, that believes in freedom and choice; a party in which they will give representation both as part of a Liberal government and as individuals, to the constituents it serves.

It is impossible for me in the short time available to mention my regard for my new colleagues who have joined us in this place representing my state. I should, however, mention that Peter Slipper's win was quite remarkable and well justified. The wins by Andrea West, Teresa Gambaro, Elizabeth Grace—all in difficult seats—Kay Elson and the return of Kathy Sullivan—the latter two in the Gold Coast region—show that the Liberal Party is a party of equality where people advance and achieve success because of their abilities, not because of their gender. In fact, all four new Liberal female members defeated very high profile ministers and office holders in the previous government.

I am also more than delighted to see joining us in parliament as well my good friends Graeme McDougall, previously with a magnificent track record as a councillor in the Brisbane City Council; Gary Hardgrave, a very capable young person with a great command of politics and government; and Tony Smith and Mal Brough, both young men of great enthusiasm and with real skills and experience that they will bring to this parliament. I am pleased to see them all joining us. To all my other colleagues who were re‐elected—Bill Taylor, Alex Somlyay, John Bradford and David Jull—my congratulations.

I should also congratulate those of my Queensland colleagues elevated to the ministry in the new government. I am particularly delighted to see John Moore in a senior position where he deserves to be. He is a man with so much talent who will make an enormous contribution to Australia's wellbeing, particularly in the business area. To me, John is the pathfinder for the Liberal Party in Queensland in recent times and the one who has brought the party from practical oblivion through to the success it now enjoys. His guidance, influence, encouragement and support has been quite magnificent.

I am also very pleased to see my Senate colleague and friend John Herron achieving portfolio ranking, taking on the difficult and at times contentious role that he has been allocated in the ministry. It is good to see Warwick Parer there in the ministry attending to things that he is very familiar with.

I should also at this time make reference to the very significant and little known contribution that the Queensland President of the Liberal Party, Bob Tucker, has made to the success of the party in the last couple of years. He, Jim Barron and his team at headquarters should be justifiably proud of the results they have achieved.

The new government has a huge task before it. For my area in the north of Australia those challenges are enormous and will require a great deal of consideration and understanding. The Liberal Party now holds more seats in rural and regional Australia than any other political party, holding 31 rural and regional seats to the National Party's 18, Labor's five and the Independents' two. I will ask leave later to incorporate in Hansard a statement regarding regional and rural representation in the parliament.

It is significant that, except in New South Wales, the Liberal Party now holds in every state the most rural and regional seats. It is essential that the support given to the Liberal Party in the election is reflected in government. I think that it is time to revisit a consumption tax similar to the goods and services tax proposed three years ago.
I acknowledge the honesty, courage and great contribution that John Hewson made to the debate. I only regret that John is not with us at the moment to be part of the new government of Australia.

For the north, which has a significant export focus, the introduction of a goods and services tax with its attendant exemption from tax on all imports into exports and business would be of real value.

Perhaps the one thing that makes me such a strong supporter of the GST is the impact that such a tax would have on petrol prices, which would benefit regional Australia tremendously. The reduction of excise from around 35c per litre to a GST of about 7c or 8c per litre, which would follow on from the introduction of a GST, would have an incalculably beneficial impact on rural and regional Australia, particularly in North Queensland, and would at last give regional Australia a chance to compete equally with those cousins of ours living in the most comfortable confines of the capital cities and in the golden triangle of Brisbane, Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra.

The implementation of a form of GST would have a very beneficial effect on the cost of business inputs, would increase Australia's competitiveness overseas and would lead to greater production and, therefore, greater employment. For a dynamic region like North Queensland all of these outcomes would be of significant benefit.

I am pleased to see that the government is, in accordance with its election promises, intending to introduce reform of the labour market, which will give Australian employees higher wages based on higher productivity within a framework of guaranteed minimum standards. I am also pleased to note that compulsory unionism will be abolished and effective sanctions against secondary boycotts will be restored.

In light of this move, I would like to think it is incumbent upon the sugar industry in Australia to revisit the closed shop deal between the AWU and the Queensland sugar industry which is in effect compulsory unionism within the sugar industry.

Our proposals to reduce the complexity and compliance costs of the taxation system, particularly in the capital gains tax and fringe benefits tax areas, will be welcomed particularly by small business on whom those taxes have a disproportionate impact.

The strengthening of work‐based training opportunities for young people through a modern apprenticeship and traineeship system will help provide real and meaningful jobs for young people and at the same time will ensure that Australia has a qualified and trained pool of workers in areas where there is a particular need. Older employed Australians will continue to have access to labour market programs, assistance and support services. I am pleased to see that regional and community employment councils will be formed bringing together business leaders, education and training providers and representatives of the wider community to more effectively link the training of unemployed people with real jobs and with a regional development focus.
I am also pleased to see that regional development will figure in projects designed to enhance employment opportunities in the regions of Australia.

There needs to be a real attack on youth unemployment, on the alienation of youth and particularly on youth suicide, which is tragically prevalent in rural areas. I am pleased to see the government's emphasis in this regard.

PARA.BREAK: I specifically note the government has made a strong commitment to equality of opportunity for all students in education. It is timely at this stage to reiterate the case accepted by the previous government after pressure from the then opposition that Queensland should receive a quantum of university places which would see my state reach the national average by 1998. I know there is opposition from southern states but Queensland is the only state to record an increase in the applications for higher education while in New South Wales and South Australia particularly con cern is expressed about the capacity of their institutions to meet Commonwealth targets.

BREAK.PARA: In attempting to bring Queensland up to parity with the national average, the Commonwealth target for 1998 was based on 88 places per 1,000 head of 17‐ to 34‐year‐old population. This target was based on population estimates for 1993 but the 1995 figure shows that the original estimates have been exceeded by about 29,000, of which Queensland accounts for more than half. If this trend continues, Queensland will still not catch up with the national average even with the additional places already promised. All additional places have been allocated in Queensland to regional areas, particularly the new campuses at Cairns and the Sunshine Coast and in others planned in Logan City, Ipswich and Hervey Bay. If, therefore, the Commonwealth government is obliged to cut higher education funding to meet Labor's black hole of $8 billion in the budget, that reduction should be achieved by an equal percentage reduction across all states, not by an arbitrary removal of the growth funding for Queensland.

In the Governor-General's speech, the government gave prominence to a factor that in the past has been conveniently overlooked by bureaucrats and legislators whose horizons never seem to extend beyond the leafy suburbs of Brisbane, Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra. The government very clearly recognises that the nation continues to depend on the natural human resources of rural and regional Australia for a major proportion of its wealth. It is therefore essential that government services continue to apply in these areas and that regional Australians are not, as they were under Labor, treated as second class citizens compared with those living in the capital cities.

The government's commitments to restore the nation's land and water resources infrastructure and enhanced primary industries by removing impediments to international competitiveness are welcomed and must be pursued vigorously.

I am pleased to see that Labor's ridiculous, illogical and insupportable three mines policy will be removed and that new mines will be approved subject to strict environmental, heritage and nuclear safeguards. I do not want to sound like having a bad case of `NIMBY' but at this stage I do want to flag my opposition to any uranium mining in the headwaters of the Burdekin River unless all of us who depend on its water are shown that there is no possibility of any impact on the quality of our water.

Our historic and comprehensive environment and sustainable agriculture programs will be of great significance to Australia. I have every confidence in the new Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill), who has already shown a refreshing change to the way environment matters will be handled. Senator Hill is prepared to consult and listen to the sensible arguments of all Australians and not be captive of any particular group. I congratulate Senator Hill on the work he is already doing in that regard and also on both his election and his appointment as Leader of the Government in the Senate. We are indeed fortunate in the Senate that that type of leadership is available, leadership that will ensure the proper and decorous workings of this chamber and the speedy progress of government business through the Senate.

I should also, in passing, pay tribute to the great work of my friend and colleague, Senator Rod Kemp, in guiding our environment policy through the election. I look forward to the resolution of the Labor government's politically motivated interference in the Queensland government's approval of a tourist facility at Cardwell. It is essential that our unique natural environment is available to all to experience and enjoy.

Tourism is Australia's fastest growing export industry. It attracted $10.6 billion in expenditure from foreign visitors in the 1993‐94 year, according to BTR, and another $36.3 billion from Australian residents. Tourism's share of domestic output is estimated at about 5.5 per cent. It employs directly 535,600 people, or about 6.9 per cent of the work force. Every effort must be made by the government to support this industry and to reverse current impediments on the industry's growth. Coming from North Queensland, which is the leading area as far as Australia's tourism is concerned, I know that the government's policies will enhance tourism and our export capacity in that regard in the years ahead.

North Queensland and generally northern Australia have a significant and special interest in both defence and trade. I urge the government to concentrate its defence preparedness in northern Australia. The defence forces situated in Townsville, Cairns and Darwin in particular are a great example of the professionalism of our armed forces and also bring a great sense of community and economic benefit to the areas in which they are located.

I am always conscious that those of us in the north live closer to the almost 200 million people in Indonesia than we do to the majority of Australians resident in the southern capitals. It is well recognised that Australia's future is in the north. Its proximity to the burgeoning markets of South-East Asia, particularly to Indonesia and Malaysia, means that trade will continue to have an important and ever expanding focus in the north.

Northern industry and exports have achieved great successes without the indirect and subtle assistance given to southern industries and exports. That success will continue. I urge the government not to be overwhelmed by the voices in the south for artificial support mechanisms for exports which naturally emanate from the north of Australia.

All Australians should have equality of opportunity. Divisions based on gender, race or colour should become a thing of the past in Australia under the new government. Unfortunately, the Labor government, despite what I will concede may have been its best intentions, has created the opposite impact. I look forward to ensuring that Aboriginal and Islander Australians have the same opportunities in health, education, housing and employment as all other Australians do.

As one who lives in a part of Australia where many Aboriginal and Islander people reside, and as one who has during the last six years spent a considerable amount of time in the Aboriginal and Islander communities, I look forward to the time when indigenous people are able to maintain their place and traditions in an Australia free from racial or social conflicts. In my days at school, Aboriginal and Islander people were treated as equals. I look forward to the day when this again occurs.

The Liberal Party has always maintained a commitment to the High Court's decision on native title. However, it is without question that the native title legislation, bullied through parliament by the Labor Party—more as a political exercise than for any other purpose—is quite unworkable. It will be a major achievement of this government when native title legislation is dealt with in a way which makes the High Court's decisions workable and fair to all concerned.

In accordance with its election promises, the Liberal and National parties will be considering constitutional reform through forums, discussions and consultations. I have always had the view that Australia will eventually become a republic but that it will do so under a Liberal government rather than under a Labor government. The Australian public would never trust Labor with any tampering with our current constitution. I believe that, under a more moderate, sensible and consultative government, the majority of Australians will have confidence that our new system of parliament will be one which maintains the best and, I might say, the most of our traditional form of government, but with some change perhaps to the head of state.

Whilst I suppose I could be classed as being mildly in the republican camp, I have no such equivocation about our flag. Our nation's flag is our nation's flag and must forever remain that. It must not be changed at the whim of any government to accord with what is trendy in the advertising or marketing arena at any particular era of our history. The government's proposals to ensure that the flag cannot be altered without the people's approval is a significant step. I am sure it will mean that our flag will remain forever.

I am very pleased to support the address‐in‐reply motion to the Governor‐General's speech moved by my colleague Senator Teague. The amendment moved by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) is a churlish one. It really deserves little comment in this debate, apart from saying—and re-emphasising—that our proposals in relation to Telstra were very clearly enunciated before the election.

TALK.START.PARA: —And they didn't like them; Australians didn't like them.

—They did like it, Senator Kernot. I have to explain to you again that we have a 45-seat majority in the lower house, and in the upper house we achieved an election of 50 per cent of the senators. Yet you choose not to listen to that. Fifty per cent of the senators were elected to the Liberal and National parties. That is significant thing to remember when people over the course of the next few weeks start rabbiting on—if I may use that phrase—about mandate.

BREAK.PARA: It is quite clear, as I mentioned and have again emphasised, that the Australian Democrats again are showing their involvement with the Labor Party. My colleague Senator Kernot, who is sitting in the chamber, should well be grateful to the Labor Party—it has been shown that she is—because she has been elected only on its preferences.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are wrong.

—That is correct. Have a look through them. I had a look through them before I came in, Senator Kernot. It is a pity that I do not have the results or I would table them. The full results from Queensland showed that Senator Kernot was getting there. She did not get a quota in her own right, but she was getting there—200 from all the odd groups on the left, 100 here, 100 there. But she was nowhere near the quota. What happened? The Labor Party kindly allocated all their preferences to Senator Kernot, and, bang, she was able to scrape into the sixth spot in Queensland.

BREAK.PARA: If you call that a mandate, if you call that anything except being part of the Labor Party group, then you deserve the sort of response that the Democrats received from the Australian public. They received a very low vote. As I mentioned, and again repeat, the vote that the Queensland candidate got in this election—

TALK.START.PARA: —It was the highest ever.

—Was much the same as you got six years ago, Senator Kernot. So much for your brilliant enlightened leadership. So much for the great support you brought to the Democrats. Your vote is within 0.3 per cent of what you got six years ago. If you call that a mandate, I do not know where you get your reasoning from.

BREAK.PARA: It is significant that in this election not only did we get that huge result in the lower house but in the Senate—and this has got to be emphasised—the Liberal and National parties got 50 per cent of the senators on a very clear and explicit policy. That is, I think you will concede, Madam Acting Deputy President, almost unprecedented in Senate elections around Australia. It has been a magnificent result for the Liberal and National parties in the Senate, a chamber where usually the vote goes everywhere. The Democrats, I think, lost one and gained one, but it was all at the expense of the Labor Party. The people of Australia quite clearly understand that it does not matter who you vote for. Whether you vote for the Democrats or Labor, it is all the same, because they have the same policies.

I should indulge myself in the last couple of minutes, if I can, by just pointing out the pettiness of the Democrats. Have a look at the Queensland card that they registered. Their preferences went to everyone except us, I might mention. They started at the top of the thing and went down. They went to 15, 16, 17. They got to the Nationals—it was Boswell. They got to 28, 29, 30. They got through them all and got to the Liberal Party. Then they counted from the bottom and went upwards. So I got the last vote and I am very proud of that. It is a badge of honour. The pettiness of it is just incredible. I am very pleased to announce that I am going to talk about that as often as I can. I shall wear that as a badge of courage. I thank Senator Kernot for letting me know that I point out the undeniable truth about her relationship with the Labor Party and that is that they are just part of the team. She does not like me saying it. She went to that pettiness to make sure that I got the absolutely last vote. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ian Macdonald's speech shows why he is on the backbench and why Prime Minister Howard has overlooked him. For six years in this chamber, we have heard nothing but bile and vitriol from you against the Australian Democrats. You did not even have the graciousness today to restrain this bile and vitriol straight after the first speech of our newest senator. Such is the level of it. Is this a reflection of the new parliamentary standards of the government? I see it as the same old business. I guess one day Senator Ian Macdonald's deep and dark psychological reasons for this pathological hatred of the Democrats, and me in particular, might be explained. But from day one, not knowing Senator Ian Macdonald before I came to this place—
—I hate to stop Senator Kernot in the midst of this very interesting speech—
—Oh, go ahead.
—Are you rising on a point of order, Senator Macdonald?
—What do you—
—Don't panic. I am desperately keen to hear your speech. I just want to confirm that I had leave to incorporate these documents.
—I did. I did say.
—There is no objection, but I do note that you did leave out the central coast of New South Wales.
—Would you like to do it at the end of Senator Kernot's speech, please, so that we do not disrupt her.

—We all know exactly why Senator Ian Macdonald rose at that time. I will just say it all again, Senator Ian Macdonald. One day, the deep and dark psychological reasons for your pathological hatred of the Australian Democrats, and me in particular, may be explained. It is absolutely a mystery to us. We did not know each other at all before we came into this chamber, and from day one we were subjected to what I think is totally based on ideological prejudice and never opening your ears to listen. How ever, one of the real highlights of the federal election campaign in Queensland for me was Senator Ian Macdonald's own example of `nimby': Cheryl Kernot, not in my backyard. He put out a press release saying that his mission, specially designated to him in the federal election campaign, was to eliminate Cheryl Kernot from the Senate. Well, Senator Ian Macdonald, you failed spectacularly. For the record, I got the highest ever Democrat vote in Queensland. However you want to distort it, I got the highest ever.
—Did you get a quota?
—No, I did not get a quota. I wish I had but I did not.
—How many quotas did you get?

—You know what it is like at the top of the ticket. You could not care less. Senator Macdonald, I think you should go and look at the preference distributions all around Australia and see that Democrats were elected substantially on green preferences, not Labor Party preferences. I wonder if you stopped to consider the way that Democrat preferences assisted the election of the Liberal Party candidate in Canning. Just don't be so selective. Don't let the facts get in the way of a good argument. You always overlook the Democrat practice—
—Of voting with the Labor Party.

—No, the Democrat practice of what we call split tickets where we have attempted to be as even‐handed to you as we have been to the Labor Party. I invite you to go back and look at every electorate. I wonder why, colleagues, through you, Madam Acting Deputy President, on the Liberal Party preference allocation, I was the only Democrat senator not to receive 100 per cent of Liberal Party preferences. I wonder if that had anything to do with Senator Ian Macdonald's physical presence in Queensland.
—I have no idea what you are talking about.
—I think you should go back and look, Senator Macdonald. Queensland was the only state where the Liberal Party did not give me as a Democrat 100 per cent of preferences in the Senate.
—We favoured the Greens.
—I don't care who you gave them to.
—A far better party than yours.
—And we spectacularly outpolled them, didn't we? Three to one, Senator Macdonald.
—Senator Kernot, would you like to address your remarks to the chair? It might reduce the number of interjections.

—I will try very hard. You must admit, Madam Acting Deputy President, that I have been very restrained for six years. But seeing that Senator Macdonald's mission in life was to eliminate me from the Senate spurred me on to achieve my highest ever vote in Queensland. So thank you, Senator Ian Macdonald. I just want to point out to Senator Macdonald: bad luck. I was elected, I am here for six years, I am not bitter and twisted, I am still the leader of the party and I bet I have a better time than you do on the back bench.
