SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I just ascertain that Senator Ian Macdonald has finished all of his interjections for the time being? Before I speak on the address-in-reply, two speeches ago in this chamber we heard the debut speech of Senator Stott Despoja of the Australian Democrats. On behalf of the opposition, as I am the first opposition speaker since that speech, I congratulate her on a very fine debut speech.

SPEECH.PARA: We observe the comments made, I thought uncharitably, by Senator Ian Macdonald following upon her address that the dispiriting nature of the youth view of Australia was due to the Australian Labor Party. In fact, I understood the senator to actually say that the young people of Australia had an inspiring view of the prospects of this country and that, in fact, they were pigeonholed into a caricature by the media, which had them as a drug-riddled, disinterested, unemployment prone group. But indeed, their view is much wider in the world.

Yesterday the Governor-General, Sir William Deane, opened the 38th parliament of Australia and delivered the opening address. The tradition is, of course, that in that address he presents an outline of the program for the coming three years of the government. I rise to speak in the address following that speech and to support the amendment moved by the Leader of the Opposition in this chamber, Senator Faulkner, on Telstra. I mean no disrespect to the Governor-General, but I do intend in my remarks this evening to criticise some of the aspects referred to in that speech as the government's program for the next three years.

Before turning to the speech, I say that it is the first appearance by the Governor-General as the Governor-General in this parliament. He was appointed to the position of Governor-General by the Keating government at the beginning of this year. I congratulate him on his elevation. I think Sir William has proven to be a thoughtful and distinguished member of the High Court and I believe he will fill the office of Governor-General with equal distinction. He is, in the view of all Australians I believe, an excellent choice.

In the last several months Australia has come through what I believe to be a quite extraordinary time. A government which, I think by fair measure, would be regarded as a successful government has been turned from office at a time when the Australian economy is buoyant and where the prospects, particularly for the latter half of this year, are ones for strong economic growth. It is unusual—in fact, I think, unprecedented—that governments are defeated in those circumstances. Let us look at the details of the Australian economy and compare the record of the Labor government with the record of the previous Fraser government, a government in which the now Prime Minister was a Treasurer. On inspection, you can see that the records, on a historic Australian national comparison—if you like, us, the Labor government of the time, compared to them, the Liberal government of the time—show that we had much more effective managerial credentials than they did. If you compare us on a geographical or global basis—that is, to like economies elsewhere in the world—our economic performance was indeed, by that measure too, outstanding.

If one compares the records on economic growth, one sees that the average rate of real economic growth during the Labor period of office was 3.7 per cent. When Mr Howard was Treasurer it was 2.2 per cent. The average rate of inflation during the period in which Mr Howard was Treasurer was 9.8 per cent whereas under the Labor government it was, on average, 5.3 per cent, and since June 1991 it was on average 2.5 per cent. The rate of inflation at the time Mr Howard last left office as Treasurer in Australia was 11.4 per cent, whereas the rate of inflation when we faced the electors early this year was 5.1 per cent. And so the figures go.

I turn to another key measure: employment. The average number of jobs created per year during the period of Mr Howard's incumbency as Treasurer was 50,199, whereas during our 13 years of office we averaged on the job creation front 164,514 jobs per annum. The average annual growth in employment during Mr Howard's incumbency as Treasurer was 0.8 per cent, whereas under us it was 2.9 per cent. Unemployment when John Howard left office as Treasurer was 10 per cent, whereas the rate when we faced the electors was about 8.1 per cent.

On the measure that most home owners in Australia are concerned about—that is, the measure of home loan interest rates—the average home loan interest rate today is roughly around 9.7 per cent, whereas when Mr Howard left office in 1983 it was 14 per cent, with a strong argument being that the practical rate, given the cocktail nature of the loans at the time, was about 18.9 per cent.

I make those comparisons for a number of reasons. I make them because I want to make two observations about this election. The first observation is that I think the modern Australian electorate is certainly more volatile than we have become used to in our previous electoral experience. Indeed, I think that, with strong economic performance, the electorate is more ready to pay attention to issues such as the `it's time' factor. That type of approach does count in their minds more than it would at other times of economic difficulty. So, in part, I think the decision was made easier by the electors facing to a `it's time' type of enticement than it would have been had the economy been in less good shape than it is now.

The other element of this election that is worthy of noting in this address-in-reply speech is, as well, the policies that the opposition at the time, now the government, ran on in that election were policies that mirrored in many respects the policies of the government of the day; that is, the policies of the Labor Party.

I remember, graphically and surprisingly, ads being aired in the closing days of the campaign on, for example, Medicare—an area in which the now government, then opposition, had trenchantly criticised us, the government, during 13 years of Labor government in this country—indicating that, in fact, they had moved to a position in which Medicare, one of the defining issues of difference between the two major parties in this country, was now an issue of no difference. That obviously means that they a have jumped from their position of the past—an implicit admission that they were wrong in the past and acceptance that we were right; that we have pioneered and engineered significant change in Australian health care delivery and health care servicing in this country; and that now they would join us and minimise that difference between us.

Many of the other policy formulations that they put were formulations of policy that we had pioneered too. We have as an outcome of this election—I must say there are a few notable exceptions to those points—a situation in which the risks of voting conservative were minimised as a deliberate election ploy. Mr Howard was presented to the electors as someone who would not rock the boat, who would not bring in radical change and who would tread softly. It would be pretty much business as usual. I think that, as I have said before, no doubt the Australian people take the view that if the economy is sound they can then risk a change of government.

As well, I think the peculiar outcome of this election is that the Liberal‐National Party coalition is governing with, essentially, the Labor mandate and that the Australian people have taken the Liberal‐National Party commitment to that mandate at face value. While recognising that fact as an analytical imperative, nonetheless, unfortunately, there are already signs that that faith is being betrayed. Of course, we in opposition, loyal to our task, will take every opportunity to point out where the mandate has been deviated from.

As well as those remarks about the most recent election there are, of course, lessons in the outcome for the Labor Party. We are a party that certainly has retained a vision for the future, a flexibility in the application of the principles for which we stand so that they fit the circumstances of the time and a fundamental commitment to standing up for the ordinary Australian people in this country. But the election lessons are lessons of us in defeat, and we will honestly face what those lessons mean to us. We will forge again a strong bond with the Australian people, and we will rekindle the confidence that they have in us that enabled us to govern in this country for so long and so successfully. We will come back to power as soon as that will and confidence is restored.

What troubles me about the present Australian government is their readiness to manipulate the arguments, to manipulate the economic outcomes and the expectations of the community to suit political ends—to, in fact, engage in political double speak. For example, in the field of small business, we have had a lot of rhetoric about the importance of small business to the Australian economy. Of course, small business is integral to the success of the Australian economy. This is a country in which small business is the most common form of business found anywhere, and about 80 per cent of business activities conducted in this country are conducted by what you would define as small business. Therefore, it is not to provide a great insight but, nonetheless, to cite a reassuring fact when one says that small business is the rock upon which economic growth will be built. If you can encourage the growth of small business, so too will you encourage the growth of employment.

That is true, but it is also in the field of a motherhood statement and it does not take us any further. The truth of those assertions, the truth of that propaganda position, really is found in the detailed policy prescriptions about how the objectives enunciated by those soft words are to be realised.

When one turns to the government's policy platform in that respect, one finds it thin on detail and, in fact, contradictory in many respects, superficial in the extreme, and patronising of many of the advocates and spokespersons of small business. It takes their words and twists them in a way in which it might appeal on the broad front, without being specific to the particular policies and needs of the small business community. I want to go through some of those elements of superficiality and contradiction so that I can illustrate my point by resort to actual examples and detail. But, before I do, I make a couple of threshold observations generally about the economic approach of the government as enunciated both in the policy statements before the election and things that they have said since the election.

We have had today, at least by one or two of the speakers from the government, a reference to what they have styled for propaganda purposes—the so-called $8 billion Labor black hole in the budget. Of course, this is not true in the context in which it is now being used as a political slogan. It relates to forward estimates. It relates to a speculative possibility. It is, as I said after question time, a situation in which the Treasury notoriously is conservative about outcomes. Those figures change and will change come budget time, and they will change as the various parameters of the macro economy change.

The figures are already different because of the most recent reported figures on inflation level outcomes achieved by the policies of Labor when it was in office. I do not think this furphy that is being used as the raison d'etre for a sweeping axing of government services and cutting of jobs in the public sector—a reduction in efficiencies in the public sector and a withdrawal and reduction of services to people who rely on government services or industries that work with government—is justified in any way.

I believe this furphy of this so‐called $8 billion black hole is being used to justify a slash and burn policy which will, in the end, dishonour the political promises made before the election by the then opposition. It will introduce Fightback by stealth and will undermine its commitments in the Medicare and health field, certainly in the education field and bizarrely in the field of employment generation. You don't have to believe all of them; you just have to see the credibility of some of the changes being foreshadowed, particularly in the employment area. By cutting employment and employment generation programs in order to reduce outlays, one cuts the ability of the government to help people find jobs to suit their skills. The government ran to the election on the basis that it is the party that can create employment. Now it is talking about cutting the very programs that will help deliver that outcome.

As well—this is my main point in economic terms—the cutting back of government programs in the economy as it is poised at the present time will have a dampening effect on business activity and therefore will start to slow economic growth. The anticipation is that in the second half of this year we will have strong economic growth. Maybe the judgment is being made on the government side that we can therefore absorb a few hits from massive government cuts. Irrespective of that judgment, the truth will be that it will slow economic activity and cause more unemployment then otherwise would have been the case.

Let us take the bizarre example of ripping about $1 billion worth of expenditure out of the acquisition of information technology. As is commonly understood and appreciated in business and in the Australian community, information technology is an enabler of greater efficiencies and a deliverer of different services—a greater choice in services and a greater reach in service delivery. Chopping out $1 billion of expenditure will mean reducing the ability of a modern government to deliver up to the minute services in the best and most effective possible way and to save other costs elsewhere. It is a cutting off your nose to spite your face approach.

It will also have a massive impact on Australian industry. Australia has the second largest IT, information technology, industry in the Asia-Pacific area. We come in just behind Japan and ahead of every other country in the Asia-Pacific area. That has been built up because it was nurtured by the former Labor government with partnerships for development programs and a whole series of other things that have helped to build an indigenous Australian information technology industry.

Government purchasing was used to build that industry sector. By chopping out government services, by refusing to continue with an enlightened program of efficiencies generated by the enabling technology of information technology, we not only curtail or impair the ability of government to give to the taxpayers what they want and what they are entitled to but also stilt and stunt a major industry sector which is important to our future economic growth and which, if it does not grow apace, will mean that we will import the technology they would have created in Australia from overseas and blow out our current account deficit as well.

Let us look at factor F, which is the pharmaceutical area. We provide a payment to companies that produce pharmaceuticals in this country because they sell to the government and we peg the prices so there is no free market. We pay a bounty to them on the basis that they locate their research and development here, they locate their operations here, they export overseas and then attract a bounty. That compensates for the lack of a free market for them and has enabled a number of Australian pharmaceutical companies to grow and become world competitive at a time in which there is a rationalisation in this industry sector globally. But this has meant that we are a player. If you chop that bounty out, if you chop the factor F program out, as has been widely reported will occur, you will therefore, again, undercut a major Australian industry sector.

When I say these cuttings will dampen Australian economic activity and undercut business activity, I have described two clear examples of major industry sectors important to the economic development of a modern industrial state in which this government is moving in a regressive way. That is the first of my two thresholds. The second of my two thresholds is the oft cited and much bruited changes to industrial relations that the government has announced.

During the election campaign, the then opposition was very keen to sneak up to people and whisper quietly in the ear of the electorate, `Don't worry. We're not going to do anything that is going to hurt any individuals.' If you look at what detail we now have available, it is unmistakable that the impact will be the possibility that wages will fall across Australia because individual workers could be victimised—their wages could be put at risk, their living standards could be put at risk and their families could be put at risk because of those changes.

I think the government should pause here. It should not proceed any further. It should try to forge a better and deeper understanding with the Australian union movement about how these changes can go forth. It should not foist them on the union movement after nominal consultations in which there is no change or very little change based on the evidence that can be adduced.

If the government proceeds down the course that it has now embarked on, it will simply be inviting unions in this country to maximise their bargaining position before any legal changes are made, and that would be disruptive to the economy in itself. It would fracture our internationally recognised record of industrial peace and the genuine workplace cooperation that we have been able to build up over the years. It would also drive Australia down the New Zealand road of low wages but not high skill. It is the turning away from high skills and the embracing of the low wage concept that is, I think, at the base of these changes and, in economic terms, the worst element of them. It would penalise good employers who have built trust and confidence with their own work force by encouraging negative cost cutting by bad employers forcing the good employers to follow suit if they are to remain competitive. I urge the government to pause, to engage in genuine discussions, to recognise the strength and merit of the cases that can be adduced to show that progress here is being dramatically but cooperatively achieved, and to not unilaterally proceed now and fracture the industrial harmony that this country has obtained and carefully built and nurtured after many years.

These changes that I have just referred to will affect all business—big business, medium business and, most of all, small business. This is why the government's rhetoric on small business is very empty. Let us look at what the government is proposing to do in terms of what it said before the election. I am not talking here about the rumours and leaks emerging out of the government in its run to the budget, but what it promised to do before the election and which one must have a full expectation it will try to deliver on. In the industry and science area alone there is to be a cost cutting of $270 million in programs that are key supports for small‐ to medium‐sized business in this country. These are programs that are strategically targeted to meet the needs of small business, to help them flourish and grow in the Australian community.

Take the innovation statement that the Labor government brought down in December last year. That statement is aimed at keeping Australian inventions in Australia, using our scientific and entrepreneurial ingenuity and generating investment in and the commercialisation of those inventions in this country. That program is now being swept aside. We can stand on the dock and wave goodbye to yet some more Australian technology, as foreign markets commercialise on our science and industry ingenuity. The innovation statement, which would have set up a national system of innovation for this country in a way that would have kept those inventions here, has been swept aside.

BREAK.PARA: Take the empty rhetoric of the government when it talks about the need to increase trade and the need to work with Australian industry to do so. The government, according to its election platform, is proposing to cut the export market development grants and the other supports that are provided as financial incentives for companies to get into export. Export market development grants are fundamental and critical, particularly for small business. Small business cannot export without access to those funds. It encourages small business people to recover the costs of developing a market position in a foreign offshore market and it helps to defray some of the costs for them in going overseas to do that. By cutting those funds, we cut the penetration of these Australian companies into those markets and reduce our export effort accordingly.

If the rumours about Austrade are true the international market intelligence system that this country has developed over the years to provide best knowledge about state of play in foreign markets across a whole range of industry sectors for Australian small‐ to medium‐sized business will be significantly reduced. We will therefore be going blind in those markets. We will then be at a disadvantage compared to companies from other countries and we will not be competitive in anything like the way in which we now have a reputation for being.

What the government has undertaken to do in the export area is, of course, unbelievable. Let us go further and look at the DIFF Scheme. This is a scheme for soft loans for Australian companies to develop in export markets. Two of the companies that spring to mind, being the biggest beneficiaries, are Clough Engineering—of course, the principal of that company is the President of the Liberal Party in Western Australia—and Transfield. The country in which most of these funds are expended is Indonesia, a developing country where we can use soft loans to get our infrastructure developers in to help develop the infrastructure of those countries. This scheme is going to be removed if the government's election undertakings are to be believed. Our penetration of the fast growing infrastructure market in the Asia‐Pacific region among the developing economies will be undercut. Jobs will be lost where jobs have now been gained, and companies that have become successful will be made marginal because of a lack of access to or an ability to rely on that scheme.

I can go further: research and development funding is to be reduced. We in this country have a great ability to invent things but we want to encourage more private sector research and development, and incentives are needed to do that. By cutting those funds, it means that we can come up with the ideas but we cannot develop them for the marketplace. If we cannot do that, we cannot take advantage of our capacity and win new markets in a fast changing international marketplace. That is a regressive change.

The NIES scheme, which is delivered by Ausindustry, is to be cut. Every small business company in Australia knows about NIES. It is a scheme that helps small business, in a personal way, to develop business plans and marketing strategies. It is delivered with the state governments. The states will complain about this, and so they should, because they will have to bear the brunt of the reaction that comes from industry when this is cut. But this is also slated to be reduced. Let us move now to the diesel fuel rebate. If that rebate is abolished, it puts a tax on exports in this country and pushes the current account deficit further into the red.

Let us go to the tariff concession order scheme. We tidied up the tariff concession order scheme in our innovation statement, and we committed ourselves in the election campaign to consult further with the Australian business interests and the Australian industry organisations about that scheme. I think it is a good scheme and it ought to continue in its now revised form, the form we announced after the innovation statement.

Australian industry—including the most prestigious industry organisations in this country, and some of the most conservative—is up in arms over this government's threats to cut this scheme. By cutting this scheme, we would make Australian industry less—not more—competitive in the world. You tie not one but two arms behind their backs when they are in the international marketplace trying to compete with foreign companies by, in fact, imposing a tariff on the import of intermediate goods where there is no Australian producer.

If there is no Australian producer, then the tariff is not protecting any Australian company; it is just a revenue raising exercise. It imposes costs by increasing the price of those intermediate goods to the Australian companies that need those goods to produce a final product that can compete in the marketplace. So I think that that would indeed be a regressive step. They are some examples—I have to say they are superficially treated examples—of where I believe the slash and burn policy of the government is wrong in fact. It is wrong in principle, but it is also wrong here in application, because it does not go to improving the competitiveness of Australian industry.

It undermines the competitiveness of all industry, particularly small business, the ones who are most vulnerable, who have less discretionary time to protect themselves, who are overpressed and who need every assistance the government can provide to help them up the ladder. That is what these cuts do. These are not whimsical ideas by me; these are black letter commitments by this government when it was running in the election campaign.

I think that the somewhat superficial remarks that have been made by the government should be set aside. These programs should be restored and there should be a real program of assistance for small business, not empty rhetoric, not fobbing off, not patronising industry leaders, not telling them what is good for them, but actually working with them to help build this economy internationally as a more competitive economy.
Debate interrupted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the first opportunity I have had to offer to Senator Stott Despoja my congratulations on the presentation of her first speech earlier this evening.

SPEECH.PARA: Last Sunday, the people of Port Arthur, Tasmania, Australia, and indeed the world, suffered and witnessed a tragedy of unspeakable proportions. Times of tragedy often bring out the true character of people. Following this tragedy we witnessed the discreet and humble national leadership displayed by His Excellency the Governor-General in calling for the ecumenical service held in Canberra on Monday. All Australians would wish to thank His Excellency for his leadership.

Today I attended a state funeral service in Hobart. Prior to that service, families and friends of victims were invited to partake of coffee at Hobart's Hadley's Hotel. I was deeply touched and privileged to have been invited by the family of my friend Glen Roy Pears to be part of that gathering. As I was there, I observed their Excellencies, the Governor-General and the Governor of Tasmania, quietly and unassumingly move amongst the mourners offering the nation's and the state's sympathy. Their demeanour, their presence and their obvious sympathy made me feel proud of the heads of state of Australia and Tasmania. The community turnout today in Hobart and the messages were of great comfort and support to those of us who mourned. The flying of flags at half mast throughout the nation was a truly appreciated gesture of solidarity. So out of this tragedy, we can celebrate our unity, support and love for each other.

But it is with a heavy heart that I juxtapose these positive aspects of our national character with the behaviour of some within the Australian media. Let me preface my comments by saying that I believe in the freedom of the media. Having said that, let me say that that freedom, so unfettered as it is, demands that it be exercised with dignity and with responsibility. What I now say is said not in anger, but rather in genuine sorrow. But it was with revulsion and disgust that my fellow Tasmanians and Australians observed the sharklike feeding frenzy the media are engaged in.

The Today program sent Steve Liebmann to the front door of the Royal Hobart Hospital for sensationalism. Some of his comments, I have to say, left a lot to be desired. The Australian published a doctored photograph of the accused. Listening to its editor's defence on radio, I could not help but compare the standards the media apply to themselves as compared to those in public life. There were elements of the media that went doorknocking in the township of Port Arthur, wanting to get the new story, the different angle. There was no sympathy for the people, just the callous seeking out of an extra story, a different angle.

There were journalists stationed at the Melbourne airport gate lounges at which planes from Hobart were arriving. Journalists were calling out to the passengers, `Is there anybody on the plane that was at Port Arthur?' There were some people on those planes who had been counselled at the Qantas lounge before leaving Hobart airport for the trip back to the mainland, only to be confronted by those elements of the media not showing any concern or respect, but just wanting that angle, just wanting that story.

There was no thought, no sympathy, no discretion. All those things were completely discarded for the sake of that story. Frontline has nothing on the tactics employed by the real media. The Sydney Morning Herald best highlights my concerns. Allow me to give you an example of their absolute disregard for privacy. Glen Pears, my friend that I have previously mentioned has, as yet, not been positively identified, although those of us who know Glen have resigned ourselves to the worst. His remains have not been positively identified, but, really, in our minds there is no doubt that there is one remaining person and we believe that to be Glen.

PARA.BREAK: The Sydney Morning Herald, undeterred by the fact that Glen had not been officially identified as a victim, sought to obtain a photograph of Glen from his family. This was officially denied them by their lawyer, Mr George Walker. Within 15 minutes of that denial a person identifying herself as a repre sentative of the Sydney Morning Herald arrived at the Pears' home announcing that she was authorised to collect the photograph of Glen Pears. Unbeknown to the Sydney Morning Herald, the lawyer who had just told the Sydney Morning Herald no was in the Pears' residence. Suffice it to say, the person who alleged she had the authority was told to leave.

SPEECH.PARA: Undeterred, the Sydney Morning Herald continued in their search for a photograph, although they knew that the family did not want any photographs published. What was their next port of call? It was Glen's former employer. They rang requesting a photograph from the staff file. His former employer quite properly sought the permission of the family. Do you know when that phone call was made? When they got home after the memorial service today. After that they received this call from his former employer saying, `The Sydney Morning Herald has made a request to release the photograph from the staff file; do you give permission?' Of course, it was denied.

I ask those in the Sydney Morning Herald, `How do you think the family felt, having said, "No, this is our request, please respect it"?' They then, I would submit, deceitfully sent someone around to the Pears' home to try to get one. When that failed they went off to the employer. The family, in their grief after the state service today, was confronted by another request through the back door. Why did they do that? Was it out of respect to Glen Pears? Was it to try to help his family cope with the grief? Why can't they just leave the family alone?

I say to the Sydney Morning Herald and other media outlets that your insensitivity, your heartlessness and your crassness have done untold damage to your profession. The sensational, the biggest story, is the only priority it seems. This desire for the story rates above any other consideration. Next time you people in the media seek to criticise a trade unionist or an employer or somebody else in public life, I say, `Just look at yourself in the mirror and you will see an element of our community which is far worse than those that you seek to criticise—an element that has failed to show respect, compassion, sincerity and empathy.' The story, the photograph and the sensational have been the motivator throughout. The ethics of journalism in this national tragedy have been found to be devastatingly wanting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wheelwright, Sen Thomas

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this adjournment debate to speak briefly about my recent attendance at the Inter‐Parliamentary Union Conference in Instanbul. I do so because it was the Senate which paid my fare, so I feel required to at least say a few words about my experiences there. I must thank the Senate in that regard because I found it a very stimulating and useful experience to be in Instanbul. I was lucky enough to be able to speak in the first plenary session. The speech that I gave was very well received, to the extent that the Japanese delegation decided to incorporate it in their report to the Diet in Japan.

SPEECH.PARA: Having got such international notoriety, I thought it might be appropriate for me to provide it to the Senate here today. I will not go through it, but the first line says that I fear that parliamentarians are losing control of politics. I went on to talk about my experience in Papeete and Mururoa. I know that Senator Margetts, who was there, would join with me in saying that as a parliamentarian the experience of going with other parliamentarians who acted out of individual conscience rather than as representatives of their own governments was an unique experience and one which I think gave us all faith in parliamentary institutions and the power of individual parliamentarians as opposed to the power of bureaucrats or diplomats.

As I said, the speech was very well received. Having been to the Inter‐Parliamentary Union, I was given an opportunity to see the worth of that institution. I was asked to serve on the Cyprus committee, which deals with one of the most thorny problems of the Mediterranean or, indeed, the world. The IPU is the only international institution which talks to both sides of the people on the island of Cyprus. The UN can only recognise one side, but the IPU, in a spirit of genuine desire to find some common ground and some solution, is able to accept delegations from political parties on both sides. We were also able to have about half an hour with the Turkish foreign minister on that question. The IPU is also able to bring a better understanding of the issues of terrorism and things which might not seem so important to us, such as fish stocks, but which are very important to countries in the Third World.

I would like to thank for the assistance I received Peter Keele from the Australian parliament and Pamela MacDonald from DFAT, who worked very tirelessly for our delegation to provide briefing notes and everything that we might require. She certainly seemed to know the face of absolutely everyone from the hundreds of delegates who came from all over the world.

The person I would particularly like to thank is the Australian Ambassador to Turkey, Mr David Evans, and his wife Pamela. He worked tirelessly on our behalf. He gave our delegation a sense of authority which I think was missing from some of the other delegations who were not quite so well supported. It was a pleasure from my point of view to be supported by someone so knowledgeable on the issues of not only that country but international politics in general. I would also like to thank his wife because too often we fail to recognise the efforts of the partners of people who do these difficult jobs for Australia. They are an unpaid member of the partnership but they are no less unstinting in the efforts that they go to to make people feel welcome and to provide very useful assistance.

Finally, as everyone knows, on these international trips there is an element of friendly ribbing between people from different political parties. Generally, there is a good feeling about it. There is said to be a 200‐kilometre rule about some of the conversations that are entered into in private but there is one I do not think anyone would mind me repeating.

PARA.BREAK: We were taken by the ambassador through Istanbul to give us a feel of the place. We were passing a somewhat less than salubrious part of the city when the leader of our delegation, Steve Martin, commented that obvious ly things were not great for everyone in Istanbul; there was poverty, and so on. One of the Liberal members of our delegation said, `That's where all the battlers are, pal.' I replied, `Yes, they've probably got a photo of John Howard in every house.' One of the Liberals said, `Yes, and Mr Abbott as well'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to commend Senator Abetz for his contribution to the debate on the adjournment. He raised some critical issues. Senator Abetz and I do not always agree but I agree absolutely with what he said tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to raise an issue which has been raised with me by a number of pork producers in Queensland—from Warwick, the South Burnett area and Monto. They have a number of concerns about their industry, particularly the prospect of more pork producers going out of business or being taken over.

A couple of their concerns involve the possible initiation of a couple of large piggeries in the Warwick area. One of them, already quite famous in this place having been mentioned quite often here by another senator—Danpork—could be starting a 10,000‐sow piggery.

The producers want to know whether Danpork was given favoured treatment in terms of environmental responsibilities and controls. It wants to site its piggery only one kilometre from the Condamine River which, of course, is part of the Murray‐Darling Basin.

One of the positive things about Danpork is that it claims to be creating 500 jobs through building such a super‐piggery in the area. But the pork producers, particularly in the South Burnett, asked me what point there was in creating 500 jobs if you lost 500 farms because of it.

They have also raised with me the issue of the importation of Canadian pork. I certainly agree with the new Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Bruce Scott, who for some years has raised this issue on behalf of the pork producers. I would like to mention a number of concerns that he has raised.

BREAK.PARA: I want to place on record a number of company names and brand names which have been used to import, process and/or retail products containing Canadian pork. It is important that we understand this. The alternative is proper labelling laws so that consumers have a choice. I trust that the coalition will very quickly bring legislation into this place that will allow consumers to know what they are purchasing.

In the absence of such legislation, I inform the Senate that, as I understand it, Meapro of Sydney, which is sold through the Franklins stores, is one of these companies. Primo and Goldcob are two product brand names sold through the Coles stores. Duncan and Davis are processors of these products. Redlich, Ritter and Dyson, Melbourne manufacturers of ham and salami products, also process and retail imported Canadian pork.

My other concern is the health threat that Canadian pork still poses. I am happy to repeat some of the concerns raised by Bruce Scott in previous years. He called for a ban on all Canadian pig meat imports because of his concern about disease. He specifically talked about the threat of importing porcine respiratory and reproductive syndrome, otherwise known as mystery swine disease, MSD. He pointed out that this is very prevalent in regions of Canada and results in a reduction of fertility rates, increased neonatal mortality and an increase in the prevalence and severity of other diseases.

He pointed out that the infective agent is unknown and that the risk associated with the importation of fresh meat and frozen semen from Canada cannot be quantified. He was reported in a press release as saying:

The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service has supported a ban against Canadian semen imports due to little being known about the disease's transmission but continues to allow the import of fresh pig meat.

While we readily import a possible diseased product from Canada a local meat works recently had a consignment of beef refused entry to Canada due to a lower class `G' in the kilogram measurement on the cartons.

It is this kind of unequal competition which Australian producers have to face in the global market. I agree with Mr Scott when he says that Australian producers pay a levy to the Australian Pork Corporation towards the promotion of the consumption and sale of Australian pork and that Canadian importers directly benefit from such promotion with no associated costs. Those are the issues that I want to raise; I could refer to many others, but I know that there are other speakers in the adjournment debate.

I again impress on the government the need for, in the least, proper labelling so that Australian consumers can make a choice for themselves about whether they want to eat an Australian product or imported products.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight on a very sad occasion. It is ironic that tonight Senator Wheelwright referred to the parliamentarians who last year travelled to Tahiti to participate with parliamentarians from many parts of the world to help in solidarity the French Tahitian people who were deeply concerned about the beginning of French nuclear tests again on their soil. When I came back to Australia from Tahiti, as soon as I could I fulfilled a promise to a woman I met in Tahiti, Marguerite Tetuanui, to present in the Senate a speech which she was to present to the Beijing Women's Conference. She was unable to attend that conference. A small section of her speech states:

SPEECH.PARA: I am not a scientific but I am sure that all the population of Polynesia die from cancer. My mother is dead from the cancer of stomach. My Brother Paul is dead from general cancer. My sister Celestine is dead from cancer of lungs. My sister Leonie is dead from cancer of lungs. My sister Liliane is dead from cancer of breast and my sister Madeline and myself had the cancer of the breast. Both of us have had operation; and thank God who (help) us and keep us alive.
I received a letter from another wonderful woman, Ahuura Paia, who spent much of three days with me and Kerrie Tucker, a member of the ACT parliament. Her letter states, amongst other things:
Dear Dee,

. . . at this time: It is our sad duty to inform you of the passing of our Beloved Marguerite TETUANUI on the 23 April 1996 17.55 pm, Tahiti time. Marguerite fell ill a short time after you left us last summer. As a result Marguerite was unable to correspond with you. In March it was diagnosed as Cancer. Thankfully she did not suffer long.

I am appalled that we in Australia continue to supply uranium to countries who use it in nuclear weapons programs. This has gone on for too long. The brave people of this world, like Marguerite, who fought against the tragedies caused by nuclear weapons, should be commemorated. I hope that the work Marguerite has done will help the world to change its mind about the production of nuclear materials for nuclear weapons.
